PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose the cuts to Childcare Assistance available for holiday absences for families who use long day care centres.

These cuts, which both the Liberal/National Coalition and the ALP support, reduce the amount of Childcare Assistance previously paid by the Government to parents for allowable holiday absences by half.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate reverse its support for these regressive changes to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows strong support for a quality, accessible, liberating, public higher education system. As such we are opposed to the education measures announced in the 1996 Federal Budget process.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate not support legislative attempts to
introduce up front fees for Australian undergraduate students;
lower the thresholds at which HECS fees must begin to be repaid;
increase the level of HECS fees;
introduce a system of HECS whereby fees are differentiated according to course; or
reduce funding, in particular operating grants, to the sector;
and use all other means possible to oppose attempts to reduce public expenditure to education or increase the private contribution to the system.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should recognise that the Coalition's proposed cost‐cutting measures to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will remove the broadcaster's ability to properly provide services to both its radio and television audiences—particularly those in rural and regional areas.
Your petitioners oppose any cuts to the ABC and request that the Coalition be held to its pre‐election promise to "maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
Your petitioners request that the Senate reject any measures to downgrade the ABC's budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose the cuts to Childcare Assistance available for holiday absences for families who use long day care centres.

These cuts, which both the Liberal/National Coalition and the ALP support, reduce the amount of Childcare Assistance previously paid by the Government to parents for allowable holiday absences by half.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate reverse its support for these regressive changes to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia expresses our grave concerns about the conflict in Sri Lanka as arguably the most significant crisis in the Commonwealth of Nations of which Australia is a member.

We understand that both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have expressed their concerns about the conflict and have advocated sending a fact‐finding parliamentary delegation to Sri Lanka. They have also emphasised the need for an internationally mediated peaceful resolution to the conflict that would bring greater autonomy for the Tamils in Sri Lanka.
We therefore pray that the members of the Senate call on the government:
to persuade the United Nations to authorise a delegation to carry out a fact finding mission to Sri Lanka.
to appeal to the Sri Lankan government to lift the economic embargo and allow non‐government organisations to carry out emergency relief works without any government interference in the Tamil areas.
to appeal to the parties to the conflict to stop the war and negotiate a political solution that recognises the right of self‐determination of Tamils.
to persuade the parties to the conflict to accept the role of an independent "Envoy" to facilitate a negotiated peaceful resolution to the conflict under international observation.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws attention to the Senate that the Government reverse its decision to abolish operational grants to long day child care centres, and the removal of 5,500 long day child care places. This is on the grounds that:
many university and TAFE child care centres will have to increase their fees, causing increased hardship for many studying parents, and even possible closure of centres;

at a time when the Government should be reducing barriers to Higher Education, the proposed changes to HECS as well as AUSTUDY, combined with increased child care costs will have an adverse effect on the participation of parents at university and TAFE;
the child care sector is at a crucial time and is in need of further expansion, not reduction, otherwise many women forced out of higher education and the work force.

And your petitioners ask that the Commonwealth Government reaffirm its pre‐election commitment to maintain the present child care assistance scheme, and to ensure national accreditation of child care centres.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Employment Service
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned, wish to advise the Senate of our opposition to the abolition of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). We call upon the Senate to maintain the CES as a Government funded employment service available to all Australians who are looking for work. We ask that in the 50th year of operation the CES be retained as a service for all Australians and not as a profit orientated enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report:
The necessity for public accountability of all government services provided by government contractors, including:
(a) how best to ensure that the rights, interests and responsibilities of consumers, contracted service providers and government agencies can be defined and protected, with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (i) whether contracting out arrangements should be governed by written contracts between the government agency and the service provider in all cases,

(ii) whether contracts should contain standard clauses dealing with matters such as responsibility for record keeping, complaints and dispute resolution procedures, and the allocation of responsibility between the contracting agency and the contractor in the event of financial or other loss on the part of the consumer, and

(c) whether the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman's Act 1976 should be extended to ensure that it covers all contracted out government services;

(d) ministerial responsibility to Parliament for contracted out services, noting that in other parliamentary systems it has been argued that, with regard to corporatised or contracted out government services, ministerial responsibility extends only to policy issues and does not encompass questions of day‐to‐day management and operation;

(e) whether government, to meet its responsibilities for policy making, should have access to all files, information etc. generated by private‐sector contractors in meeting their contractual obligations; and

(f) whether, and to what extent, claims of commercial‐in‐confidence should be accepted as limiting the right of Parliament to examine contractual arrangements between government agencies and service providers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the administration and management by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy of all aspects of the importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia, together with submissions received by the committee and transcript of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, during its inquiry, the committee received a considerable amount of additional information, some of which is marked confidential, which has assisted the committee in the preparation of its report. The committee will table this material in due course when it is finally sorted out. As soon as this material is compiled and indexed, it will be printed and tabled in the Senate and I expect that this will occur next week.
Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In dealing with the particular issue before us, I have to say that it is one of the most difficult and certainly one of the most contentious issues that I have been involved in in terms of the inquiry process in this place. I would like to put on public record my appreciation, and I am sure the committee's appreciation, to the various people involved—the members of the committee, the secretariat, the witnesses and a whole range of people—for the cooperation they have shown. I also make the point that the report that has been brought down is a unanimous report.

I will deal with some of the issues, realising that we are now dealing with a different situation from that of a year or two ago as far as the importation of foodstuffs into this country and the quarantine requirements are concerned. This comes under the auspices of the previous government. When the Uruguay Round outcomes were finalised, we did move into a different trading situation and different arrangements in relation to Australia's role in foodstuff imports into this country and how quarantine matters or non‐tariff barrier matters should be handled.

The first recommendation which we deal with in this particular report is that we believe in this new trading environment that governments in this country should now, in fact, develop or operate under a whole of government process. Therefore, our first recommendation is that the Quarantine Act be amended so that the final decision in terms of the import of foodstuffs into this country is on a recommendation from the director of quarantine to the minister and/or government, whichever is appropriate according to the circumstances. As I said, this would involve a whole of government approach.

We mention the position of the director of quarantine, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade and their particular role under these new world trading arrangements. That relates back to the Uruguay Round outcomes. Although not specifically mentioned in this recommendation, it would also involve the Minister for the Environment with regard to the environmental implications that could flow on.

This particular application as far as chicken meat is concerned dates back to about 1985, so it has been around a long time, with particular emphasis from about 1991. I make the point—and the committee acknowledges this in the report—that we are not scientists but, nonetheless, in view of the evidence that was put before us, we believe that the heat thermal treatment has never been tested on chicken meat as far as we can find out. In regard to this, we have had information, particularly from Dr Alexander, which was tabled before the committee. We have recommended that AQIS commission tests of the thermal inactivation of Newcastle disease virus and infectious bursal disease virus in chicken meat products under commercial conditions.

I also make the point that this need not necessarily delay the process of decision making, as has been claimed, providing it is dealt with immediately. As a member of the government, I certainly strongly recommend that to the minister and to the government.

The second point that we make in terms of these recommendations, which fits neatly alongside this particular recommendation, is that there be collaboration with the industry in setting up the design of this experiment and this action so that there can be no further disputation about the validity of the science underlying these protocols. You have one group of scientists who, in effect, tell you that the scientific processes are sound and reliable and work, and you have others who tell you that, in fact, it is dangerous to extrapolate results from the particular work that has been done on egg yolk, for example, and apply it across the board to chicken meat, and that is why we have brought down this particular recommendation.

The next recommendation that we deal with is that these field trials be extended to a commercial cooking environment. Once again, we were given evidence that you could have large degrees of variation of temperature in particular ovens, and we would need to be satisfied that the thermograph calibration and its performance in fact did meet the requirements that were needed as far as the process was concerned.

We touch on the necessity for the inspection of plants, wherever they might be. There is already a commitment to go to Thailand, but I will not dwell on that in the time that I have. When it comes to the environmental consideration in terms of the likely introduction of Newcastle disease or infectious bursal disease, there is no appropriate scientific test that can be applied to detect whether or not you have these diseases in the chicken meat after it has been treated other than to feed it to the chickens to find out whether or not they die. This is a pretty thorough test, I guess. As there is no other test, we have recommended that AQIS require area certification from avian disease. The committee believes that AQIS should follow established international practice with regard to disease certification requirements. I make that point because that is practised in other countries.

I turn to the committee's recommendation that the most appropriate assistance measures available for the government's consideration would be introduction of appropriate safeguard action to allow imposition of tariff or quota restriction on importation on a temporary and reducing basis. These were the outcomes of the Uruguay Round and the WTO negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very courageous.

—I am not sure whether it is courageous or not, but I think it is proper. It seems pointless to me and the committee, when this is part of the procedure that was agreed to and which other countries are using and are prepared to use, that Australia should not use those same processes.

SPEECH.PARA: The bound tariff which would apply in Australia, which was agreed to, would amount to 13.7 per cent reducing to nine per cent by the year 2000. In addition, provision is made for the utilisation of import quotas on a reducing basis. A very technical, detailed process is involved there; nonetheless, we have recommended that the government give consideration to using those processes in relation to the import of chicken meat and, I would suggest, other products. We have also recommended an industry assistance package of limited duration similar to the citrus industry package.

There is a lot more to this report than the points I have covered, but I will make some general comments on the whole issue of the importation of foodstuffs into this country. I hope this report does set some guidelines for how we deal with the importation of foodstuffs into Australia. It is absolutely clear from the evidence given to us that there is still confusion about the particular processes that have to be gone through as far as AQIS is concerned, despite the recommendations of the committee I worked on prior to Christmas, of which Senator Burns was the chairman. Certainly Senator Brownhill and others were on that committee.

PARA.BREAK: This particular aspect should be addressed to make it absolutely clear and to separate those roles with total transparency of quarantine issues, adjustment issues and environmental issues. We strongly recommend that to the government because it does create confu sion and significant mistrust between the participants.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points that was particularly brought out by this inquiry was an opinion in the general public, in this case in the chicken industry, that the stance AQIS has adopted is to formalise their position, put that position out for public comment and call that consultation. Once again, that came through very clearly.

I will have more to say about this matter in due course, but I think the position that has been adopted by the committee is one that is sustainable in the longer term for other imports. We want to be absolutely certain, in terms of the processes that will be put in place, that every aspect has been examined. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is one that does not contain any dissent. It is a report that was agreed unanimously by all members of the committee. But it should not be forgotten, in terms of that unanimity, who the odd person out was in this particular debate. That was the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson himself.
—Another doormat.

—It should not be forgotten in this debate, and his colleagues know it, the absolute hash that the minister made out of imported chicken meat. I might say that, considering the processes that it has to go through and the cooking temperatures it would need to be subjected to, hash is probably the only thing you could make out of it by the time it gets here. Senator Boswell knows the mess the minister made of this single-handedly.
—And still making it.

—And is still making it. The committee is rescuing him from this mess of his own creation and, I might add, in a bipartisan way in a unanimous report that contains a number of recommendations that go well beyond the question of chicken meat.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the last election, this was a red hot issue in primary industry. A lot of people do not realise what a significant industry this is for Australia. It employs thousands of Australians in permanent jobs. It is, for example, the single biggest industry in the Hunter Valley in New South Wales. These are things a lot of people do not know.

The question of the importation of this chicken meat had been on the agenda for a considerable period of time and the previous government and the previous minister had made absolutely no decision at all on it. That is a matter now of indisputable public record. The now minister, then the shadow minister, provided to that industry some weeks prior to the election a categorical, written undertaking—with his signature on the bottom of it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which he did not do.
—No, that is correct. He provided an unequivocal, written undertaking that the coalition in government would take no decision on the importation of cooked chicken meat until the Nairn review—
—That's right. Exactly right.

—Senator Boswell, you will get your turn in a minute. Don't try to defend the indefensible. Your own credibility will suffer as a result. The minister provided an unequivocal, written undertaking that the coalition in government would take no decision on the importation of cooked chicken meat until the Nairn review, which I established as minister, into the whole quarantine service had completed its findings and—Senator Boswell, you have forgotten the letter—its recommendations were implemented in full. That is what the letter said.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only did the Nairn review have to complete its work but the recommendations of the Nairn review, which the minister at that stage could not have even contemplated let alone seen, were to be implemented in full. I thought it was an extraordinary undertaking, a stupid undertaking, to give anybody, that site unseen you would bind yourself to have a whole bunch of recommendations that you did not even know would come down implemented in full. Nevertheless, the minister gave this assurance to the industry and said that nothing would happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he kept it.

—He did not, Senator Boswell. The Senate Hansard will show it. The minister then attempted to tell whopping untruths about it when he got caught out, when his representative minister in here—and it is in the Hansard —came into this chamber and said that the minister had made a decision that chicken meat will be imported.
—He hasn't made a decision.

—He backed off it when he got monstered by Senator Crane and no doubt you, Senator Boswell. I was certainly doing a bit of monstering of my own. The minister made a hash of it. Don't believe me; read the Australian Financial Review reports at the time. He made a total and utter mess of it and is still making a mess of it.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why I suggested this reference to the committee so that the committee could rescue the minister for primary industries from the mess he single‐handedly created. To add insult to injury, not only did the minister say that he would not take a decision on importing the meat until the Nairn committee had completed its work and its recommendations had been implemented in full—that is probably still at least a year away yet—but he also gave a commitment, as Senator West and Senator Woodley know, to conduct a full environmental impact statement under the EPIP act into the importation of cooked chicken meat. To fix that puzzled expression on your face, Senator Boswell, I can provide you with the letter.

So the minister gave two written undertakings, Senator, before you leap to your feet to defend him—one for an EIS and the other for the Nairn committee. He made a total hash of it. I give due credit to the chair of the coalition primary industry committee for the work he did to get this stupid decision reversed. The minister backed off it at 1,000 miles an hour when he got monstered by Senator Crane as well as being monstered by a few of us on this side of the house.

But what angered me—and I am still angry about it—is that, having messed it up, this wimp of a minister then attempted to publicly put the blame on the previous government that had taken no decision whatsoever to import chicken meat. As I said publicly at the time we went out of government or prior to that, Senator McMullan, the then Minister for Trade, and I had actually completed a draft cabinet submission—it will be sitting there in the department somewhere.

I was concerned as the then minister for primary industries that in this brave post‐GATT world we must take quarantine decisions based on the science, not on the politics. The reason I make these remarks is to point to what I think is one of the most important recommendations in this report that goes way beyond chicken meat, and I am sure Senator Crane would agree. It is so important for our national interest that we handle this business properly because it is a fact, as the minister said last night on the 7.30 Report, that this country exports in dollar terms five times what we import.

Having said that, it is a fact that if a quarantine decision is taken to remove a prohibition which formerly existed it has the same effect of ripping away an entire tariff law that formerly existed but with none of the consideration that a whole of government approach needs to give to it to consider what assistance that industry might need afterwards if the decision is taken to import. Senator McMullan and I engaged in discussion that lasted almost a year as to how we could appropriately redress this structural problem with our quarantine arrangements—and it does need to be fixed. The then Minister for Trade and I had agreed as to how it would be done.

An important recommendation is in this report. I commend the committee and its chair on dealing with an extremely important issue, I think, very expeditiously. This was done quickly, but it was done thoroughly and the recommendations of this report have very profound implications for the quarantine regime in this country that go beyond the question of chicken meat.

One of the recommendations I would draw to the attention of senators is the recommendation that says that in future—and this will need a legislative change—the arrangements should be changed so that the decision maker at the end of the day is not simply AQIS alone. The technical decision as to whether a product should be imported to this country must remain with AQIS, but it needs to have the involvement of the minister and, in my view, the cabinet. Apparently the Prime Minister is also of this view, I am delighted to hear, at least in respect of chicken meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wasn't this done when you were in government?

—I just explained that, Senator Macdonald. We were actively moving to do this in government because of the concern that the Minister for Trade and I both had and that, let me tell you, Senator, is a matter of departmental record. It is right there and can be proven any time you like.
—How long were you minister for?
—Two short years, Senator—not long enough. If I could refer senators to any recommendation in this report, it would be the one I have just referred to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may recall that I have spoken on this issue on a number of occasions. Just checking back this year, I have spoken on the issue of AQIS and cooked chicken meat on 9 May, 20 May, 22 May and 20 June. Senators may also remember that it was the Greens who spoke out very loud and long during the debate on the Uruguay Round of GATT, the World Trade Organisation, expressing concerns that we were flying blind into an area which we had not properly considered. Both major parties were saying, `Shut up. It is all going to be great.'

SPEECH.PARA: We had inquiries which were not worth the paper they were written on because they only went for a couple of days. We only had a couple of days to do the whole inquiry into the World Trade Organisation bills—the entire lot of bills that have affected us so profoundly. If you want to tell me that we had more than two hearings on this, tell me. How many public hearings were there—one, two? There were no more than two.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were three days.

—Oh, three days. Senator Crane tells me we had three days of hearings on the World Trade Organisation. This is what we are dealing with in a situation where we are now saying, `Isn't this outrageous.' We are now, I am pleased to say, beginning to see the association with this mess in relation to AQIS and the confusion with trade barriers. We are now beginning to debate it, I am pleased to say. But it is after three years. We are now beginning to talk about it as an issue that needs to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now even, I am pleased to see, beginning to talk about an environmental impact statement. But it is well overdue to start looking at the range of issues to which Australia signed up under the Uruguay Round of GATT, now the World Trade Organisation. It is well overdue for us to now go in and look systematically at the range of agreements and do what I said we should be doing right from the beginning—that is, a social, economic and environmental impact statement of what it is we signed up for. It is time. I asked originally, and you said, `No, we don't know what we are signing. After we sign the Uruguay Round of GATT, it will be too difficult.' Well, it should not be too difficult now because the issues are falling in front of our faces.

It is well overdue. We are fighting for the rural industries, and it was various areas of the rural industries which came up to those inquiries at the time—the citrus industry, the egg industry and the dairy industry. What did we do as a parliament? We ignored them. We told them to go away because there would be so many benefits that they ought to be not selfish and they should let the whole thing go through.

We told them the meat industry was going to benefit. We told them that wool growers were going to benefit. What situation is the meat industry in now? What situation is the wool industry in now? Who are the real beneficiaries of this proposal? Not just trade, but investment. What has happened to the control of a number of our industries. Let us look at the banana industry. What has happened there? The industry has been taken over. We have a virtual monopoly of the banana industry in Australia. What has happened to the price? Has it given more varieties? No. Has it given a better price? No. What has it done? It has given control of an entire industry of production to an overseas investor.

These are the kinds of decisions we made as a result of the way Australia approached the signing of the Uruguay Round of GATT. It is about time all these reports are beginning to come into the media. The issues go well beyond this particular issue. The issues obviously go into the salmon industry; the issues go into the ridiculous situation of how we have also signed up for the reversal of the onus of proof on intellectual property; the issues go into whether a person can do research in Australia and get their papers checked by overseas people. There are a whole lot of issues which we have not had the guts to look at in Australia.

Why? Who is stopping us from looking at these issues? It is in our best interests to find out what it is we signed up for—what it is we need to do and know before we go into any further rounds of GATT; what it is we need to know before we leap into any further negotiations on APEC; what it is we need to know when Australia goes into any negotiations internationally in relation to our trade regime; and what it is we need to know about how our trade regime impacts on domestic economies in Australia.

It is also about time we started opening our eyes and looking at what the impacts are on the developing countries throughout the world. Every time I have in my office somebody from a developing country who comes to see me about other issues, I take the opportunity of asking them what their situation currently is with the outcomes of the Uruguay Round of GATT. They usually tell me about the newly imposed structural adjustment programs in their countries.

The impacts, generally, are indicating that there is a growing gap between rich and poor in those countries. I can tell you that part of the argument that was used for Australia and other countries supporting the Uruguay Round of GATT was that we ought not to be selfish because this would benefit developing countries. Well, it is a load of rot. Some people are benefiting in developing countries, but it tends to be the same people who are benefiting in countries like Australia, because they are the same people.

If we have a new deregulated trade and investment regime, some people certainly are making a lot of money. They are transferring and vertically integrating their businesses. They can manipulate rules and regulations. They can put pressure on countries, host countries—the countries to which they are operating. They can play off tax regimes. They can play off environmental regimes. They can play off tax customs regimes, and they have that power.

But this is not a free market; this is a controlled market. If we have the guts and the courage, we are going to have to deal with this some time or other in Australia. Bit by bit, some of the thoughtful elements of the media are beginning to see the connections between what we have signed and what the outcomes are, and it does no good at all for us to concentrate only on AQIS unless we start looking back at the nature of the agreement which Australia has signed.

If Australian negotiators do not start—and not only in relation to this specific rule—going into international fora and arguing sensibly on the basis of full information, then we will continue to see these arguments. Not only that, we will have huge motions in this chamber once again when entire fish species are being destroyed or dying or being overrun by species that come from other places. When a species moves from one environment to another, what is known from other countries about the impact does not necessarily relate to what we know in Australia because it is a different environmental situation.

So what will we have in the future? Are we all going to come in here outraged when something actually does happen, as we did with the situation of the pilchard kill? How many times will we have to come in here before we actually start saying that the problem is not just whether or not the minister does or does not allow the importation of cooked chicken meat?

BREAK.PARA: The problem goes back further than that. The problem is in the way we negotiated the Uruguay Round of GATT, the naivety and the lack of proper debate within this chamber, the lack of proper debate that occurred within the community because the major economic rationalist push said, `This is going to be wonderful.' You have only to look at yesterday's balance of trade figures to see that even in dollar terms it was not.

So for our own interest, for our country's interest, we have to start being honest. We now have to go back to the point of honesty, look at what we signed, look again at our negotiating stance and start to try to fix things up in the next Uruguay Round of GATT and to fix things up in negotiations on all aspects of Australia's trade relations with other countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not respond to Senator Margetts's remarks. I know that she is fairly passionate about world trade, but I do want to address the report that Senator Crane, as chairman of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, has brought down. I have only had a very brief period to look at it, but I congratulate him and Senator McGauran for a report that I believe addresses the realities of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Although I have not sat on the committee, it seems to me that it will be some time, if the government accepts this report—and I sincerely hope it does—and this recommendation is picked up, before cooked chicken meat will come into Australia. The recommendation states:

The Committee recommends that AQIS commission tests of the thermal inactivation of Newcastle disease virus and infectious bursal disease virus in chicken meat products. This study should be conducted in conditions that are as close as possible to commercial processing conditions.
No doubt it will take some time to have those tests carried out.

I want to make some remarks about Senator Bob Collins's contribution. When speaking, Senator Collins puts on this indignation, this bluster, this bluff, that almost convinces you he knows what he is talking about. I must admit—and I must apologise to the Senate—that I have been sometimes bluffed into accepting what he has said as right, but what he said today is totally unacceptable.

He accused the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) of breaking a commitment. He then said that the minister for primary industries had made a hash of the cooked chicken meat importation. It is advisable to see what the minister did say. The minister said that no cooked chicken meat would come into Australia until the Nairn committee brought down its report. My colleague, Senator McGauran, said the Nairn committee report comes in today. I will defy anyone in this parliament to show me one piece of cooked chicken meat that has come into Australia before the Nairn committee report has come down.

So Senator Collins has gone down in the first round—a complete knockout. He said that the minister had misled the parliament and had left it in a hash. The minister's commitment was, `I will not make any final decisions to allow cooked chicken meat to come into Australia until the Nairn committee report has come down.' No decision has been made and no cooked chicken meat has been imported into Australia.

It is timely to go back and assess what the real situation was. When the government changed hands, there was a decision from AQIS that cooked chicken meat be allowed to be imported. Under the act, AQIS makes the decision. The minister was given a decision that had been made by AQIS under the act and he had to respond to that decision. Senator Collins said today he was going to try to get that changed. He said he had tried to get that changed. He was the minister for two years. While I agree that government should govern, government should make decisions, ministers represent governments and they should make decisions, that was not the case when this government took over and John Anderson became the minister for primary industries.

At that time, the act clearly said that AQIS makes the decision and the minister implements that decision. If the former minister, Senator Collins, wanted to change that, he had two years to do it. But, in effect, he sat on his hands and did nothing. When the baton was changed over he wanted John Anderson to break the law. That is what it amounts to. The law clearly stated that AQIS makes the decision. AQIS had made the decision, the baton changed over and now the former minister says, `You should've broken the law.' We are not in the business of breaking the law. We on this side are law-makers, not law‐breakers.

I, along with Senator Crane and a number of other people, went over to see John Anderson and said, `Let's hold this up until the Nairn committee report comes down,' and he agreed to do it. Let us not just listen to Senator Collins bluster and bluff because he has carried it on far too long and no-one believes him anymore. It is like the boy who cried wolf—you can get away with it only so many times.

Senator Collins, you have carried it out for the last time. If you wanted the law changed, you were the minister at the time, you had the responsibility to change the law, but you sat on your hands and did nothing. Then, when the baton changed over, you wanted John Anderson to break the law that you sat on for two years. That is the chicken meat saga, as it stands. John Anderson has no blame; he has honoured every commitment he made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the importation of cooked chicken meat. It is a unanimous report because the Democrats believe that, as far as it goes, it is a good report. It certainly is an advance on the situation we had some months ago where the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), having promised certain things to the chicken meat industry before the election then, whether or not deliberately, certainly did not deliver—and that is the problem with the promises that were made. It was not just about whether or not AQIS or the minister should make the decision; it was about whether or not an environmental impact study should be done—and certainly before the election he gave the industry a written undertaking to that effect but then, after the election, reneged on it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this committee recommends a way in which it can be fixed up—and that is important, I think, Senator Boswell. Perhaps I should remind Senator Boswell, Senator Collins and everyone else that if there is a gap or problem, then let us admit that the problem is there and fix it up. This is the recommendation made by the committee:
The Committee recommends that the government amend the Quarantine Act and place final responsibility for quarantine decisions in the hands of the Minister and/or Government.

We can spend all day here apportioning blame and trying to decide which minister should have done it. Let us hope that the government will pick up this recommendation and, in fact, amend the act. Quite clearly, it is too serious a matter simply to be left in the hands of departmental officials. It ought to be a decision of the minister and/or the government. They should take appropriate advice from their departmental heads. But in the end, the decision should be made by the minister. I support that recommendation strongly.

However, having said that this is a unanimous report and that the Democrats support all of the recommendations which have been made, let me go on to say that, nevertheless, the Democrats do believe that the report needs to say other things. I realise that the government and the opposition are plugged into and wedded to the World Trade Organisation legislation which was passed in this place some time ago. The Senate will remember that the Democrats raised serious problems with that legislation. We still have serious reservations about what the World Trade Organisation does to our industry.

Even this report, although making some very good recommendations, is still formulated within the framework of that World Trade Organisation legislation. The Democrats would say that even this report raises serious problems with that framework; that, in fact, this report quite clearly says that framework is becoming for Australian producers not a way of making free trade accessible but a prison within which many of our industries are languishing—and that is true of the chicken meat industry.

In the end this report says that there should be much more stringent application of environmental controls than there has been; that there are problems with the protocols which were formulated by AQIS; and that we can see a lot of problems in the future in terms of cooked chicken meat unless we do some very serious analysis of the procedures. But in the end the question really raised by this report is whether or not we ought to important chicken meat at all. The framework within which the report is operating is the assumption that in the end World Trade Organisation legislation will compel us to allow the importation of chicken meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the law.

—I know it is the law, Senator Crane, and I am saying that that law which this Senate passed has some very serious problems. It is only a short time since it was passed and already those problems are coming home to bite us. That is why the Democrats want to say very clearly that, although we have supported this report as far as it goes, we are aware that in the end, if we are forced through the World Trade Organisation legislation to import chicken meat into this country, that will have serious repercussions for our own industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats do not accept that there is a need for us to import chicken meat at all. We have a viable industry of our own. It is successful and it operates in a very good way. It is crazy to suggest that, because of some legislation that this parliament has passed, we have to sacrifice our chicken meat industry. The committee itself recommended that, if chicken meat is imported, we will need to put in place the imposition of a tariff or quota restriction to allow the industry to adjust. What that simply means is that our own industry would then have time to get out of the road so that imported chicken meat could come into this country. That is a crazy proposition. It is one that the Democrats cannot accept, even if we passed such legislation some time ago. The Democrats certainly voted against that legislation and, as time has gone by, the reservations we had at that time have simply been confirmed.

Let me commend the committee for the work it did. I attended most of the hearings but not all of them. They were very intense. There were considerable concerns raised by the Australian chicken meat industry. Those concerns, I think, remain. The Democrats cannot accept there being any need to import chicken meat into this country. At the same time we would commend the report to the Senate; in as far as it goes, it certainly is a very good report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments about the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. One of the things it drew to our attention—I, like Senator Woodley, did not attend all the hearings—was that there is no doubt that quarantine has been used as a non‐tariff barrier in lots of countries around the world. Australia has done a lot to be seen as one of the countries that does not use it. It is very important, as highlighted in the report, that we get the process right. Senator Bob Collins alluded to this by saying: whatever we do, it has to be based on science; it has to be defensible.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that has concerned me is the salmon industry in Tasmania. Senators would know that I have had more than a passing interest in it. Highlighted in the risk assessment by the previous government on the salmon industry was the lack of transparency of the process.

During the committee hearings we were told by the director of AQIS, Mr Hickey, and his adviser, Mr Gebbie, that the process has three stages. The first stage is a risk assessment by AQIS. The second stage is a technical assessment by ABARE and the involvement of an interdepartmental committee to look at the economic impact of any decisions that are made. The third stage is consultation with industry and reporting to government.

That is totally unsatisfactory, and I think that the chairman of the committee agrees with that. Whether it is chicken meat or salmon—whatever it is that has quarantine ramifications—it is the industry that is going to suffer. Industry needs to have confidence in the process and has to be consulted all the way through the process. This has not happened. It certainly did not happen in the salmon debate—they were adversely faced with a fait accompli. More knowledge by the industry of what the processes were and what the government of the day and the current government were doing certainly would have saved a hell of a lot of time and a lot of disquiet amongst the industry.

We make that point in our report. In fact, we recommend that the government provide the parliament and the committee with a clear explanation of the assessment process at the earliest possible time. That is one of the very positive recommendations that came out of this committee. Senator Woodley has already alluded to the fact that, if chicken meat is allowed in, there has to be a process to allow the growers some leeway to adjust.

One of the interesting things—most senators and lay people would not realise it—is that, as far as chicken meat is concerned, we are talking about chicken meat that would be hardly recognisable as chicken meat. It is not the drumsticks, the wings and the bits with bones in them—none of those will be imported in any shape or form—but the chicken waste that is used in chicken pies and fillings. From our observations, it is an unrecognisable gluey substance that does not even look like chicken meat. That is what we are talking about—not the nice cuts that we are used to having. But that is an aside.

The attack on the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) was quite unwarranted. I have been to public venues where he has stated publicly—as far as the salmon industry is concerned, anyway; I believe that he has done the same with the chicken meat industry—that the decision will be made by the minister and, also, it will be a cabinet decision. That is wise. That is exactly what we have recommended in this report, as the chairman has said.

I thought that the attack by Senator Margetts was a bit rich. You would almost think that she was defending the farmers and making a case for defending rural industries. Your track record on defending farmers and rural industries is pretty good, isn't it? You are opposed to the live sheep trade. You have done everything you can to upset private forestry. You are trying to stop pulp mills. What is your opinion on intensive animal husbandry?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You will address your remarks through the chair.

—The Greens have even tried to stop the use of phosphate based fertilisers in the sugar industry. To come out here this morning and try to make out that they are the friends of the farmers is a bit of a joke. I just hope that the bipartisan agreement that was reached in this committee continues because there is no doubt that there will be other inquiries into other quarantine matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, one of the things that disturbed me was that a lot of decisions that were made by AQIS—it was highlighted in the report at the finish; I will not mention the AQIS member's name—on this particular matter were based on the opinions of some of their officers. That is not good enough. If we are going to make decisions that affect people's wellbeing and their financial future, we need to base them on more than just the opinions of some of the officers in the quarantine service.

That is why I say that any decision made on this matter, or any other matter regarding the importation into this country of products that could destroy or help destroy our local industries, have to be based on science. The decisions will have to be very well founded before I ever have anything to do with them or even give support to any to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to speak today on this Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee report. It is a very important report. It is going to be one of the most significant reports that a Senate committee has handed down in some considerable time. It is important in the fact that it is a bipartisan report. It deals with a very significant issue for a sector of the rural community.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to join with the chair and place on record my thanks to those people who have been involved in this, particularly the committee secretariat. Also, I particularly thank the chicken meat producers and the chicken growers in this country. If it had not been for their hard lobbying and their hard work, a lot of this may never have occurred.

It is a significant report, because the thing that I get out of it after a quick read of some parts is the need for more research to be done. That is summed up very clearly in appendix 6, which was a letter to Mr Bob Baldwin, the member for Paterson, from Dr Alexander, the person upon whose research AQIS appears to have drawn a lot of its conclusions.

Dr Alexander expresses concern about some of the conclusions that are being drawn from his research—the transferring of that research from one disease to another: the transferring of an extrapolation of that research and results in relation to egg yolks across to how it will impact upon actual animals and diseases in the real world. So it is a report of major significance. As I say, further research is the key thing that keeps coming out.

The other thing that comes out in this report—and it came out in the evidence that we were given when we went to Maitland—was the work that has been done by the chicken industry itself. It is not just the producers and the chicken growers—those who feed the chickens and those who process the chickens—but the whole industry. They were there and put concerted and well‐documented scientific evidence before the committee.

They reminded us that newcastle disease could come into this country by birds flying here. We know that birds migrate to this country. They have been migrating to this country for tens of thousands of years and, to this stage, have never introduced one of the virulent strains of newcastle disease. So I think we can place a very small possibility on that being the source of contamination. The sources of contamination, if that disease gets into this country, are likely to be through the importation of some product that is contaminated already.

It is very well documented in the report that there are many types of newcastle disease and infectious bursal disease. They are not sure that they actually know the precise number. They are not sure they can tell you how severe a number of these disease are. There are, in fact, a number of very mild non-virulent forms of both diseases in this country that cause no mortality and morbidity and have no impact. It is the virulent forms of the diseases, which are endemic in Thailand and in the US, that we have concerns about. They would decimate our chicken industries. Not only that, newcastle disease, if it became loose in this country, would decimate our native bird populations as well, because all birds are affected by the disease, not just chickens.

The chicken industry is of vital importance to this country. In the Hunter region the chicken industry is the largest employer. It is a large employer of people living on the central coast of New South Wales, the Campbelltown area of southern Sydney and the Riverina. We cannot afford to put at risk these industries without there being some very serious scientific research done into what the likely impact of this importation of cooked chicken meat is.

I recommend this report to people. AQIS has said that heat control, thermal control, is the way to kill the disease. Yet there is evidence here that, for some strains of the diseases, it is not known what the impact of heat is upon the meat and the disease.

I want to refer to table 1, which is under chapter 3 of the report. It is a summary of the results of thermal inactivation studies in the newcastle disease virus. The variation is that some of the diseases were found to be inactivated at between 50 and 55 degrees centigrade for 30 minutes. Another researcher found that four strains require 70 degrees centigrade for 40 to 50 seconds. Another lot required 60 degrees centigrade for six to seven minutes and 55 degrees centigrade for 60 to 80 minutes. Another one found that there was a 99 per cent loss of infectivity at 43.3 degrees centigrade for 75 minutes.

The other point raised by the industry was the difficulties they had with packing the ovens to ensure that these temperatures could be reached with the whole load being cooked for the whole time. There were also variations in the results on thermal inactivation studies on infectious bursal disease. These are all issues that require a lot more research and a lot more work. There is also work that needs to be done on the prospect of post‐cooking contamination and the prospect of contamination of packaging. It would appear from the evidence we have received that, in fact, no work has been done by AQIS on this particular issue. I think these are all shortcomings in the recommendation being made to the minister by AQIS that we allow these particular products in.

An area that is of grave concern to me is the use of chemicals in overseas countries—which might happen—and they are chemicals that are not used in Australia. We have seen in recent times some concern about antibiotic resistant bacteria being able to cross species. We do not know what antibiotic use is made in other countries in the foodstuffs for chickens. So it is an issue that is of major concern.

I would recommend this report to everybody who has an interest in this issue. I would recommend this report to anybody who is interested in the salmon importation issue and fire blight, because those are the next two issues that I see being of major concern to industries in this country.

We have heard a lot today, and we have had attacks from both sides, but I was concerned to see the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, on the 7.30 Report last night. I gained a very distinct impression from that performance of the minister that he was quite satisfied with existing scientific evidence. I hope the minister is going to read this and digest this, because this documentation provides extremely valuable evidence that he should not be satisfied with the scientific evidence to date.

We had promises from the then opposition, prior to the election, that they were not going to allow this to happen, that there would be more research done. In fact, in a letter to some of the chicken producers themselves, the now minister said that a coalition government would suspend the approval of all proposed new import protocols, including one for salmonoid products, until such time as a scientific review has been completed and its recommendations acted on in full. Just after they came to power, he was saying that there would be a review of quarantine and nothing further would be allowed to be imported until that had been completed and its recommendations were in place. That was before the election.

In May, I asked the question in here of the minister's representative and was told the minister had given approval to go ahead with the importation of cooked chicken meat. This just indicates that they changed their minds so quickly it was not funny. They were prepared to leave that industry out to dry. I think the minister should be hanging his head in shame at that. He was quick to decry attempts to import grain when it would have affected his industry, but he is not quick to defend those industries that require further scientific research to be done on their products. The minister should be asked to take a very close look at this report and to act upon the findings of this and undertake a heck of a lot more research before anything further is done.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1996INCOME TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996INCOME TAX (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the bills and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1996
The Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 is the first instalment in a package of legislation which will replace Australia's main tax law, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The existing act has grown in haphazard fashion over the past 60 years. Layer upon layer of new provisions have been added with no serious attempt to ensure either that the act remains understandable, intelligible or internally consistent.

It has grown enormously in length and complexity. Over the last 13 years of the former Labor Government alone the size of the ITAA trebled from about 1100 pages to around 3300 pages. The cost of compliance with the act has grown commensurately.
Not even the most expert of tax practitioners can claim to fully understand all aspects of the act.

The complexity of the current act has been responsible for a significant erosion of certainty and of confidence in our taxation system, by the general taxpaying community, both individuals and companies. This is damaging to the system itself. It can also weaken the essential tax morality of otherwise honest, law abiding, responsible citizens.
The Government has as a high priority the objective to rewrite the tax laws to:
reduce their length
reduce their complexity
increase their certainty and consistency
reduce compliance costs
provide a better environment for business and individual taxpayers to meet their obligations
This priority is part of a wider commitment by the Government to attack unnecessary red tape, over regulation, complexity and uncertainly wherever it exists.
The Government is committed to reducing the cost of doing business, to increasing national productivity and competitiveness—to adopt world best practice wherever possible.
The package of bills I am introducing today—of which the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 is the centrepiece—is a major first step in the achievement of the Government's tax law objectives.
The bill is essentially the product of the Tax Law Improvement Project. In late 1993 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended that the income tax law be rewritten.
It recommended setting up a broadly based Task Force to undertake the task. As a result, the previous Government in 1994 established the Tax Law Improvement Project for this purpose.

The Tax Law Improvement Project has undertaken extensive public consultation in the preparation of the bills before the House, including the release of draft bills for public comment. The Project has also been advised by a consultative committee of experts in the field of taxation.

Work is well advanced in rewriting much of the remaining rules that affect how much income tax a person must pay. A discussion paper outlining a proposed structure for a rewrite of the capitals gains tax provisions has been released and an exposure draft rewrite of the capital gains tax provisions is imminent.

Future instalments of the new law will progressively build up the new Assessment Act. This package of bills makes a significant inroad into that work. The Government intends that this first instalment should apply from the 1997‐98 income year, subject to transitional arrangements for some measures. The practical rule changes made in it are overwhelmingly favourable to those it affects. Future rewritten instalments, essentially on an annual basis, can be expected to apply in similar fashion.

The Government recommended that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which has had a long standing interest in the tax law and has kept a watching brief over this project in particular, continue to have the opportunity to complete a review it undertook of an earlier version of this legislation. The Committee considered the bill and reported on it at the commencement of the Budget sittings in August. The bill has been amended to incorporate all the Committee's recommendations.
I now turn to outline some of the specific features of the bill.
At a broad level, a number of strategies have been adopted to make the law easier to understand and use.

The most important general provisions of the law, those dealing with how much tax a person must pay, have been redrafted in simpler and clearer terms and brought together at the start of the new law. These core provisions are essential to an understanding of the income tax system. They have been expressed clearly but with minimal change to the language of central income and deduction rules in order to retain the value of established judicial precedent.

Readers will be assisted by a more logical structure to the law. The new act will use a top down approach, starting with the core and moving on to general provisions which affect large numbers of people; then to more specialised provisions that apply to specific groups of taxpayers or to special types of tax. After that come provisions about collection and recovery of tax and then those about administrative matters.
The act will finally contain a dictionary where readers will have easy reference to the meanings of defined terms and concepts used throughout the legislation.

There will be a new section numbering system that is simple to understand and will better cope with the addition of new material in future. The existing system is cumbersome, confusing and disorienting to readers. It has been a source of derision.

The practice of addressing readers in the second person, which was introduced in the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Act 1995, has been continued for areas where the law affects individual taxpayers. This engages readers much more actively and promotes understanding. It is not used, however, in provisions that apply only to impersonal entities.

Important parts of the law begin with orientation material to help readers find their way to what they need to know about it. This material will have a strictly limited legal status in interpreting the new law. The text makes clear distinctions between these non‐operative guides and the operative rules.
The bill incorporates modern design techniques for clear and effective communication. It makes extensive use of:
examples and diagrams;
notes highlighting special features of the law; and
signposting to other parts of the law that the reader may need to go to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Specific areas of the law rewritten

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the core concepts, some other areas of the existing law have been rewritten and are included in the bill.

The provisions dealing with deductions for current and prior year losses and company group loss transfers have been rewritten. This has reduced the length of the existing provisions by more than half.

Unnecessarily complex and prescriptive rules have been simplified. Another feature is the bringing together of common themes such as the continuity of beneficial ownership and the same business tests of the losses provisions. Redundant provisions have been eliminated.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Tracing the ownership of listed public companies

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments will provide, in the rewritten losses provisions, streamlined rules for listed public companies to establish who owns their shares. The amendments were also announced by the Assistant Treasurer in his response to the Joint Committee's report.
The new rules are a major compliance cost breakthrough. They will provide more certainty and a far simpler method for establishing share ownership.

Companies need to maintain continuity of ownership to deduct tax losses. For listed public com panies, tracing through nominee companies and interposed entities to identify very large numbers of individual beneficial owners can impose a significant evidentiary burden.
There are 2 features to the new rules.
First, companies will now trace ownership periodically rather than on an ongoing basis.
Secondly, small shareholdings of less than 1 per cent that are not part of a large indirect holding will be aggregated and a notional shareholder will be taken to own that pool of shares.

Additionally, shares held by complying superannuation funds, mutual life companies; and other like entities will be taken to be the beneficial owner of those shares. This will relieve the obligation to trace beneficial ownership of these shares.
The new rules, announced by the Assistant Treasurer on 22 August 1996, will apply from the 1997‐98 income year.

Also rewritten are the capital expenditure write‐offs regimes for the petroleum mining, general mining and quarrying industries. This has helped reduce the size and complexity of the law and a substantial amount of duplication has been eliminated, reducing the length of the relevant provisions overall by some 70 per cent.
The capital expenditure write‐offs for buildings have been rewritten and, again using the various simplification techniques I have described, have allowed the length of these provisions to be halved.
The income tax rules for calculating car expenses and substantiating work expenses, which were rewritten and enacted last year, are also being transferred across to the new act by this bill.

The new law will operate prospectively and existing rulings and court based interpretation will not be affected where the new law re‐expresses the same ideas for clearer effect, which is mostly what the new law will do. Where a change in substance is being made to the existing law, those changes will only apply for the future. In these cases existing rulings and precedents will apply up to the time the new law begins.
The revenue impact of the new law will be mainly neutral. While most changes will have no direct impact on the revenue outcomes, some will result in minor but unquantifiable revenue costs.
There are two proposals that will have a measurable revenue impact.

A proposal to allow accelerated write‐off for mining expenditure incurred before July 1982 will initially be revenue positive, being $10 million and $5 million in the first two full years respectively, but will become revenue negative in later years.
A proposal to allow display homes to be written off under the special concessions for buildings will have an annual cost of $2 million.
I present the explanatory memorandum which includes a more detailed explanation of the new structure of the bill and of a number of relatively minor changes to the law itself.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996

The Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 I have just introduced provides the framework for the rewrite of the entire Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. That bill also contains the rewrite of a number of specific areas of that act including its core provisions.

This bill will amend other Commonwealth acts that contain references to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, to ensure they reflect the changes made by the bill just introduced. It also makes amendments to the 1936 act closing off the application of provisions that have been rewritten.
The explanatory memorandum that has been circulated provides details of the amended acts and, where necessary, any substantial changes.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996
This is the third and final bill of the package that forms the beginning of the rewrite in stages of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
This bill explains when and how the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 will commence to apply. As a general rule the rewritten law will first apply for the 1997‐98 income year.
Further details of the transitional arrangements are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carr) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
Madam President, this bill provides for a number of changes to the patient contribution Australians will pay for these medicines when accessing the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

The PBS has provided Australians with protection against the high cost of necessary pharmaceutical drugs for over forty years, and it is the government's intention that this Scheme will continue to provide that protection for all Australians. The PBS is without doubt a world leader in providing not only a most comprehensive range of necessary medication but also in providing these drugs at a reasonable cost to both the taxpayer and the patient. Regrettably, with the escalating costs of new medicines, it has now become necessary for the burden on the Australian taxpayer to be redistributed slightly and the user to be asked to contribute a little more towards the costs of their medication.

To this end the government has decided, reluctantly I might add, to raise the patient charges for all persons accessing the Scheme. Concessional users, the most frequent users of the Scheme, will be asked to pay an additional 50 cents per prescription, a rise of contribution from the present $2.70, while the general users will pay $20 towards their own medication, representing a rise of $2.60 per prescription.

It is important to note that the "safety net" arrangements under the PBS are not changing, thus maintaining the high level of protection afforded under this Scheme. The annual concessional limit to access the safety net will remain as 52 times the patient contribution at $166.40, and the general safety net limit is to remain at $600, with a normal CPI indexation being due on 1 January 1997. Members will note that many general users of the Scheme will now reach the safety net limit quicker, using fewer prescriptions. It is important to note, Madam President, that this program continues the government's policy of protecting families since the safety net also covers the patient's family. The Pharmaceutical Allowance for pensioners will remain at $140.40 per year and will continue to be indexed, which is sufficient to cover their copayments for 44 prescriptions. As the average user in this group has about 30 prescriptions per year the Allowance will continue to over‐compensate many pensioners. If a pensioner reaches the safety net the additional annual cost is $26. This is little more than the average price of one of the 52 prescriptions needed to reach the safety net.

It must be said that the government has maintained the very high level of protection afforded these persons by only increasing the patient contribution by 50 cents and maintaining the "safety net" protection. The rise to date in the concessional copayment represents an increase of only 1 per cent per annum while the cost of the PBS has risen by 16.5 per cent in 1995‐96 alone.

The opportunity has been taken to amend the indexation of these charges to bring all indexation under the Scheme to 1 January of each year commencing on 1 January 1998. Members will note that the increases in copayments in the bill are to take effect on 1 January 1997 and that the indexation of the patient charges will not take place until the next year.

The method of indexing of the general safety net threshold and all patient charges is to be amended to allow the calculated figures to be rounded to the nearest of ten cents, that is up or down, not just down as was the previous arrangement. It has been of concern for some time that the previous rounding process worked against the interests of the taxpayer and these changes are considered to be a fairer method of sharing the rises in charges driven by CPI increases.

Madam President, the final item in this bill concerns a matter of interest to all Australians for the government feels it is time to make it clear that this program is for Australian residents and not to be accessed by all who might be visiting our shores.

I hasten to add that visitors from countries with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement are to continue to receive the benefits as they are entitled to under those agreements. But it has been of concern for some time that persons visiting Australia have taken advantage of the PBS, and thus the Australian taxpayer, while here, and in some cases even after they have left our shores, to have their pharmaceutical needs subsidised by the Australian taxpayer.
It has not been uncommon to hear reports of drugs being found by Australia Post or the Customs Service in the process of being sent overseas to persons who clearly are not residents of Australia.

These amendments change the National Health Act 1953 so that the PBS may only be accessed by persons eligible for Medicare benefits. These are Australian residents, eligible overseas representatives and other persons treated under the Health Insurance Act 1973 as being eligible persons, including visitors from countries with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement. Before supplying a pharmaceutical benefit the pharmacist will need to be satisfied that the patient is eligible for Medicare benefits. To this end the pharmacist may request the patient to show their Medicare card or some other document which establishes their eligibility for Medicare benefits, for example, a passport issued by a country with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement.

The act continues to provide for refunds of excess moneys spent on pharmaceutical benefits where the patient is unable to satisfy the pharmacist that they are eligible but are later able to satisfy the Secretary to the Department as to their eligibility. The refunds by the government will be limited to the difference between what the patient should have paid and the Commonwealth dispensed price.
These changes are estimated to reduce outlays on the PBS by $74.2 million in 1996‐97 and by $534.5 million over the following 3 years.

Madam President, I wish to only take a moment longer but I believe it would be helpful if I also outline other budget changes to the PBS that, while they do not require a legislative amendment, are being introduced to make the PBS a more economically viable program.

I will be asking the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), the experts in these matters, to re‐assess significant drug groups listed prior to cost‐effectiveness criteria being applied to such listings, to ensure these medicines are providing value for money. Included in this group will be the calcium channel blockers and the Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitors used in the treatment of hypertension or high blood pressure.
The PBAC has also been asked to advise on the delisting of the topical antifungal medicines which are generally used to treat minor diseases and which can be obtained over the counter.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.
