DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: General Business and Consideration of Committee Reports and Government Responses

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That general business and consideration of committee reports and government responses not be proceeded with on 31 October 1996.

The intent of the motion is that the Senate would agree to a proposal to effectively not proceed with general business or the consideration of committee reports and government responses this afternoon and dedicate the time between 4.30 and 7.20 this afternoon to debating the committee stages of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill.

The coalition government has received general agreement from all parties. I do understand the Greens have had some reservations about the proposal. I did discuss them with Senator Brown briefly yesterday afternoon. He did raise some reservations at the whips meeting, I understand—even though they were not discussed with me. We are very keen to ensure that the workplace relations bill gets thorough consideration in the chamber. We know that many people, particularly Labor Party senators, have very strong views on this, as indeed do people on our side. We want to ensure the legislation has a proper debate in the chamber.

We thank the opposition and other parties who have indicated that they will support this motion. I would ask Senator Brown to think carefully about whether he would be able to support it as well, so we can have unanimity on this motion and so it is done by consensus and not forced by way of numbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters to be brought up here. The first is that the chamber will be aware that the Greens are not in favour of the rush to the committee stage in the voting on the industrial relations legislation, because we believe that the community should have at least a couple of weeks to digest what is an enormously important piece of legislation and to feed back, and for this Senate to then have a debate based on that feedback. Senator Margetts's proposal, that we hold off until 18 November so that the community can have input, was not accepted by the chamber a couple of days ago.

SPEECH.PARA: That aside, I just wanted to flag the business of this Thursday contribution to affairs of the Senate. There is an informal agreement which allows for the 2½ or three hours to be given across to the non‐government benches to discuss matters which are important to them. In the ordinary course of events, opposition, Labor Party, Democrat, Green and Independent matters are discussed in that time. I am concerned that here we have the opposition effectively giving the government that period of what I see as very important private members' time to discuss matters which I think are very important to us. If we give up that time to the government—which has control, essentially, over all the other hours of business in this chamber—we lose the ability to discuss matters which are important to us.

I have, for example, on the Notice Paper a bill to alter the Electoral Act which I think is very important. It is a Democrat innovation and I think we ought to be discussing it this year. Jointly with Senator Lees there is another bill on the Notice Paper for the phasing out of export woodchipping from our native forests. That is a highly contentious issue, but it is very important for many Australians. If the Greens simply accede to the process in hand, there is no hope of that bill being discussed this year and I would submit there is little hope of it being discussed next year. In the meantime, many of the forests that we are concerned about will have been chomped.

BREAK.PARA: So there is a certain urgency concerned with the legislation I have before the Senate, and it would be remiss of me not to promote the interests of that legislation being dealt with before Christmas. I do not believe that that legislation should be making way for an extra few hours debate on the industrial relations legislation which is being rushed through this place. I do not think that is good process. I do not agree with it, and I do not agree with the priorities. Having said that, I can inform the Senate that this morning I have had a word with the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner). I hope we have in hand a process for reviewing what happens with general business, with all components of the Senate being involved.

If we look at the 20 or so Thursdays which come up in a year and if we look at the make‐up of the non‐government benches, there ought to be two periods in the year which are allocated to the Greens and Independents. There will be some 14 periods given across to the Labor Party and 3½ of those periods will be given to the Democrats. Senator Margetts has informed me that the Greens had not had, before a week or two ago, a Thursday afternoon component for a long time. But we now have important legislation before the Senate and I would like to see those two bills that I have cited dealt with between now and Christmas. I recognise that we do not have the power to force the issue, and I do not want to delay debate. That is not in our interests, and it is not in the interests of the opposition or the government. But I do want to flag this matter because it is very important.

Pursuing a conclusion on legislation brought before the Senate by the non‐government parties is a critical component of the Senate's contribution to democratic discourse in this nation of ours. So it is not a light matter; it is a very important matter indeed. To simply give over that period to rushed government debate—and I think it is unseemly rushed government debate—on industrial relations is not a thing I would do lightly.

I do not want to take it any further, except to say I do not support this move. I think that period this afternoon should be given to the important matters that the opposition and people on the non‐government benches have. The government should, of course, be pursuing its industrial relations debate outside that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place on the record that the opposition is supporting this proposal—in fact, we initiated it. I say it directly and clearly: we initiated this proposal. It is an unusual set of circumstances when an opposition, this early in the parliamentary process of sitting times, chooses to go to the government and suggest that we undertake consideration of legislation in a period which is reserved for general business discussion. We did this in these circumstances because of the importance of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not uncommon for governments to come to oppositions and say, `Will you give up opposition business time, the general business times, to consider government legislation?' When in government, our manager at that time did this on a regular occasion to the then opposition. It is extremely unusual for oppositions to agree to such a request, particularly some six weeks before the end of a session. It is not unknown for oppositions to agree to such a request later in the sittings, usually much later in November and, of course, in June, towards the end of particular sitting periods.

I would assert that the Labor opposition's attitude in this matter is particularly generous. As the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) made very clear when this proposal was discussed, it is groundbreaking. He is a very modest man when it comes to describing the attributes, the particular generosities and the dedication of the opposition in the consideration of these extremely important legislative matters. We are committed to a proper and thorough examination of the legislative process and, of course, a consideration in a responsible manner of matters that are before the parliament. This is not necessarily because we want to see the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 passed. On the contrary, we see this bill as being obnoxious, insidious and fundamentally hostile to the interests of working people in this country. We see it as fundamentally opposed to the maintenance of living standards for working people in this country and as a device aimed at redistributing wealth and power towards people who are already extremely well positioned within our society.

The Greens senators have indicated their concern that there be greater community consultation. We acknowledge just how important community consultation is in this process. They suggest that we ought not be giving up time, but that we should discuss matters that are of particular importance to them. We acknowledge that there are a very great number of issues that ought be discussed in this parliament. However, we put the view that, for our constituency, particularly for working men and women in this country, there can be no more fundamental issue than their wages and conditions, no more fundamental issue for Australians than the protection of their living standards, particularly when they are under such threat by this bill.

There are many issues of concern to Australians which this parliament has to consider on a daily basis. But there could be no more fundamental issue for working people than the manner in which they are able to organise themselves, present their interests and, of course, defend themselves against attacks by employers and against the devices by which governments—such as the current government—are undertaking to reduce their wages and conditions and to reduce their positions of real bargaining power within the economy.

We will be taking very strenuous steps to ensure that there is full community consultation about these measures. In particular, we will be seeking to mobilise community opposition to and outrage against these measures which are aimed at reducing the power of workers and reducing the living standards and the wages and conditions of working people.

So it is not true to suggest that the Labor Party, in particular, would seek to avoid community consultation about these matters. But what we do insist upon is that there is detailed consideration of these matters and that the full implications of arrangements entered into between the Democrats and the government are fully understood, so that we can establish the priorities of political parties within this parliament and understand exactly what it is that the various interests in this parliament represent, and who it is that they are seeking to serve.

In that way, we want to see these measures discussed fully and understood and we want to see this bill defeated because it is quite clear that the workplace relations bill is an insidious bill which fundamentally breaches the rock‐solid guarantees that this government gave in the election campaign that no‐one would be worse off as a result of their industrial relations changes. We want to highlight the fact that this bill opens the door to the cutting of wages and conditions, particularly for young people. We want to highlight the fact that this bill fundamentally removes fairness which we argue has been entrenched in the industrial relations system. We want to highlight to the community how this bill proceeds fundamentally to work on the basis that working people are going to be disadvantaged.

We say there is a flawed assumption that underlies this bill in that it presumes that there is, somehow or other, equal bargaining power within the economy and, in terms of industrial relations; that somehow or other employers and workers should be on the same footing when they are clearly not on the same footing. The so‐called Australian workplace agreements are devices by which real power will be distributed to the employer. The so‐called `employer advocate'—which is what it is—will be used fundamentally to undermine working people's positions. We will be trying to explain to the community—community consultation is what it is all about as far as we see it—just how this bill does not recognise the legitimate and desirable rights of workers to be able to organise effectively on the job and the rights of their unions to bargain effectively on a collective basis for those workers.

We will be seeking to highlight that this bill greatly restricts the central role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, that the arrangements entered into between the Democrats and the government do not seriously challenge that fundamental proposition and that they reinforce the notion that workers should be isolated and removed from the protection of their unions by the undertaking of individual contracts.

This bill undermines the award system as a dynamic framework for the protection and the advancement of wages and conditions. It is in that context that we say there are a range of priorities that this parliament must always consider. However, choices have to be made and this is one choice that we make willingly, openly and directly, to protect and represent our constituency in this parliament and to highlight the inadequacies of the government in regard to this particular measure. With that mind we say yes, we are making a generous offer to the government, but it is not on the basis that we seek to rush this bill through; it is on the basis that we want to carefully consider its implications and to do all that is in our power to defeat this odious legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to go into the details of the industrial relations legislation; I am anxious for us to get into that shortly. I would like to point out very quickly that, as Senator Carr said, it is unusual for the opposition to be offering additional time to debate legislation, particularly at this time of year. But we do have to have regard to the government's program. In saying that, I am not suggesting that we are not going to take a great deal of issue with much of the government's program. The industrial relations legislation is an obvious example.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have budget legislation to complete before the end of this year. I assume that we have Telstra legislation, although I think there is a question mark over that with respect to the government now. We also probably have euthanasia legislation. I am not taking anything away from the priorities that Senator Brown identifies—he would know that I would not necessarily agree with him on some of those issues in terms of content—or that of the Greens or, indeed, of the Australian Democrats, but the fact remains that we have less than six weeks to deal with industrial relations, Telstra, euthanasia and the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —And budget-related bills.

—That is right, Senator Campbell. In the spirit of cooperation, at least to the extent of timing and dealing with a program that is before us, we are commencing appropriations at lunchtime today, so, again, we have agreed to that procedure. That is not necessarily unusual, but we do recognise the continuing pressure on time. Again, the Labor opposition has agreed to two additional sitting weeks. We will also be sitting on two additional Fridays in the next six weeks.

BREAK.PARA: I just wanted to highlight those areas of cooperation with the government in an attempt to debate the government's program. As I said earlier, I am not conceding that we are agreeing with the government's program; in fact, we have fundamental differences in a range of areas. But the government is entitled to have its program considered and debated in a reasonable time. We certainly do not want to go back to the years when—

TALK.START.PARA: —They were in opposition.

—To some extent, the difficulties we face with the budget and the time process have been brought on by the present government. We are operating under rules that they established and confines they established when they were in opposition, which they imposed on us. They imposed those rules on us, and we are operating within those rules.

BREAK.PARA: With respect to the budget, it is obviously not easy for the government when the former Assistant Treasurer and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer have recently had to resign. That has obviously put additional pressure on Senator Kemp, the new Assistant Treasurer. We have some sympathy and understanding for the new minister in those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly sympathy for the pressure he is under.

—I say this quite seriously. We recognise the impediment of these two resignations and the blow it has dealt to the government's program. It is not easy to operate under those circumstances for the range of reasons that Senator Carr and our leader, John Faulkner, has very magnanimously—forcefully, but magnanimously—outlined. I do have sympathy because I have sat where Senator Campbell is sitting as a parliamentary secretary, on occasions having to handle legislation at the last minute, and it is not easy. I place our support on the record for the proposition that Senator Campbell has advanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to make a couple of points, mostly in response to Senator Brown in relation to the amount of time that non-government business has actually been dealt with this year to date. The clerks have very kindly provided me with an analysis of that. It shows that 64 per cent of the Senate's time has been devoted to non-government business and government business has taken up 36 per cent of that time. The total amount of time devoted to government legislation is 26 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: To put those figures in some context for other honourable senators, the average amount of time in 1994 that non-government business was dealt with was down to around 58 per cent to 59 per cent and the amount of time spent on government business was up to around 42 per cent to 41 per cent. The differential has changed quite significantly. In terms of the actual hours devoted to debating government legislation, which is some measure of time, it is worth while putting these figures on the Hansard record. In 1984 the then government was achieving about 11 hours and 10 minutes per week. In 1995 it was about the same figure. In the 1996 year to date this government has been achieving about seven hours of government business a week. We have a problem there.

PARA.BREAK: We genuinely appreciate the attempts of the opposition and other senators to recognise that the government should have its program debated. The government also recognises that there will be a number of very contentious issues, and the workplace relations bill is one of them. It has obviously been a very contentious issue throughout the history of Austral ian federation. It was a contentious issue when the founding fathers debated the arbitration powers in the constitution, and it will continue to be. There are very genuine heart-felt disagreements over those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator Brown to say that this debate is being rushed also belies the fact that, to date, this chamber has spent 16 hours and 25 minutes debating the legislation. Four hours has been spent on the committee stage this week. If you do a rough calculation based on some of the previous strong, heartfelt debates in this chamber on things such as native title and the land fund, at the rate that we are progressing at the moment on the committee stage—I am not making this point to be churlish in any way—we will spend about 150 hours on the committee stage. I am not saying that that is the rate at which we will proceed. I think it is fair to say to honourable senators that the objects stage of the committee debate clearly gives senators a time to range far and wide over many issues. I did listen to the debate very carefully yesterday. It looks more like a repeat of a second reading debate. I respect the contributions that have been made.

To say, Senator Brown, that we are rushing that debate is far from the truth. The government obviously would not intend to spend this amount of time but, on the current rate of progress—and I hope other honourable senators do not intend that we spend this much time on it—we would spend 150 or 200 hours on the committee stage debate, based on previous experience with things like the Native Title Act, which is the best example you can base it on.

At that rate, we will actually spend 20 weeks debating the committee stage, so that is not a rush. We do want to ensure that all of the issues are canvassed. I am sure that anyone in Australia who has an interest in industrial relations will be tuning in to the parliamentary network and speaking to senators and lobbying them. Obviously, our friends in the gallery will focus on the content of the debate. It is a packed gallery today. It is good to see that AAP are still up there, and to see our friends in the public galleries. There will be a focus on it and the debate will allow that focus, Senator Brown.

I do hope that you will take this opportunity. The opposition and the government have both made it quite clear that private members business is, of course, an important part of the Senate chamber, and we respect that fact. I hope that those figures will reinforce the dilemma and the challenge that the government faces and we do genuinely appreciate the cooperation that senators on the crossbenches have shown from time to time. We would like more cooperation. We will try to keep communication lines open so that you know what we are seeking to do. We genuinely respect the rights that crossbenchers and private senators have in regard to these matters.
