DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the bill as a whole and government‐Democrat amendments Nos. 1 to 7 to schedule 1. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell has already alluded to the fact that the debate was wide ranging. It is appropriate on the objects clause of the bill to have a wide ranging philosophical debate because the objects, as has been mentioned previously, are critical to providing a signpost showing the direction and the underlying philosophy of the amendments that we are dealing with in respect of the bill before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I make any more comments, I would like to indicate that we have one further amendment to schedule 1. I will provide copies of this amendment to senators at this point and I will make a few comments about why we are moving this further amendment a little later. I will be doing it briefly.

BREAK.PARA: I do acknowledge Senator Campbell's concern about the rate of progress but I would point out that the rate of progress on this bill will vary according to the schedules. For example, in schedule 2, I would anticipate much more rapid progress. Schedule 1 is the underlying philosophy, which identifies the objectives of the bill, and it is an area where I think it was obvious that there was going to be some time spent.

Just to briefly make some comments about a number of the amendments that we have moved to schedule 1, in respect of the amendment to subclause (c), Senator Cook concluded on this area in his contribution yesterday afternoon. The Labor members who participated in this debate certainly reflected on that change very well yesterday. The same applies with respect to our amendment to subclause (d).

With respect to our amendment to subclause (f), where we state that the bill must provide a framework for fair and effective bargaining, not just agreement making, as is provided for in this bill, we highlighted, again through the contributions made by my colleagues yesterday, that the fairness provided in the bargaining process is very important. It is not just fairness in terms of the ultimate making of the agreement but fairness in that bargaining process. Again, Labor senators yesterday highlighted the inequity in bargaining power between an individual worker and an individual employer.

One aspect that I will touch on here is this issue of fairness as it relates to new employees. When an agreement has been reached and registered, where is the fairness for a new employee who starts work? The government would certainly argue that they have a choice of accepting the agreement that has been negotiated, but, in reality, how fair is it to a new employee in that situation? The agreement has been negotiated. They have had no input into it. We are critical of that process anyway. The new employee comes along. They inevitably have to accept the outcome of that bargaining process that has already occurred. We will make more comment about that later on in the specific provisions of the bill before us.

With respect to subclause (g), we accept that the act should ensure freedom of association, but we add that the act must nevertheless maintain the rights of employees to organise and bargain collectively. I think the words of the Democrat amendment are `and are able to operate effectively'. They are the new words that are proposed in the joint government‐Democrat deal document that we were provided with on Monday. Certainly the words `and are able to operate effectively' are added, but contrast this with the specific provisions in the bill—45D and E. Will employee organisations, unions, be able to operate effectively within the confines of the proposed changes to 45D and E? The Democrats' amendment really only goes some way to addressing our concerns in that area.

Freedom of association provisions should not be placing any obstacle on the right of employees—this is recognised in international law—to organise and bargain collectively. When we get into the provisions of the act in some detail, we will have some specific examples of that.

To subclause (h) we add a requirement for the act to encourage and facilitate the development and registration of organisations. This is very important, not just for trade unions but also for employer organisations. It is vital, if we are to maintain the cooperative spirit in our industrial relations system.

When we look at international systems, we see that cooperative spirit is very important. We are talking about cooperative spirit not just at the workplace level. As my colleagues have pointed out, unfortunately at times there is not a great deal of cooperation at any number of workplaces. Certainly that can be a minority of workplaces, but we have laws that operate where this cooperative working spirit does not exist.

I am sceptical about the degree to which Australian culture will change, particularly quickly, in terms of cooperative spirit. There is, no doubt, significant cooperative spirit at the moment, but I think the day when we are going to see this great outburst of back slapping and self-congratulation between employees and employers is a long way away.

Often the leadership of the employee organisations, contrary to the belief the government would enunciate, does have to provide some guidance to employees on particular issues. I can recall having to face up to a pretty hostile meeting of brewery workers to attempt to convince them that they should give away their `beeros', the free distribution of alcohol in breweries. I did not get a very pleasant reception when I was supporting that proposal from the employers. I had to point out the accident rate in the two breweries in Tasmania. There were quite horrific consequences from some people drinking alcohol before work, at morning tea, at lunchtime, at afternoon tea and after work. That was not a particularly popular position. I just raise that as an example of where employee organisations have to provide leadership and as an example of the importance of employee organisations in our industrial process.

I can say the same for employer organisations. Many is the occasion in my experience when, regrettably, irresponsible employers have breached agreements with respect to treatment of their employees. We have responsible employer organisations—various chambers of commerce. That is not on all occasions, I have to say. Often I disagree with them. But employer organisations would often have to counsel their constituent members about behaviour and treatment of employees. The continuance of the objective of ensuring and facilitating the development and registration of organisations is very important.

In respect of subclause (i), some comments were made by colleagues, as well as in respect of subclause (l) relating to ILO conventions and meeting international obligations. Again, those points were covered very well in the debate that occurred yesterday.

In concluding my remarks at this stage, I have a few brief comments about the amendment we have circulated this morning. The amendment to schedule 1, objectives, relates to item 1 on page 4. It is a new subclause (f)(a). It states:
"encouraging the right of employees to bargain collectively and"

We call this the Senator Murray amendment. We really would like him to consider this particular amendment because, in reflecting on the deal between the government and the Democrats, we were somewhat perturbed and concerned. Senator Murray did a great job at the Senate Economics References Committee, particularly as a new senator, in listening to submissions, along with his colleagues on that committee. Senator Murray did an excellent job in identifying the particular problems that employees face in bargaining collectively. The preamble to the recommendation of the Australian Democrats on page 330 states in part:
The Majority report highlights some of the most important omissions from the proposed objects of the Act.
Senator Murray was spot on on behalf of the Australian Democrats. It goes on:
The Democrats share the concern of the Majority report that the proposed objects give insufficient attention to the need to promote fairness in the labour market—
The recommendation from Senator Murray on behalf of the Australian Democrats reads:

It is recommended that the objects clause in the bill be broadly supported, but that it be further amended to take into account the concerns expressed in the majority report, to ensure that employees maintain the protection of an up to date award system and access to the independent umpire in the AIRC, that the bill encourages collective bargaining as a means of evening up the otherwise dominant bargaining position of employers, and that the processes and procedures of the AIRC be kept as user friendly, practical and non‐legalistic as possible.

I re‐emphasise the two critical lines: `that the bill encourages collective bargaining as a means of evening up the otherwise dominant bargaining position of employers'. We have reflected as a Labor opposition on this very important point that Senator Murray made. We have taken the words from Senator Murray in his report—an excellent comment, Senator Murray—and we have encapsulated it in the amendment that we have circulated this morning.

It is unfortunate that your comments on the right of employees to bargain collectively has not been taken up adequately in your deal with the government in this respect. We are calling on you to support the amendment that has been circulated this morning, along with our other amendments. We accept you are locked into a deal with the government in respect of other matters in this schedule.

It is an excellent amendment, Senator Murray. I would like to offer you a Labor‐Democrat deal at this stage on this particular provision. We were really inspired on reading the report on your approach to the rights of employees to bargain collectively. It should be in the objectives of the act in the words that you have outlined in this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, you are preying on my private sympathies publicly. I should remind you with respect to the remarks you made about beer that the Germans found a very good way to get around it. They disguised beer consumption during working hours as quality control. It is known in Germany as a Brauers Fruhstuck, which means a brewer's breakfast. After testing the beers early in the morning they then proceed to bratwurst and cheese. That is the way to get around that particular problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to reply to the wide ranging remarks which have been made so far in this debate. Some senators' remarks have been exceptionally good and some, as you would expect, have shown a lack of homework. Some think the workers' world is going to end with this bill; I do not.

I would like to return to the Democrat‐government amendments that are before you. Amendment No. 1 seeks to ensure that the first and primary objective of the act is not just a flexible labour market but one that is also fair. I believe—and I said so in my first speech—that fairness is a very important principle. I was disappointed to hear one senator use it in the same framework of reference as the H.R. Nicholls Society did; namely, referring to it as a weasel word. If you check your Hansard you will see that that was referred to. Fortunately, I discovered that Minister Reith is not a member of the H.R. Nicholls Society and has been happy to see this absolutely important principle included.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments Nos 2 and 3 are to ensure that the award safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions is maintained. That was a vital change. This is an important amendment in that it makes clear that it is not the object of the act that awards merely wither on the vine. Rather, they should be kept up to date and relevant to provide the minimum standards for enterprise agreements and to ensure that workers are protected. The clauses must also be enforceable. These provisions also mirror the objects of the awards part of the bill.

Amendment No. 4 was a very important amendment reflecting our strong belief that unions are an important and vital part in the industrial relations framework and should be allowed and entitled to operate effectively. This object makes it clear that it is a role for the AIRC and the Office of the Employment Advocate to ensure that unions are not just recognised but able to operate effectively. That means actively intervening to prevent attempts to de‐unionise workplaces, which we oppose, or to reduce the status of unions. This additional phrase is attached to an equally important object that unions should be representative of and accountable to their members, which we agree with and we believe is also equally important.

Amendments Nos 5 and 6 are important because they reflect the modified role that the Democrats wish to see implemented for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. As I have said before, I believe that this bill is an evolutionary bill providing a further level of reform of the labour market—the clear reform thrust that we are prepared to support. Within this evolving framework there is a continuing role for the AIRC. That role, I believe, is to protect the rights of workers and also employers in a weak bargaining position. As we move through the amendments it will become clear that this is a recurring theme of our amendments and the change of the object makes it clear that those arbitration powers of the commission should be exercised as is consistent with this evolving role.

Amendment No. 7—and I am sure Labor senators will concur—is easily the most important of the amendments to the objects clause being moved by the Democrats and the government. It requires the commission and the Employment Advocate in the Federal Court to have full regard for our international obligations in respect of labour standards. That is vitally important. If Australia is to hold its head high as a defender of human rights, it must ensure that it practises what it preaches. We and all others know that labour rights are human rights, that workers are a part of the human rights movement and that unions are groups of workers and are part of the human rights movement. The International Labour Organisation is a United Nations affiliated body.

Australia is signatory to a wide range of ILO conventions and United Nations covenants on labour standards. These as ratified treaties are part of our common law, but I believe it is vital that these are reflected in the industrial relations bill itself. It is also necessary from a legal point of view to have this recognition in place. As Gough Whitlam reminded us recently, the High Court, only last month in upholding the use of the external powers to underpin the AIRC's jurisdiction on equal remuneration for work of equal value, on work and family balance and unfair dismissals, referred to the particular importance of the object in the current bill referring to international obligations. I am pleased that the Democrats have been able to persuade the government to insert in this legislation an object referring to the importance of giving effect to our international obligations.

I want to turn to the ALP amendment which seeks to build on the proposed objects of the bill. We believe that the ALP amendment raised some important issues and we sought to pursue those issues in our discussions with the government. In particular, we supported the need for the bill to aim for a labour market which was both flexible and fair, the need for the award system to be maintained and up to date, the need for organisations of employees to be able to operate effectively and the need for the bill to assist in meeting our international obligations. All of these points dealt with in the Labor amendments are picked up in another form in our amendments. As such, the Democrats do not see the need for following the wording proposed by the ALP while having much sympathy with their aims.

I want to discuss briefly the ALP's proposed object (f), which they have adapted, in which they sought to add the words `while maintaining the rights of employers and employees to organise and bargain collectively'. The Democrats strongly support collective bargaining and we have sought in all our discussions with government to ensure that collective bargaining is primarily maintained and reinforced. As we go through this debate, the amendments we have sought to enhance the abilities of employees to bargain collectively will become apparent. But we have been persuaded that it is unnecessary to include it in an object. We already have the ability of employers and employees to choose the most appropriate form of agreement for their particular circumstances as an object. That appropriate form of agreement will obviously include collective.

We will have a new object for organisations to operate effectively. That refers to collective. We have object (e) providing a framework for fair and effective agreement making. Most importantly, we have a new object of assisting in meeting our international obligations—the important one of which, I will remind you, because you know it well, is the ILO convention on collective bargaining.

The primary means of collective bargaining is obviously certified agreements. The act makes it quite clear that certified agreements override Australian workplace agreements. This is an important restatement of collective over individual. The certified agreements stream is the pre‐eminent stream in this act.

This is an important restatement and, more importantly, the act will contain a positive duty on the AIRC to encourage the making of certified agreements. This is found in proposed section 170L, the object of part 6B and 170LA. This combined effect is that the commission is required to perform its functions in a way which facilitates the making and certifying of agreements. Thus, if a union has notified a bargaining period, the commission is required to try to bring that bargaining period to a successful conclusion through conciliation. There is no similar requirement to encourage the making of AWAs or individual agreements under the act. So, read as a whole, the Democrats believe that there is a considerable and strong emphasis on encouraging collective bargaining in the act.

I want to turn briefly to a few of the remarks made yesterday. I want to talk about the awards issue. The Prime Minister, John Howard, created a wonderful device for us—and what some have seen as a major rod for himself—in the lead‐up to the last election by giving rock solid guarantees that workers would not be disadvantaged by his IR policy. If we look upon that favourably, it was in fact a statement that he was not prepared to see the working conditions of Australians eroded. He told the freight conference in October last year, `No worker in Australia under the Howard industrial relations policy can have his or her award conditions taken away,' and that was referred to at length by a number of senators.

I used that quote in my supplementary report to the Senate inquiry report into this bill. I pointed out that the committee had received contradictory advice on whether section 89A, the allowable award matters, picked up all of the important award conditions or not. I also pointed out that there is a need to modernise and make the award system more user friendly and that Labor's section 15OA process simply was not working. I should make the point here, which I have made privately to members on both sides of the House without contradiction, that, in my opinion, in many respects, this bill is the son of Brereton and continues the work that Labor began. The modernisation and simplification process is one of those areas.

My recommendation was a simple one—that section 89A be amended to more accurately reflect the government's pre-election commitments, and it has been. Superannuation is in. Variation to hours notice periods and rest breaks are in. Skill based career paths are in. Outworkers are in. The provisions will be given a broader interpretation to include all matters incidental but necessary for the effective operation of an award.

The ACTU has asked us about accident make‐up leave. I have QC's advice that that is in as well. On top of that, if the matters are not in—and independent legal advice says that over 95 per cent of award matters, including all the entitlement clauses, are picked up—and the workers cannot reach agreement with the employers on the provisions, they can have the conditions maintained if the commission determines it would otherwise be harsh or unjust. That, fellow senators, is a massive concession that we have won from the government.

What this means is that unnecessary and cumbersome union weighted and union privileged clauses and awards inserted because of the dominant power of the union will still be modernised, simplified and reviewed or moved to agreements, but where the employees have little bargaining strength, or where the employer is in a bargaining position capable of imposing harsh or unjust outcomes on employees, the conditions will stay.

As I said earlier, this reflects the new evolving role of the commission not as the arbitrator between employer and union power but as the defender of workers in a weak bargaining position. That is what this bill is about. It is about not only moving employees and employers capable of enterprise bargaining into being able to make fair and productive bargains but also ensuring that employees with little bargaining strength—the bottom third, as Professor Ron McCallum describes them—are adequately protected.

This system, we believe, is rigorous enough to give the balance between the government's desire to encourage bargaining and the Democrats' desire to protect the vulnerable in the work force. We, the Democrats, are not here to protect union privileges or to defend 70‐page documents designed to tie employers up in unnecessary knots. We are here to provide fairness and balance and to assist employees and employers who need assistance. That is what we have done in the bill, in the award system, in the certified agreement stream, in the AWAs and in the union rights to representation. This approach will become clear as we debate the remainder of our amendments.

I have some final comments. There have been lots of remarks from the house, as we have expected, on secrecy and deals. I am of the opinion, as you heard me remark the other day, that those are generally political points. I refute that the deal is secret or, indeed, is worth elaborating on. If you truly believe that our agreement, now published openly and circulated to all senators, is a secret, it is the worst kept secret and the most open secret I have ever heard of.

There are many meetings in politics in which many people would like to be a fly on the wall. I would have loved to have been at Kirribilli, for example. I would have liked to have been underneath the Sydney Town Hall at New South Wales ALP meetings. I would love and would have loved to be in the cabinet rooms of both governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you would have liked to have been there.

—As you can see from my face, I have been in some rough places. For those who are using it as a catchcry and a political device, the rhetorical tricks, we should really concentrate on relevance and policy, and I concede that I have heard some very good remarks already.

BREAK.PARA: There is a legitimate place, as you know, for private negotiation within politics, whether it is the many hours that we and the Greens spent with the previous government on native title, whether it is the many hours that the Greens (WA) spent privately negotiating the land fund bills with the coalition when in opposition, or whether it is the many hours we will continue to spend with both sides of the house. That is the way it will be. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard a number of issues talked about today in relation to the Democrat‐government amendments to the principal object, but a number of the issues there tend to focus on the question of fairness. So it is probably reasonable to ask what definition is being used for `fair' because it may be considerably important.

BREAK.PARA: If the object of the bill does not, in our opinion, necessarily coincide with what the bill does, if at some stage people in the end rely on the object of the bill in some sort of legal battle for basic human rights in the workplace, it will be very important to know what the definition of `fair' is. Could the government enlighten us on what is meant by the word `fair' in these amendments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get a Macquarie Dictionary and quote to you in a minute the definition of `fair'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many dictionaries with many definitions. I am talking about what is often the case in bills with a legal definition. Perhaps in some prospective court cases in the future various people will bring in various dictionaries if the word `fairness' becomes all that is left between them and annihilation in relation to a contract in which they are hardly an equal partner. So it is not just a throwaway line.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to know what legal definition the government is using. If there is not a legal definition, it is a very important point that anybody will be able to bring in any dictionary definition and perhaps the person with the best dictionary definition, or who is able to argue on the best dictionary definition, will gain ground in any court interpretation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be frivolous here just to lighten things up. The first definition I saw of `fair' actually said `an amusement place to be amused' and `having merry‐go‐rounds', but that is not what you are looking for. The legal argument is that in fact there is no special meaning to this. It has its ordinary meaning, and that is the legal context of the object and the word `fair' in the objects.
—Which is?
—It is the ordinary meaning of it. If you want me to quote from the dictionary, I can tell you what the dictionary definition is. It is, indeed, an amusement show, but it is also:

SPEECH.PARA: free from bias, dishonesty, or injustice; . . . that is legitimately sought, pursued, done, given . . . proper under the rules; . . .
It refers to things like: fair game, moderately good, satisfactory, et cetera. The legal response to your question is that the word `fair' in the objects of the act has no special meaning.

TALK.START.PARA: —So we have the parliamentary secretary giving an admission that the word `fair' in this object, as has been amended, can mean anything from an amusement park to moderately good. That gives no protection whatsoever to workers in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The other point that should be made is the definition of `fair' in this bill is no different whatsoever from the meaning that is ascribed in the present act—that is, in the law of the land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It had not been my intention to delay the chamber, but I have heard a number of extremely vital and excellent contributions to the debate thus far, not least your own, Mr Chairman. Since the committee stage commenced, I have also heard a number of contributions. Senator Hogg referred to the question of employment and what ultimately might be the outcome of this particular piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask the Democrats and the government, in respect of the question of employment: what is the object of encouraging this pursuit of high employment? In regard to employment, and it is very interesting, I notice that very often that governments of both sides of politics—the previous government and this government—tend to boast when there is an increase in the number of employed; that is, an increase in the participation rate. Is that what this means? Are we saying here that we should be encouraging the pursuit of high employment; that is, an increase in the participation rate? Is that what we are saying?

If that is what we are saying, it is not what we used to say; it is not what the trade union movement used to say; and, as far as I know, it is not what the political parties used to say. I am very interested to know whether that is what it means—an increase in the participation rate. Is that supposed to be an objective? Will that reduce the level of unemployment? In fact, it will increase the level of unemployment. If that is your objective, then you had better have another look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to Senator Harradine. I will make two points. I was going to respond to some of the points that were made during the debate yesterday and, as you have said correctly, Senator Harradine, that was a point that Senator Hogg and a number of other senators have raised—and it is an important one.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the opposition in their own amendment No. 1—and I refer Senator Hogg to that—have used exactly the same words; that is, `encouraging the pursuit of high employment and improved living standards'. There is another debate over better pay which is also in the objects. I am sure that the opposition, when they drafted their own amendment and put in the words `high employment', would have had in their minds just what that meant. But in terms of the object of it, the pursuit of high employment means exactly what it says. You can seek to reinterpret it in terms of participation rates, and so forth. But my own definition of high employment would be that those who are seeking work are able to get it.

I think, Senator Hogg, you made a point yesterday in relation to casual work, part‐time work and so forth. There is nothing in the bill and that certainly is not the intention of the government; I cannot speak on behalf of the Democrats, but I am sure that it is their position. The government's intent is that people are able, and more able through this bill when it passes into law, to have a range of choices. There are many people in Australia clearly who at the moment do have part‐time work who would like full‐time work; there are many people who have casual work who would probably like to have permanent part‐time work; and there are probably many people who are working casually who would like to have well paid full‐time work.

I think the point Senator Harradine probably alludes to is that there are probably people who have full-time work or work of some kind who would rather not work at all and who may prefer to stay at home and look after their children. But, in relation to the matter of the definition in these objects of the words `high employment', we make no judgments or prescriptions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the parliamentary secretary. You point to the fact that the opposition's amendment includes similar words. It is precisely for that reason I asked you the question and not the opposition. As I read the bill, the bill will establish a regimen which ultimately will mean that workers will be worse off both in pay and conditions. If workers who have family responsibilities are worse off in pay and conditions—particularly in pay—it will mean that more people in that family will have to seek paid work in, say, the part‐time employment area just to make ends meet.

SPEECH.PARA: You talk about freedom of choice. That is not freedom of choice, I can tell you. And I can tell you another thing: go out there into the shops and workplaces into which I have gone and find out what is the major emotion in the hearts of employees when they consider this particular legislation. I will tell you what it is: it is fear—fear that they will lose their job; fear that they will have their pay reduced; fear that, if they do not lose their job, they will be going onto part‐time work. I tell the government that that is how workers feel at the present moment. That is the predominant feeling amongst workers at the moment, particularly those who are not unionised. I say to the Australian Democrats that they will need to think of that too when other questions come up in respect of the need to ensure that workers are properly represented.

I do not intend to pursue this greatly, but I do ask the government to take on board this very question on which I do not think we have focused enough up to this stage—and I am not speaking of in this debate, Parliamentary Secretary, but over the last few years. We just have not looked at the question of what unemployment is. We have said, `Oh, increase the jobs' and people have said, `Oh, yes, look at the increase in the number of people in jobs.' But there is not a corresponding reduction in the unemployment figures. Very often they both go up together. The reason for that is that there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available at the same time as new jobs are being slashed through increased automation and technical change. That has been the case now for perhaps five or 10 years, or more.

We really do have to face up to that, and I flag it very seriously here that we should be looking at it. We should be looking at those people who are in the paid work force who do not wish to be there but are required to be there because of their economic circumstances. It is not a matter of choice, in that case. There is the case that the parliamentary secretary mentioned, but there are other socially desirable alternatives, where income support is necessary in some way so that those persons can pursue these socially desirable alternatives as a matter of choice. I thought that I would raise that matter at this point, but obviously there will be other occasions on which we can canvass it and related matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Campbell's response to my question yesterday, it is very important that the government outline their intention for the term `high employment'. As I said yesterday, there is a real need for the courts, the law‐makers and the public at large to understand what is meant by `high employment'. Does it mean more people actually being employed but in part-time or casual employment? Does it mean that the government is heading down the path of trying to create more full-time employment? I ask this given that there is a growing trend for part-time and casual employment which does not satisfy the need of people to be able to sustain themselves. So the definition that the government gives to `high employment' is very important in assessing the rest of the context of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the discussion that we have just had on employment, it is perhaps an appropriate time to suggest that the government now respond not just to the employment issues but to the several issues that were raised yesterday, to the extent that the government is prepared do so at this stage. Otherwise, I can imagine that in this debate we will continue raising one issue after another issue and end up going around in circles.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to highlight two issues: one relates to the objects, which I focused on yesterday, and the other follows Senator Murray's comments relating to the provisions in the objects clause regarding awards. Senator Murray referred to the Australian Democrats' agreement with the government as maintaining the award system. I made the point yesterday that I do not think the objects as they stand maintain the award system—certainly as we know it. It is a system that we have worked with for near a century. The objects as they now stand simply refer to awards as a minimum safety net.

I would like to know how the government has convinced the Democrats that an award safety net is an award system. It certainly is not in keeping with the comments made by the Democrats in their report following our inquiry relating to the award system: it should be comprehensive and it should have broad arbitration powers.

The second point that I would like to concentrate on, following Senator Murray's comments, relates to the promotion of collective bargaining. I would like to know how the government also convinced the Democrats that the bill meets the issue of collective bargaining and that there is no need for an objective in the objects clause to specifically refer to it.

Senator Murray referred to the ILO and the reference to ILO conventions in the objects. We still have in the objects clause provisions with respect to discrimination, but there are ILO conventions relating to discrimination. So why has the government been able to convince the Democrats to specifically exclude what currently exists in the act with respect to the promotion of registered organisations? Why have they been able to convince the Democrats to move away from their position in their committee report that collective bargaining should be promoted?

The line put by Senator Murray that there are priorities for certified agreements means nothing. The priority in the bill for certified agreements exists only until they have expired. It will not affect the bargaining position of workers. It gives no priority to collective bargaining for workers. Once the nominal expiry date of a certified agreement is reached, once the negotiating period has expired—even if the certified agreement might still be continuing in form—there is no priority. There is no promotion of collective bargaining. There is nothing. So we then go back to the question: to what extent does this bill actually deal with our international obligations, because it does not promote collective bargaining in any form?

I raise this issue at this stage because it is now appropriate for the government to respond to the several issues that were raised. I have highlighted two issues, but there are several more. We could continue day after day asking questions on this until we actually hear something sensible from the government. The government has sat there saying, `This relates to native title,' and, `This compares to native title,' et cetera. I would like to make a comparison as to how we dealt with native title. Mr Gareth Evans, as a senator, dealt with the native title legislation. The relevant minister and the leader of the chamber actually dealt with the legislation.

What do we have here? What expertise do we have from the government in relation to this industrial relations legislation? I would suggest, Senator Campbell, that either you or someone representing the government start dealing with some of the comprehensive and, as you have already acknowledged, significant issues that have been raised so that we can now not string out dealing with this. That is what will happen unless the government starts responding to some of the legitimate concerns that have been raised not only today, not only yesterday but right through the whole passage of this legislation since it was first—I do not even know how to describe it—germinated, I suppose. I could think of many other words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jacinta Collins talks about the government's responses. I privately said to Senator Sherry just a few minutes ago, when I was finding out how he wanted to run this debate, that I was going to respond in detail to the contributions made yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Very few of the contributions made yesterday did deal with substantive policy issues on the points. There were some, and I have a list of them. I have listened very carefully to the debate and have responses. Senator Cooney, in particular, actually dealt with some issues that do require specific responses. He asked quite specific questions. I have already said to Senator Cooney that I will provide those. I will seek leave to incorporate a document to give him quite detailed answers to his detailed questions.

The majority of yesterday's debate was actually about political points. There is a fundamental philosophical difference between the two sides of the chamber. The opposition wants to retain an encouragement of and specific reference to collective bargaining and seek for there to be a substantive legislative encouragement in one form or another of coming to a workplace bargain arrangement. The coalition's position—and the Democrats have in many respects agreed with this—is that we do not in this legislation seek to favour one form of bargaining over another. Much of the comment yesterday was based on that.

It does not matter how many times you ask me why we do not put specific legislative provisions into place to encourage collective bargaining, I will keep giving you the same answer. That debate has pretty much been thoroughly canvassed in second readings, because it is a significant philosophical difference between your approach and the approach the government is taking.

Senator Collins, I did say to Senator Sherry earlier that I was prepared, once everyone from your side had spoken during the committee stage, to try to respond to those points that I thought required a significant response. Then, wherever it is required, I will seek leave to incorporate documents and so forth once you have all put your positions on the record. I did not interrupt you yesterday or today. I thought that was a sensible way to progress, and I thought that was the way we were going to progress. Senator Sherry recently informed me that you now have a series of specific questions that you want to put to the government, which I am very happy to answer to the best of my ability.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your role.

—It is my role, and that is what I will do. I said to Senator Sherry that, if that is the approach you want to take, I will do that. Therefore, I thought it unnecessary to sum up all of the matters yesterday. I will do that in the course of responding to specific questions as you raise them. Otherwise, I would imagine we would go over the ground twice instead of once. So I recommend that that is the right way to do it, and we will do that.
—I would like to direct a question to Senator Campbell. In respect of the question I asked before, is it your intention that that should be covered in your broad answers at the end of the section?
—In relation to higher employment?
—Yes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am happy to deal with that now. In relation to higher employment, I reiterate that in your own amendment you have higher employment as one of the objects that you wish—
—Because we support it.

—We have something in common, Senator Childs. I think we both support the concept of high employment. We do not, however, seek to define that. There is nothing in the bill that says we are trying to move towards part time and casualisation. There was—you are right, Senator Hogg—a significant move towards that form of work over the past 13 years or so. That occurred under Mr Keating. I am not seeking to make a political point here. It was a massive change. You would have known because of your own experiences in the labour movement that that has occurred.

BREAK.PARA: That suits some people and does not suit others. There are many people who work casual and part time who would like to have full-time employment. I think it was back in 1993 that there were about a million people unemployed—that is the raw number. I think a number of reports said that there were at least another million who had casual or part-time work or only worked a couple of hours a week who would have loved full-time jobs. So hidden unemployment was nearly twice that again.

So your point is taken. We are not seeking to make a judgment about that in this bill. Our bill seeks to encourage higher employment. For many people that means full-time employment; for others it might mean casual or part-time employment. This bill does not seek to make a judgment or encourage people one way or the other.

PARA.BREAK: The object of the act reflects the intention that the flexibilities and choices provided by this bill will have a positive effect on the economy which, in turn, will lead to higher employment. The form that that employment will take is the form of employment that is appropriate to particular employee needs. We hope that there will be a lot more choice. There is not a lot of choice out there at the moment. There are, as I said, a lot of people who do not work part time by choice. They work part time because that is all they can get. There are a lot of people out there who are in that situation. I have friends and family who are in that situation. They work casually at the moment but would love to have perma nent work. We would hope that all of those people have more realistic choices, partly because of the outcomes of introducing this new legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to ask Senator Campbell directly: do you believe the objective of the pursuit of high employment in respect of this act will increase employment in Australia? Yes or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe in a number of regards this act coming into law will have the effect of increasing employment, increasing choices and increasing employment opportunities for many people. I do not say that just off the top of my head. There are a number of people, such as the Retail Council of Australia, who estimate that something like 200,000 jobs for juniors would be at risk in their industry if junior wage rates, for example, were replaced. There are a number of reports, including the Yellow Pages surveys and various other surveys by ACCI, in relation to the impact of the unfair dismissal laws if they are not changed. That is a part of this act.

SPEECH.PARA: So there are a number of people out there who think that employment will improve as a result of this act. There are others who are more sceptical about it, such as the Governor of the Reserve Bank, who believes that it will be good for the economy. It will ensure that productivity in Australia is able to improve so that the economy can grow faster without risking other speed limits in the economic area.

But, of course, Mr Macfarlane, by way of example, said that he was unsure of the short‐ to medium‐term impacts on employment. It is an object of this bill. We are not in here for 25 hours debating this bill because it amuses us. We think this will make a contribution to improving people's opportunities to gain access to the sort of employment they want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question of Senator Campbell arising out of the use of the adjective, `high', in relation to `high employment' in paragraph (a). That, of course, as we all understand, is a quite critical change from the past when references were often to full employment deriving from post‐war settlements, principally in Europe and the United States, which flowed through to this country and the public policy mechanisms that were created to give effect to that full employment. The common understanding of full employment was, indeed, employment where everyone who sought it was able to achieve it and a range of institutions were created to give effect to that. That critical change in the amendment proposed by the government and the Democrats to high employment seems to me—
—And the opposition.
—Yes, I understand that, but I am asking you. You are the government and you apparently have the numbers so it is appropriate for you to respond.

SPEECH.PARA: The corollary of that change is that it suggests to me that a level of unemployment is to be—if not encouraged, at worst—tolerated because when we had full employment as an objective, it meant, certainly by express implication, that nothing else was acceptable. When we have high employment, it leaves some out. So I ask the parliamentary secretary what level of unemployment does the government anticipate as a consequence of this bill. Is it 10 per cent or 12 per cent? Or do you anticipate the level of unemployment to descend to US levels of four or five or six per cent? It seems to me that issue is a necessary consequence of the declining levels of investment and seems to be, if not encouraged, a necessary consequence of this objective. So I ask the parliamentary secretary to take that question on notice and either respond now or later; or respond now as to what levels of unemployment are considered acceptable by this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that Senator Campbell has not responded at this stage. I am expressing my disappointment that you have not done it, Senator Campbell—please allow me that privilege.

BREAK.PARA: In the brief answer that he did give on this issue, he referred to the retailers council's views about youth wages as one scarce example of how the provisions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, are you seeking to take a point of order?

—I am, sir. I am sorry if I misled the parliamentary secretary. I did say `on notice or now' but I changed my position shortly afterwards. I thought you understood that, Senator Campbell, because you nodded as I said it. I was requesting an answer to the question now, not later. I thought you understood that because you seemed to nod.
—That is not quite a point of order—
—No, but there seemed to be a misunderstanding on the part of everyone, sir.
—I am saying that is not quite a point of order but you got your point across.
—Yes.
—Point taken.
—I think we should first hear the contribution of Senator Collins.

—I am happy to finish my remarks very quickly in the hope that Senator Campbell will be encouraged to respond to both the point that Senator Bishop has raised and the additional point that I will make. In the scant examples that he gave of how provisions in this bill will supposedly deal with employment, he referred to the retailers council's views about how the youth wage provisions will cause a further increase in unemployment.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to refer the minister to this. So perhaps he can take this on notice or respond now but I will give him the opportunity to take it on notice because I am referring him to the report from the inquiry. At page 145, it talks about the Australian Retailers Association's submission with respect to youth wages but also makes the point that, in its oral evidence to the committee, the association accepted that the industry had agreed to a different wages system which did not offend the prohibition on discrimination required by the legislation.

As a consequence of that, there would not be huge levels of unemployment associated with a reduction in youth employment in the retail industry. So I ask again—this has already been asked of Senator Campbell: will the government please provide us with some detail as to how the provisions of this bill are meant to meet the purported object of high employment. This is one scant example; I cannot recall the other precise example but I also agree with Senator Bishop that you should indicate what you mean by `high employment' as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that I have actually adequately answered those questions about `high employment'. I have defined what it means to the government. We believe the bill will create better opportunities. We believe Australia needs to change the system it has at the moment that has created a situation where literally over a million people do not have the opportunities they want. The government believes we are right about this. The opposition believes we are wrong. We hope the legislation will be passed and obviously this debate will continue for many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue the line of questioning that other senators from this side have pursued recently in relation to the issue of higher employment levels. I really do not think that the points raised by Senator Hogg, Senator Bishop and Senator Jacinta Collins have been adequately answered by the parliamentary secretary. In order to focus Senator Campbell's mind at bit in relation to this policy matter on the issue of employment, which is the most fundamental issue facing Australia today, I would like to restate Senator Bishop's question, which is: what does the government regard as an acceptable level of unemployment? That is the first thing. Senator Campbell really ought to be able to answer that question, given the statements made by the government recently in relation to employment growth and the fact that the government's better pay for better work promise clearly stated its policy of high productivity and high wages.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it would focus Senator Campbell's mind if I draw his attention to the Business Review Weekly report on the Dun and Bradstreet survey of small business in which small business was asked if the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 would lead to greater productivity. Eighteen per cent of those surveyed said yes, and 82 per cent of those surveyed said no. This is a survey of small business, so I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary precisely where this employment growth is going to come from, given that the government has stated small business would be one of the critical generators.

So I have two questions. The first one restates Senator Bishop's question: what is an acceptable level of employment? The second one is that I would like him to respond to the empirical data I have just given in relation to job creation in the small business sector. I would like a response, through you, Mr Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mackay, you shall have one; you deserve one. As Senator Sherry said earlier today in relation to polls that are appearing in the papers lately about the relative popularity of our two parties, he does not like the comment on the polls. He does not take them too seriously.
—Good or bad.
—That is right. When you are right up, you have only got one way to go, and when you are right down you have only got another way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: To be serious about it, Senator Mackay, I have answered the questions in relation to seeking high employment. I do suggest to the Labor Party if they have such a concern about having high employment as an object of an act of law that seeks to change workplace relations that they do not proceed with their own amendment that puts the same words in there. Seriously, it is obviously a point that the Labor Party is concerned about. You obviously have concerns about wanting to encourage high employment. Your record in government was that you achieved the highest rates of unemployment since the Great Depression, so maybe it was a matter of policy for you that you did not want to seek high employment.

This government does want people to have greater opportunities. We want people who cannot get a job to have a job. We want people who are in part‐time work and who want full‐time work to have that opportunity. We want people who are in casual work and who want permanent work to have that opportunity. Maybe you do not. Maybe that is why you are so concerned about having high employment as an object of an industrial relations act. If you have that concern, remove your own amendment. I will give you leave to remove the words from your own amendment, which is amendment No.(1). I think we are actually debating it at the moment cognately. Your own amendment—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating government amendments.
—We are debating government amendments? Have you moved your amendments yet?
—We have not moved them yet; you are wrong.

—Before you even move it, you have a great opportunity, Senator Mackay. You can go and see Senator Sherry at lunchtime. You can get your crayon and take out `encouraging the pursuit of high employment'—the first six words of amendment No.(1) 3(a). Take your crayon around to Senator Sherry's office at lunchtime and, while you are having a sandwich with him, cross those words out. If you have got serious concerns about having the words `high employment' in there, take them out of your own amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, Mr Chairman, we could do without the rhetoric in relation to this issue about crayons and amendments. The reality is that the objects of this bill determine the parameters of the entire bill. You cannot take the objects in isolation of the thrust of this bill. If the government intends to do that, then all the objects are a complete nonsense and the government amendment ought to be to withdraw all the objects of the bill.
—We have heard submissions on that.

—And we have in fact heard submissions on that. I would like a serious answer to the questions put by Senator Bishop. If this government does not have a policy in relation to what an acceptable employment level is, then this is a ridiculous exercise. If you cannot answer this question, it is just absurd having this bill here.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is supposed to be the cornerstone of the government's economic plan. Firstly, what is an acceptable level of employment as far as the government is concerned? Secondly, where will job creation come from in relation to this bill, given the survey of small business that I alluded to before? Where is the job creation going to come from? Through you, Mr Chairman, I ask Senator Campbell to please dispense with the rhetoric.

Senator Campbell talks about Senator Sherry and I having a sandwich and crossing out words with a crayon. This is an extremely serious subject. Can I please just have an answer. Senator Jacinta Collins, Senator Childs, I and others spent weeks on this during the hearings on this bill, and this is one of the critical issues that was raised. So I restate: Senator Campbell, please do not try to tell me about the Labor Party's object situation. The objects determine the parameters of this bill. What are the goals and thrusts of this bill in relation to employment growth? Where is the employment growth going to come from?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue the point again, Senator Campbell. The words `full employment', of course, come from the charter of the Reserve Bank and a whole range of mechanisms have been created over the last 40 to 50 years to give effect to that objective. Indeed, in the last two or three weeks your own government has recognised the priority of employment, jobs and job creation and presumably either full or high employment, because it has created a jobs committee comprising a range of senior ministers. I believe Senator Newman is a member of that particular committee. Obviously, it has been created for a purpose and it has particular tasks it wishes to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: My question is simply that as we seem to be shifting from full employment to a range of public policy institutions and other acts of parliament, is that going to continue into amendments to the Reserve Bank Act? How will it impact upon the decisions of the cabinet jobs committee? What are the levels of underemployment or unemployment that the current government regards as acceptable in this society?

It is simply not good enough to ignore the question, to give some minor level abuse. There is a critical change here. A key institution is going to have a different focus, a conflicting focus, with that of the charter of the Reserve Bank. The Reserve Bank is going to carry out a range of measures designed to achieve full employment. This particular institution is to be amended to achieve a different purpose and one queries how the two are going to achieve a common end. So I ask the parliamentary secretary again: what levels of unemployment or underemployment will be achieved and what is acceptable to this government in the foreseeable future?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse what has been said and reiterate the question to Senator Campbell. Senator Campbell, if you cannot answer it, get someone down here who can. When you were in opposition—and since then—your government said that this is one of the two fundamental pieces of legislation that you will bring before this parliament. I take you back to your policy, Better pay for better work. That policy says in the introduction:

SPEECH.PARA: A more flexible industrial relations system will increase productivity, achieve faster real growth in wages and profits and, most importantly, create more real jobs.

They are the precise words from your policy. Tell us how this bill will, most importantly, create more real jobs which, of course, we all agree is a noble objective. Tell us how you are going to achieve it. Tell us what is your definition of high employment.

You put that policy to the people. You claim it has been overwhelmingly endorsed, but so far you cannot tell us what it means and what the words in this bill mean in real terms for the people out there who want to know. So please, answer the question, or, as I said, get a minister down here who can answer the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that I raised this in the first instance is that this is an issue that is fundamental to the Australian people and to their lifestyle. As was just said by Senator Forshaw, the manifesto of the government, when they were in opposition, was `more real jobs'. What I am trying to flesh out—it is not a trick question—is: what are the sorts of jobs that the government aims to have created by this legislation? If it is simply a matter of having everyone in a job with no‐one being employed full time, then I think the object of this legislation fails hopelessly.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard it said by the parliamentary secretary that for people who are part time they hope to create full‐time work and for casuals more hours by way of full‐time work, but I am interested in how this is going to happen under this legislation. Is it a matter of just more people being employed for fewer hours, or actual numbers of people being employed in more meaningful jobs? What are those jobs going to look like? That goes to the very heart of what this legislation is about. If it does not do that, then the legislation fails.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay this unnecessarily. I just want to clearly state that the Greens (WA) position is to support the amendments because they are an improvement on a bad object in the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. That should not be read in any way as an endorsement of the object. Of course, we intend to move amendments later on where we would be seeking to change the entire object but, as a practical measure, we will be supporting the amendments. That should not be read, in any way, as an endorsement of the government's object.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary, has the new government initiated any studies research through the Department of Industrial Relations or through the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in respect of the relationship between industrial relations and employment or unemployment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get a response for you on that, Senator Sherry. I don't think you need that response immediately, do you?
—Yes, we would.
—I will get a response for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the parliamentary secretary to refer to the second and third lines of paragraph (a) and the reference to international competitiveness:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) encouraging . . . international competitiveness through higher productivity and a flexible and fair labour market.
Could you tell me, Senator Campbell, why it is that international competitiveness is such a critical aspect of this objective?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —We tend to agree with the gentleman who said in 1993 that only increased productivity can sustain real wage increases and lasting improvements in our living standards. That was P.J. Keating in a speech to the Institute of Company Directors just after the 1993 election. We agree with that. We agree that increases in productivity and increases in international competitiveness will improve our trading position. It will improve the export income to this nation and it will create greater opportunities and greater employment opportunities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quarrel with the fact that higher productivity is an absolute objective, but higher productive and international competitiveness are not similes; they are completely different things. In fact, they are quite contradictory. Higher productivity is just the relationship between inputs and outputs of an economic entity. International competitiveness, in the context of the Australian economy, is an absolute irrelevancy.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an economy of something in the order of $400 billion. Our exports are something in the order of $40 billion to $50 billion per year. The overall bulk of those exports are commodities, low value adding and lesser ETMs. The percentage of our GDP allocated to exports is less than eight per cent. Hence, increasing international competitiveness of low value commodities and the like has a negligible impact on the domestic economy and the growth of GDP. It certainly has an impact on productivity, but little on the domestic economy. That is why I asked the question.

If competitiveness and productivity are different things, not similes, why is international competitiveness important to domestic production, which is the overwhelming bulk of production in this country? Goods that are produced internally for internal consumption, not for trading and not for export orientation, account for 90 per cent of the production in this economy. It is irrelevant what is done in the United States, China or Malaysia. I ask: if our exports are such a small percentage of overall GDP—perhaps they should be higher; that is a different issue—why does this bill focus on international competitiveness to such a critical extent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise another matter. As I am about to go into the chair, I thought I might get in before the parliamentary secretary speaks. The opposition amendment adds the words `better pay'. When the parliamentary secretary is replying on the objects, I want him to say why that cannot be accepted by the government. `Better pay for better work' was the slogan that the government deceived the Australian people on as it went to the last election. There is nothing in this legislation that I can see that will deliver better pay to workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last 14 years the coalition has supported just two wage increases before the Industrial Relations Commission. The time was never right for the Liberal and National parties when there was a question of granting or supporting increases before the Industrial Relations Commission. I ask the parliamentary secretary to answer that question.

I ask the Democrats, in turn, to support that object too, because it is clear that the issue of better pay is critical. If you cannot accept that principle of better pay when you are looking at the objects of industrial legislation, you are admitting that the whole point of the objects, as composed by this government in their deal with the Democrats, is to prevent wage increases. All the tactics of suppression that are contained in the detail of the legislation are being used to oppose better pay.

Not to accept the expression `better pay' here gives the game away. This government really is trying, in its classic sneaky style, to first of all not accept better pay as a principle that everybody can see. It has moved away from its election promises. By not allowing the words `better pay' to be inserted in the objects of the bill, the apple that was held out to people will be a rotten core.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop raised a very interesting point, trying to say that productivity and international competitiveness are different. Yes, they are, but productivity would increase our international competitiveness. I think you would agree. I think we agreed with Paul Keating about that. I think all of us would also agree that you would have to do a whole range of things if you wanted to increase our exports and increase our living standards.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Childs, through you, Mr Chairman: you may have tried very hard with Laurie Brereton when you were putting his legisla tion through your caucus three or so years ago to get `better pay' into the objects of the existing law. Over the last two or three days I have looked very hard to find `better pay' in the Brereton legislation. `Better pay' begs the question `better than what?' The coalition has committed higher living standards as an object of this act.

TALK.START.PARA: —How? How will this bill do that?
—Senator Childs, I presume that if you are supporting the opposition amendments, you support that object as well. But that is the answer to better pay.

SPEECH.PARA: As to how, Senator Collins, there will be an ongoing debate as to whether this legislation will achieve our objects or not. There was a long debate about whether Mr Brereton's bill achieved its objects. We do know what it achieved in relation to unfair dismissals and a few other matters. We have evidence of that now. That is why most people in Australia support many of the provisions of this bill in relation to that particular aspect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will publicly provide the quotes from Mr Howard to the parliamentary secretary. We will be pursuing this matter later in respect of better pay for better work and a number of other matters, including rock‐solid guarantees. I will give him a copy before lunch so he can verify the quotes that we will provide to him.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Herron:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senators for their support in moving the package of this legislation through the Senate. I also appreciate the cooperation shown by the various parties in the Senate in facilitating the passage of the amendment to the Imported Food Control Act. I foreshadow the moving of that amendment in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to this bill. For the information of honourable senators, this memorandum was circulated in the chamber earlier this morning. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 6, page 13, lines 1 to 9, omit the Schedule, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 6—Amendment of the Imported Food Control Act 1992

SPEECH.PARA: 1 Subsection 3(1) (definition of authorised officer )

PARA.TAB: Repeal the definition, substitute:

TAB.TAB: authorised officer means:
(a) the Secretary; or
(b) an officer of AQIS appointed by the Secretary under subsection 40(1); or
(c) when used in a provision of this Act other than section 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30 or 32—a person appointed by the Secretary under subsection 40(2).

PARA.TAB: Repeal the section, substitute:
(1) The Secretary may, by signed instrument, appoint an officer of AQIS to be an authorised officer for the purposes of this Act.
(2) The Secretary may, by signed instrument, appoint a person to be an authorised officer for the purposes of all the provisions of this Act other than sections 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30 and 32.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just so that I can be clear, can the parliamentary secretary give me a brief explanation of what the amendment is?

—The purpose of the amendment is to allow persons other than officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to be appointed as authorised officers under the Imported Food Control Act of 1992 with all the powers of an authorised officer other than the specified enforcement powers. It is sought by the government as a result of concerns raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills regarding the unlimited nature of the enforcement powers which would flow to persons authorised under the Imported Food Control Act 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the amendment, AQIS anticipates a more effective, more efficient service to industry as it not only minimises the duplication of inspection activities but also provides a more flexible approach to inspection service delivery and locations where an AQIS officer is not readily available. That point has been brought up numerous times. The importing industry has been consulted at length and strongly supports the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to check, has the minister's office talked to Senator Brown's office in any way in relation to this amendment?
—As I understand it, all officers in the Senate were consulted. All participants in this debate were consulted and I am quite sure he would have been consulted, like Senator Harradine and others.
—I was not trying to be difficult; I was just trying to make sure that, in the non‐controversial debate time, we were dealing with issues that really had been properly canvassed. Thank you.
—Thank you, Senator Margetts, for bringing that up; that is why all those persons were consulted.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 and particularly welcomes the initiatives to assist defence force personnel. Importantly, the bill provides for a reduction in eligibility for loans from six years to five years and extends the eligibility to include reserves and emergency forces. Let me stress that these measures are welcomed by the opposition; indeed they are measures which Labor committed to prior to the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the position that the government took on these matters during the campaign itself, the Liberal Party's policy statement did include certain matters that are contained in this bill. The relevant section from the Liberal Party's own document says:

The coalition will increase the maximum loan value under the ADF home assistance scheme from $40,000 to $80,000 and the eligibility period will be reduced to five years. This will come into effect by 1 July 1996, not 1 January 1997 as proposed by Labor.

As I read the Liberal Party's election document, there clearly are parts of the document that have been supported in this bill. In other words, part of the commitments made have been honoured. When the government indicated that its scheme was better than the Labor Party's scheme because it operated from 1 July, I suppose some of them actually believed it, though I suspect not all of them did.

Some of those in uniform, trusting and loyal individuals that they are, did take the coalition at its word. When the coalition said that it would be available from 1 July, they did not think that meant the bill would be introduced on the second last sitting day in June, some time in August the parliament might get around to dealing with it, some time in October it would be listed for consideration in the Senate and perhaps some time in November it would be given assent by the Governor-General in Council so that, in fact, defence force personnel would be eligible for it in December. When the government said they would be eligible on 1 July, I suspect they actually thought you meant it.

This one provision for a home loan subsidy for defence personnel was actually part of a number of initiatives the Labor government was addressing before the last election. They arose from the Glenn review, established by former Minister Punch. During the Glenn review, he identified a range of issues that required improvement if we were to ensure that defence personnel conditions kept pace with their needs and with contemporary employment practices.

One of the things that was mentioned then was an increase in the maximum amount available under the defence home owners scheme.
