On 10 December last year, the then minister, Minister Punch, issued a statement on behalf of the Labor government undertaking to implement that commitment. It was not just that one commitment; it was not in isolation. This was not a bandaid approach to address the needs of defence personnel. This was part of a coordinated approach to ensure that the net of services, benefits and remuneration available to people in defence was the best to attract high quality people and to retain them.

We also gave commitments in relation to child care, occasional care, family day care and an ADF spouse employment program. We gave commitments in relation to exemption for ADF members from changes to the superannuation preservation rules. We also gave commitments in relation to improvements in compassionate leave, the extension of education assistance provisions, the introduction of reunion travel for dependent tertiary students, the introduction of spouse emergency travel, the introduction of pre‐posting travel for members with special needs and dependants, an extension of remote locality leave travel provisions and also the removal of the anomaly in tax rebates for United Nations deployments. All of these things were part of a coordinated approach that Labor was committed to prior to the last election, one of which was the improvement to the home loan subsidy scheme.

Let me say again: the opposition will support this bill. We support the improvements in the home loan subsidy scheme and we are waiting to hear what you are going to do about a number of other issues. As I have indicated, I think we are going to have here a piecemeal approach—a bandaid approach, if you like.

I am interested also in listening and understanding in the future whether the government will endeavour to sidestep the entire Glenn review process. The recently released Glenn review identified the need for a long-term, strategic personnel policy which appropriately recognises the importance of manpower as a defence asset. In the words of the coalition:
In addition to other measures identified in this policy, the Coalition will implement a long-term strategic personnel plan in accordance with the principles identified in the Glenn review.

The question is: where is it? It seems to me that the government has gone AWOL since the election on these matters. You don't let people talk about the Glenn review any more. You have not come out with a coherent policy statement in relation to defence personnel.

As far as it goes, I believe that this bill makes good sense. But it does not go far enough, because it does not honour the election undertakings which the government made great play of during the election campaign. It is not satisfactory, because, of course, it is ad hoc and piecemeal. It is taken in isolation, and it does not address in a coherent and considered way the problems which were identified in the Glenn report.

I hope that the government will not be continuing to deal with defence personnel matters on such an ad hoc and impromptu basis. I hope that we have a far more considered and planned approach. If the objective and direction of the government's approach is to ensure that the defence personnel of the three services are properly remunerated, are properly rewarded and are better placed to do their job, I can assure you that you will have my support and the opposition's support. It is for these reasons that, as I have indicated, the opposition will, in the circumstances, be supporting this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 amends the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act 1990. The Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 is to be amended to close a loophole which stops ADF members serving overseas from being prosecuted for offences such as sexual assault and other serious offences. Of course, the Greens would support this, because it is important for many reasons, including Australia's good standing, for this to be able to be clear in any case of such alleged incidents occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also amends the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act 1990 to increase the maximum amount of a subsidised loan to $80,000 for each member of the forces, and to reduce the period for eligibility from six years to five years. This has been mentioned already by Senator Faulkner. This is another incentive to try to keep people in the ADF and give them nicer conditions. The Greens would support this as well. The bill, in itself, is not controversial. However, we would be seeking to amend it at the second reading stage to get the Australian government to review the status of forces agreement between the US and Australia with regard to codes of conduct and procedures for sexual assault and harassment incidents.

There seem to be three legislative mechanisms covering sexual assault by defence forces. The ADF are governed by the Defence Force Discipline Act for offences, including sexual offences, here and overseas; and the United States military forces are covered by the US uniform code of military justice legislation, which includes punishment for crimes such as rape and assault. With regard to transferability between the two, in 1967 both the United States and the ADF drew up the SOFA—the status of forces agreement—which is a bilateral agreement meant to subject the forces to a clear legal framework for crimes committed and procedures for claims for compensation or damages.

There is a need for a comprehensive legal framework and for prevention strategies to bring justice to women who suffer from assault and harassment by visiting overseas personnel. I suppose, in that case, that it could be for men as well. According to the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, in our region United States military personnel have chalked up an unenviable record in Okinawa, where the abduction and rape of a 12‐year‐old was most recently in the headlines.

But that is only one of at least 4,700 known crimes and incidents committed by US personnel in Okinawa, including the rape and murder of women.It is also not possible to rule these acts of violence out during training in Australia. We have had a spate of cases of sexual assault in Western Australia which were confirmed by the Western Australian Sexual Assault Referral Centre. This resulted in a visit by senior US military personnel to investigate three sexual assault complaints in July 1994.

The legal situation may seem fine and dandy to the forces, but it does not go far enough. Many assaults and rapes that are committed in Western Australia while US forces visit do not get to the prosecution stage. The women complain, but are too threatened by military processes to take the complaint further. The true legal situation has also been questioned in that the military are meant to come under Western Australian laws, but apparently the military have some scope to refer the matter back to military courts where the matter is dealt with internally. And apparently, once the person is back on board, the US military refuse to hand the person over and say that the matter will be dealt with internally. Therefore, the punishments are not transparent or accountable, and there are reported incidents where personnel are docked pay or recreation leave or are delayed promotion for serious offences.

BREAK.PARA: To circumvent this situation, agencies such as the Sexual Assault Referral Centre in Western Australia have decided to work with the United States military, through the consulate, to develop education and prevention strategies for personnel while they are in Western Australia on visits, recreation leave, and so on. At the moment, this kind of work is irregular because it is based on the will of the particular agencies to do the work. What has been achieved in Western Australia by way of video presentations, talks, leafleting and procedures for passing on complaints of sexual harassments or assaults to senior military personnel has apparently been very successful. Therefore, there needs to be some kind of encouragement of this as a framework to be implemented across all states.

What has been suggested by some non‐government organisations and women's organisations is, first, a review of the SOFA agreement to bring it up to date with the changing conditions; second, an enforceable code of conduct for personnel visiting Australia to prevent misconduct; and, third, continuing programs for dialogue and cooperation between state and federal agencies and US military representatives for education and prevention strategies for US military personnel. That explains the rationale and purpose of my second reading amendment.

Before I move my amendment, I would be keen to hear if there is a response from the ALP because the shadow minister, Mr Bevis, indicated in discussion that he might not be prepared to support a second reading amendment. We went through various stages where what was said was, `It's not usual' or `It's not the right place.' But as I have explained, this bill is exactly about that, and about clarifying the situation—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak on your amendment after you move it.

—That is fine. This is exactly the right kind of bill on which to move it, because we are doing the right thing in clarifying the situation of Australian personnel overseas so it is exactly the right place to move an amendment to clarify the situation for visiting US personnel in Australia. The commitment by the shadow minister—and I hope it will also be given serious consideration by the government—is to consider the amendment I am moving, but to consider it at a later date by way of a motion.

BREAK.PARA: So if it is not supportable simply because it is in the bill and because members of the House of Representatives are not as used to amendments of this type in a second reading as the Senate is because, for various reasons, the Senate has a different make‐up, I am very keen to continue with the debate and move my amendment at a later date in a motion if it does not get support today. I would still love to see it get support today. The world as we know it will not fall apart if what we are doing is carried out.

One of the other comments by Mr Bevis was this. The amendment said, `The Senate resolves that there be laid on the table, by the first day of sitting in 1997, a report.' He said, `You haven't mentioned who the report should be done by.' But I am advised that, under the Acts Interpretation Act, when it is not mentioned who is to produce the report there is an automatic assumption that it is the minister who is responsible for the ministry which administers the act. So the automatic assumption in the amendment is that we are asking for the minister representing the Minister for Defence to present that report to the Senate.

The second reading amendment is asking for an input into the adequacy of the agreement and of current procedures to give an indication of the incidence of alleged sexual assault and of the incidence of sexual assaults that have resulted in award of damages. It is asking for an enforceable code of conduct to implement and improve existing measures. It is asking that the review consider submissions from the public and allow public comment. It does not say that this is what shall be done, that this procedure shall be changed; it is simply asking that a well overdue review take place.

We are talking about a review that to my knowledge has not been conducted for over 30 years, since the 1960s. Things have changed over 30 years. The amendment was commended to me by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. I received a phone call from the Armed Services Association. They were dealing with this bill and I assumed that they were saying, `Look, what are you doing moving amendments. We like this bill.' But no. They rang and I asked them about the bill, and they said that, in fact, they were the people who recommended that the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom should come to the Greens because they assumed that we would be able to give them assistance and put this amendment through in the bill. They thought that it was a reasonable amendment and that it was something that really must be dealt with, if not in this bill now, at some time in the future.

I do think that it needs proper consideration. I would like it to be taken seriously and, if necessary, debated with the relevant committees, if that is necessary to have a reasonable debate. I do not think that the world will end if there is a review of these procedures. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

PARA.TAB: "but the Senate resolves that there be laid on the table by the first sitting day in 1997 a report of a review into:
(a) the adequacy of the Status of Forces Agreement between the United States of America (US) and Australia, and the US Uniform Code of Military Justice in prosecuting cases of:

TAB.TAB: (i) alleged criminal offences committed by US defence force personnel in Australia, including sexual assault;
(ii) alleged sexual harassment committed by US defence force personnel in Australia;

PARA.TAB: (b) the adequacy of current procedures for handling complaints and damages claims for cases of alleged sexual assault and sexual harassment by US defence personnel in Australia, and measures to improve those procedures by the involvement of civil law enforcement agencies;
(c) instances of alleged sexual assault, sexual harassment and other serious offences by overseas defence force personnel in Australia:

TAB.TAB: (i) which have not been prosecuted in Australia, and the reasons for non‐prosecution; and

(ii) which have been prosecuted in other jurisdictions, resulting in a lesser penalty than would have applied in the relevant Australian jurisdiction, and the reasons for non-prosecution in Australia;

PARA.TAB: (d) instances of sexual assault, sexual harassment or other serious offences by overseas defence force personnel in Australia which have not resulted in the award of damages to the victim;
(e) the need for an enforceable code of conduct for overseas defence force personnel in Australia;

(f) measures to implement, or improve existing, education and prevention strategies and cooperation between military representatives and service providers assisting people who have been the victims of alleged offences;

BREAK.PARA: and that the review consider submissions from the public and provide opportunity for public comment".

TALK.START.PARA: —(1.12 p.m.)—The government will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Greens on this bill. I really do not know why Senator Margetts is so obsessed about American service personnel raping, looting and burning their way across the Australian countryside. I am not aware that the incidence of criminal activities by American service personnel is any higher than it is for Australian personnel and, off the top of my head, I would think that in both armed forces the incidence of criminal activities is at a considerably lower level, by virtue of their training and their discipline, than it is in the civilian community.

BREAK.PARA: I accept that there are breaches of law from time to time by service personnel, because the human race is not infallible and it is not perfect. But we have seen in recent decades a very high standard of discipline and conduct by uniformed personnel when they are on leave and when they are visiting. I think that it is getting it quite out of perspective to equate what might happen in Australia with what might have gone on—and we have no way of checking those figures—in Okinawa, or anywhere else. With the greatest of respect, those matters are quite irrelevant to the bill.

My mind goes back to Senator Margetts's predecessor, Senator Vallentine. For months we were besieged with stories about how the incidence of venereal disease was far higher in Perth and Fremantle as a consequence of the American carrier battle groups coming to Western Australia. Ultimately, when the figures were released by the Public Health Department of the Western Australian government, it was found that since the visits had started, there had actually been a decline. So I think that you have got to get some statistical basis for these concerns, senator.

Put succinctly, the bill remedies some of the problems in the Defence Force Discipline Act, and makes attractive changes in relation to the defence home ownership scheme. The amending bill serves to correct a reference in the Defence Force Discipline Act of 1982 to offences against the New South Wales criminal law, to bring the legislation into line with 1992 changes in status of the ACT criminal law.

As it has not been explained in any other terms, I assume this amendment is a tidying up exercise, because items 1 to 4 of schedule 1 of this bill make the amendments required. Essentially, the existing section 61 of the Defence Force Discipline Act makes it an offence for a Defence Force member or a defence civilian to do any activity that would constitute an offence against the criminal law of the Jervis Bay territory. There is also a section which ensures that Defence Force members can be prosecuted under the Defence Force Discipline Act for offences committed overseas whilst on deployment or on exercises. Section 61 relates to offences in the Jervis Bay territory. These offences are defined by referring to the New South Wales Crimes Act of 1900. The Jervis Bay Territory Acceptance Act 1915 makes the laws which are enforced in the ACT apply to the Jervis Bay territory. Prior to 1992, the New South Wales Crimes Act 1900 was in force in the ACT and, therefore, in the Jervis Bay territory. Since 1992 the ACT Crimes Act has applied, and the Defence Force Discipline Act was not amended to reflect that change in status to the ACT law.

In making this change, the bill also seeks to retrospectively validate any section 61 prosecutions, if any exist, by providing that the amendments should be taken to have commenced on 22 May 1992, the date the appropriate ACT legislation commenced. I wonder whether the minister, in summing up, would be able to advise the Senate if she has access to data on whether any section 61 prosecutions will be validated by this retrospective change.

The bill also amends the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act 1990 to extend eligibility, through a change in eligibility criteria, to members previously unable to apply for a subsidised loan. Items 5 to 13 of schedule 1 reduce the period of service required to become eligible for the home loan from six years to five years for either full‐time or composite service. Further, the definition of eligibility is extended to include members of the reserve forces or emergency forces who complete the requisite training period and are not otherwise covered by the Defence Service Homes Act 1918. Changes made under items 24 to 43 of schedule 1 include increasing the amount of the loan from $40,000 to $80,000 and increasing the maximum amount of loan available to a couple of joint eligibility from $80,000 to $160,000.

In making these changes, the government is both fulfilling an election commitment and recognising the dedicated service given by defence personnel, and the unique nature of that service. It is also moving to change the existing system in an endeavour to assist in the process of retaining in the Defence Force the services of the very fine group of Australians who presently serve. The previous system was taken up by less than 2,000 people, so it was not a very great success. This scheme should prove much more attractive.

It is a fact that, thanks to the Labor government, there has been a significant slump in morale in the Australian Defence Force, with concomitant high resignation rates. When you have got annual reductions in budgets, reductions in training and exercise time and, above all, continual reductions in staff numbers, reducing the strengths of establishment, then—whatever you might call those reductions in numbers by glorifying them with titles such as `management initiated voluntary redundancies' or `retirements'—such reductions have an absolutely devastating effect on people's morale and on their career hopes and ambitions.

We have seen, for many years now, annual reductions in the defence budget, and it really has had a most corrosive effect on morale in the ADF. One of the good things about this government is that it has held the line on budget allocations and has given a commitment to do that for the life of this parliament. That stand—coupled with measures such as the home loan scheme amendment—will, we hope, mean that there will be a turnaround in defence staff morale.

Over the years, I have expressed here a concern regarding the apparent failure of the Australian Defence Force to imbue its structure with a culture of responsibility and accountability. On too many occasions in the past decade or so, military inquiries have been followed by boards of inquiry, and by further inquiries, until the statutory period under the Defence Force Discipline Act has passed—a period which, as the Senate will remember, is only three years—and then nothing can be done about the breach of discipline. Unfortunately, this is a pattern that has become very familiar in recent years.

Senators will remember that, earlier this year, the Senate committee of inquiry into the Nomad crash reported before we rose for the winter recess. That Senate committee made the recommendation that the period be increased from three years to five years, so that intentional or unavoidable extensions of time in the course of inquiries did not preclude action being taken under the Defence Force Discipline Act.

I would hope that the government is looking seriously at this matter because it is as real today as it was when the Senate report came down. Having said that, I am not for one moment suggesting that there is a problem across the Defence Force where unlawful or unacceptable actions can be performed with impunity—far from it. I am saying that when actions of a major nature occur, which have unintended consequences, seldom is anyone brought to account for them.

I have always maintained that the ADF is a unique organisation, but that uniqueness does not justify there being a lower standard of accountability or responsibility in its operations. In fact, I would argue the contrary—that, considering the nature of service in the ADF, and the objectives and the commitment of the force to what it has to do, there is a need for higher standards of accountability than in the civilian role. With those words, I wish the bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the amendment—
—Has it been moved?

—I thought so. My understanding is that Senator Margetts formally moved her amendment and invited at least the opposition to give a response. Given that it was such a polite invitation, I feel absolutely obligated to take it up, but very briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, I would be very concerned about any amendments delaying this bill which might have the effect of denying ADF personnel access to improved home loans. The opposition will not be supporting Senator Margetts's amendments. We think it is inappropriate for a resolution calling for a report to be tabled on the first day of sitting in 1997 to be included in the statutes, particularly when I do not believe a case has been made for it by Senator Margetts in her contribution.

But having said that, let me say on a more positive note that, from the opposition's perspective, I think we would look favourably on giving Senator Margetts an opportunity in the future to debate this motion. I do not say that that indicates a position on the substance of the amendment that Senator Margetts has moved but I think she ought to interpret that as an acknowledgment on the part of the opposition of the importance of the issues that her amendment canvasses.

Let us be clear: I think this second reading amendment crosses the invisible line of those that it is appropriate to debate fully and argue within what has been a fairly broad interpretation of appropriate second reading amendments. From my perspective, this one does not meet those broad criteria for a matter to be debated in that context. With those few remarks, I think that adequately places on record the opposition's view in relation to the amendment. I indicate again that the opposition will support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. Of course, as the former shadow minister for defence, it is a matter of great pleasure to me personally to see this legislation coming forward. As Senator Faulkner pointed out, it was a coalition commitment at the last election. I would have been happier still if we had been able to bring it forward earlier than this.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Faulkner would well know, having been a minister, the pressures of the legislative program often means that legislation does not come through as fast as you might like. There was an opportunity for this legislation to come through a couple of weeks ago. Unfortunately, the Senate was not in a position to take it through on the Thursday lunchtime. I understand that it is to take effect from the date of royal assent. We hope that that will be very shortly so that the eligibility of defence force personnel to the increased home loans will become available very soon.

Apart from the increase in the size of the loan, there are two things about the bill that I am pleased about: the reduction in the waiting time for eligibility to five years and, more important than anything for the long‐term good of the defence forces, the extension of the scheme to reservists. The previous government did talk about the total force concept, but this is one of the great symbols that reservists are part of that total force. It is one force. The extension of the eligibility in a proportionate way to reservists is very important and will be welcomed widely throughout the defence forces.

Senator Faulkner also mentioned the ad hoc nature of the introduction of measures out of our policy. Perhaps he is not aware of the fact that funding has already been set aside for the eight 30‐place child‐care centres around Australia for the defence force personnel and of another measure which I think is very important—that is, the spouse employment database. One of the very big problems for defence force personnel is that their spouses find it hard to get employment as they are moved around the country to satisfy the needs of the government and the Department of Defence.

Senator MacGibbon asked about the validity and the need for this amendment. I am advised that there have been 16 prosecutions since 1992 and that the advice from the Attorney‐General's Department is that those prosecutions were valid. However, Defence, through perhaps an abundance of caution, is proposing that this amendment be included in this bill.

I turn now to Senator Margetts's contribution and refer to the important matter covered by her amendment. I take her concerns very seriously, as I would as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Violence against women can never be condoned. I would be very concerned to see that Australian women were being subjected to violence which was not being dealt with by disciplinary action or that there were not legal consequences to any such actions.

However, the government considers that the arrangements that are already in place fully address the concerns raised by the amendment. The Australian, United States and other foreign governments take the issue of the conduct of military personnel very seriously and are determined to ensure that the highest standards of behaviour are maintained. The government does not consider that SOFA arrangements in general, particularly the SOFA covering US forces in Australia, fall short of appropriate standards and, accordingly, sees no requirement for those arrangements to be amended.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Margetts flagged that there may well be other mechanisms available to her if she wants to pursue the issue. As Senator Faulkner flagged, the government would not be trying to stifle such a debate, because it is, as I said at the outset, an important issue. We do not believe it is appropriate to amend the second reading motion of this bill; therefore, we are not able to support your amendment, Senator. I thank everybody for their contribu tion and I wish the defence force personnel who are going to be the beneficiaries of this legislation the very best for home ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the appropriation bills for 1996‐97. In the course of the examination of the provisions of the appropriation bills, three legislation committees made recommendations to the Senate arising from their examination of the proposed appropriations. Most legislation committees also commented on the lack of adequate information in the portfolio budget statements and the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee re‐affirmed its view of the role of ministers appearing before committees.

SPEECH.PARA: To facilitate the moving and consideration of the committee's recommendations and findings, the chairs of the relevant committees have agreed that, as Chairman of Committees, I should move a motion on behalf of the chairs, for the adoption of the recommendations and the noting of the major findings. Accordingly, I now move:
At the end of the motion, add:
", and the Senate, having considered the reports of the legislation committees on the proposed expenditure in respect of the year ending on 30 June 1997:
(1) Adopts the following recommendations contained in those reports—

(a) That the Procedure Committee further consider the recommendation made by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee in its December 1994 report for improving the efficient conduct of estimates hearings, and that it consider options such as:

PARA.TAB: (i) allocating an extra day for hearings;
(ii) scheduling the Senate to rise earlier (or not sit at all) on estimates hearings days; and/or
(iii) setting firm appointment times during the hearing days for the different parts of the portfolios.
(Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, report paragraph 2.12) .

SPEECH.PARA: (b) That the Procedure Committee consider amending the three‐day rule to a five‐day rule or clarify the rule to mean three working days.

PARA.TAB: (Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, supplementary report, paragraph 2.5) .

SPEECH.PARA: (c) That the following matter be referred to the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee—

TAB.TAB: The Portfolio Budget Statements, including consideration of a new, improved format.

PARA.TAB: (Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, report paragraph 2.16) .

SPEECH.PARA: (d) That the Department of Finance revise the structure of the Portfolio Budget Statements to include information about estimates expenditure for items within sub‐programs.

PARA.TAB: (Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee, report paragraph 9) .

SPEECH.PARA: (e) That the President issue a procedural rule under Remuneration Tribunal Determination no. 21 of 1995 to provide that committee chairs travelling on committee business not related to a meeting of the committee be required to advise the committee secretary in writing of their travel and the reason for it, to facilitate checking of travel claims.

PARA.TAB: (Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, report page 3) .

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Notes that most legislation committees commented adversely on the current content of the Portfolio Budget Statements, including a lack of adequate information.
(3) Notes that the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee:
(a) is of the opinion that future supplementary hearings dates should be set well in advance, as an order of the Senate, to enable the presence of ministers as required; and

(b) reaffirms its view of the role of the relevant minister in the estimates process as essentially that of providing responses to questions about government policy, with departmental officers available to provide detailed responses to questions about the implementation of those policies.

PARA.TAB: (Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee, report paragraph 10) .".

SPEECH.PARA: As the arguments in support of the recommendations are set out in the reports of the relevant committees, I do not propose to canvass them at this time. I expect that senators who participated in the relevant committee procedures will address those arguments in the course of the debate on the motion for the second reading and on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this group of appropriation bills and to put forward some views on behalf of the opposition. I will concentrate specifically on matters that relate to education. I begin by indicating that I believe that these bills, in essence, encompass the lies and the broken promises that this government has perpetrated on the Australian public since the election.

SPEECH.PARA: The broken promises affect all groups in the community. They do not single out any particular group, not the elderly, the sick, the poor, the workers of this country, the unemployed, the social security beneficiaries, the families, or the mothers and fathers of children in child care. They are quite indiscriminate in their abuse of the Australian people, in so far as they grossly mislead the Australian people as to the intentions of this government. These bills bring forward the first tranche of that betrayal. Of course, we expect to see further betrayals in the coming budgets in this parliament.

They encompass a hidden package of right wing ideology which assumes that small government is somehow or other the answer to all our prayers and that the private sector is somehow or other the answer to all the problems this country faces. And they are wrapped in the lie that, somehow or other, we are facing massive economic problems which can only be responded to by undermining the rights of Australian people—rights to services and to facilities that they have a right to expect from government.

This rhetoric goes to the basic proposition that this government is effectively dominated by a group of free‐market zealots who are based on the Lyons group that operates as a faction within what we would call the caucus and the H.R. Nicholls Society. This is a generation coming to full flower. We have seen them work on these schemes in secret and acquire little covens all over this country for many years. They get into government and now they have the opportunity to vent their spleen.

TALK.START.PARA: —They give their mates contracts.

—As Senator Conroy points out, they give their mates the odd contract on the way through. What this is really all about is institutionalising advantage and privilege for the few at the expense of the many. This rhetoric of protecting privilege is nowhere more clearly demonstrated than in the education portfolio. In DEETYA, we see that this government proposes cuts across the forward estimates period of $4.3 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear a lot about these cuts in the higher education sector where we will see cuts of $1.8 billion. We see it in cuts to labour market programs at a time when unemployment is becoming increasingly a social problem in our country. When the demand for government services is growing, we see the retracting of government services under this government. We see it in the schools sector as well—something we do not often talk about at the national level—where we see $128 million being taken from government schools across this country and a direct transfer of resources from the public to the private sector.

A pattern is emerging from this. In the budget, Commonwealth outlays in relation to DEETYA for the 1995‐96 financial year were about 11.1 per cent of total outlays. It has been reduced to 10.7 per cent for the 1996‐97 year, 10.4 per cent for the 1997‐98 year, 9.6 per cent for the 1998‐99 year and 9.1 per cent for the year 1999‐2000. So we have a two per cent drop in overall outlays from DEETYA.

BREAK.PARA: That indicates quite a substantial and very radical change in government priorities in this budget period. The government is fundamentally shifting priorities away from education, training and employment services. These measures will most severely impact on future generations and most severely curtail their hopes, their aspirations and their opportunities. I have already seen this pattern in Victoria from governments dominated by extreme right wing ideologues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Grahame Morris.

—Grahame Morris has been mentioned as an example of this in terms of the advertising approach that is being presented. But what we see in Victoria with regard to the health system, the education system and the community services system is a whole pattern of disadvantage being perpetrated, a whole pattern of abuse of a community as the result of the presentation of these extreme, ideologically skew‐whiff views about the nature of the way our society works.

BREAK.PARA: In the health system we understand the cuts impact directly on the community. People often respond most acutely to attacks on the health system because people die as a result of cuts to government expenditure. In education, it takes a little while longer, and that is the problem. Nonetheless, the impact is still very dramatic. In social terms it is huge because, as a result of these cuts, we will see that the level of disadvantage for some in our community, and advantage for others, is exacerbated. It reinforces inequality, it reinforces the distribution of privilege and it reinforces the notion that certain people in our society, already wealthy, already powerful, the cream of our society—

TALK.START.PARA: —The rich and thick.

—the cream or our society or, as Senator Conroy has said, the rich and thick, will take particular benefit from government actions, while the people that need assistance the most, the disadvantaged in our community, are left to fend for themselves. That in itself is something that ought be condemned.

BREAK.PARA: Only yesterday we received information about just how dramatic these cuts are in student assistance. For example, in an answer to a question on notice from the budget estimates, the department revealed that over one in five students now eligible for Austudy will be affected by the government's budget measures, either by losing the entire entitlement or by receiving a cut in the range of payments. Up to 125,000 students in Australia will be affected by the range of cuts totalling $138 million in the first full year of these particular budget measures. Over a four‐year period the budget cut will be some $514 million in student education assistance.

Austudy changes go much further. We have seen the allegations based on the fabricated and bogus family presented as the Wright family which was designed by this government to highlight and express all of those most negative attitudes in terms of public opinion about the beneficiaries of public assistance. We had all the allegations about the 5,000 millionaires on welfare predicated on the bogus information presented by Senator Vanstone using the estimates process to propagate a lie and to try to condition the public to assume that the withdrawal of public benefit from Australian citizens was somehow a legitimate process to undertake. About 8,500 Austudy and Abstudy beneficiaries on homeless rates will now lose their schooling incidental allowance. We are talking about homeless people here, not millionaires! Homeless people! In terms of these budget measures, some 2,600 single Austudy and Abstudy beneficiaries who share accommodation will have their rent assistance reduced because of the lowering of the maximum rate.
I note that this is one measure that does not apply to the halls of residence at the universities. The wealthy graziers of the Western District of Victoria will still be able to pump—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Gippsland.

—And, of course, Gippsland. I am sure that the great McGauran family of Gippsland will to be able to pump their sons and daughters of the region into the halls of residence and they will be looked after at public expense. But the people where I live, in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, who are trying to cope with the rigours of the economy at the moment, will not have access to these sorts of benefits.

BREAK.PARA: Another measure is to raise the independence of Austudy from 22 to 25 years old. That will affect some 12,000 people who will become ineligible because of their parents' assets. We are talking about people who may be as old as 30 and who, under this government, are alleged to be dependants. People as old as 30 years of age being assessed as if they were dependent upon their parents—an extraordinary measure! We will see the toughening of the actual means test. Not only will 13,000 students be caught under the particular measures that Labor took as a government to ensure that there was a tightening up of the means test, but a further 71,700 students will be affected under the coalition's tightening of the assets tests in relation to the means test for Austudy. This will undoubtedly affect many less than wealthy families, as well.

And, of course, it is being dressed up as if it were some sort of glorious attack upon millionaires. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Austudy measures are on top of the draconian changes we have seen to HECS. Not only are we hitting students for student support services that are provided by government, but we are also attacking students by charging them higher fees to go to university. And, in terms of ancillary fees that are being proposed under this government, students will pay more for the use of the library, computers, and a whole lot of services that one expects would be part of academic and university life. Then we have charges in terms of the HECS repayments.

What does that mean for ordinary folk who are trying to use the university system as a means of providing themselves with qualifications? How can we bring pride in this country by ensuring that we have the skilled personnel necessary for us to develop as a nation? Let us look at what this will mean for, say, school teachers. The time taken for them to repay their HECS will increase from six years to nine years. The average amount paid per year will increase from just over $1,600 to $2,400, or about 50 per cent a year in which the payment actually occurs. This will be a gross disadvantage. Given the measures that are being taken by this government to make education more expensive, I would think that many people will have to reconsider whether they undertake studies to gain these sorts of qualifications. These measures provide an advantage to the wealthy: if you are wealthy you can buy a place at the university.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, under certain circumstances.
—We have heard from the minister in terms of her guidelines, which leave it open slather. Once again, in complete breach—
—Tell us the whole story.

—The full story is very simple. This minister does not have a clue what she is doing. The guidelines that she is talking about will be proposed in such a way as to allow for there be open slather, not the restrictions proposed in the public statements announced by this government. It will not be a disallowable instrument in terms of these guidelines regulating what courses universities can charge for. What we will see is that some 17,000 Commonwealth funded places will be withdrawn as a result of these government charges.

BREAK.PARA: It is in the area of schools education where the ideological obsession of this government is most evident. The market approach is encouraged and equity is outlawed under its so‐called broadbanding proposals. The whole concept of the distribution of targeted and quality education programs is removed from the guidelines. In fact, equity is presumed to be some sort of socialist concept. Of course, we cannot have that under this regime of free marketeers!

PARA.BREAK: The principle of universal free public education is abandoned and our public schools are left to wither on the vine. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been withdrawn from the public sector as a result of the so‐called enrolment benchmarks and placed with the private sector. I have seen ads in papers in Melbourne recently where Christian fundamentalist colleges are now advertising on the basis of changes to this government's policies. They say in their public advertise ments that, in an effort to attract people away from the public education system and into these particular colleges, fees can now be dropped by some 30 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: The abolition of the new schools policy that this government is proposing is but one example of where we will see the deregulation of an industry. It will have dramatic effects on the established educational providers, be it the public education system, which is one I strongly support, or the Catholic education system.

Let me turn to the targeted education programs. Under this government, my state of Victoria will lose some 11 per cent of its funding for the disadvantaged schools program. Also, the Catholic Education Office will lose $1½ million for its funding in Victoria as a result of this government's proposals. This is a proposition that has much deeper roots than just an attack upon schools themselves. A philosophy is being promoted through this budget—an ideological obsession—which seeks to highlight a view of government and society whereby the private sector is good and the public sector is allegedly bad.
Let me quote from a recent article in the Academy of Social Science newsletter, written by an education academic, Professor Connell, from the University of New South Wales. He says:

We might wonder how a group of businessmen and economists who are rather ignorant of education—and did little to learn about it—claim to overturn a generation of educational debate, negotiation and institution‐building. Yet the National Commission of Audit report of June 1996 is not an aberration. Business intellectuals believe that in the market that they have, almost literally, an answer for everything. The view is that education is mainly a private good, for which individuals should, in principle, pay; that education institutions should be forced to compete with each other, to produce efficiency; that the government provision is an `intervention' in the market which should be reduced, if not eliminated, while private provision is increased.

These ideas are, of course, vigorously contested by teachers, unions, academic economists and educators. Yet they have enormous influence—especially within this government, I might add. The deregulation of education, the abandonment of planning provisions for new private schools and the open slather `compete or die' mentality adopted by this government can only have one consequence: that the rich pay for their quality education while the poor rely on a public sector devoid of resources and strapped for cash. Professor Connell also points outs:

In Making the Difference , my colleagues and I found a well‐developed market articulating ruling class in schools, with the ruling‐class families who provide their social basis. What families were buying in this market was not an educational service as such—that was available to them free of charge in the state schools. They were buying an education and social advantage for their children.

This situation has been most clearly seen in Victoria, where the federal government has abandoned restrictions on new private schools and the new state government is implementing harsh new planning provisions for government schools. We have seen, in recent days, some 113 schools targeted for closure.

TALK.START.PARA: —All in Labor areas.

—I might point out that two‐thirds of those happen to be in Labor seats, despite the fact that we, in Victoria, hold one‐third of the seats. The closures are targeted at secondary schools with fewer than 400 students, and at multicampus schools with fewer than 300 students. How do the same provisions apply in terms of the private sector? At best, 60; and fewer than 40, for the primary schools. Only in Victoria is there any provision at all for minimum enrolments, and there the issues are, quite clearly, inequitable. What we have seen is a whole series of measures forced upon the education system in that state.

BREAK.PARA: This federal government, as far as I am concerned, is aiding and abetting the social vandals, such as we have seen in Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania, who aim to undermine the rights and the legitimate concerns that, within the government, we ought to be advancing in this country. Federal government policies aimed at the primary, secondary and tertiary levels are designed to shrink the public sector and promote the private. Clearly, these measures result in a market promoting advantage for the privileged few and disadvantage for the overwhelming majority.

Whilst, for obvious reasons, the opposition will not be opposing the appropriation bills, because we have a firm policy of not seeking to block the budget, we will be seeking to highlight how inadequate these measures are. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the great problems of following Senator Carr is that you just do not know where to start on his speech. Senator Carr, that was vintage you: straight out of the handbook of class warfare. I am only sorry that we are not being broadcast, because I am told that some 30,000 to 50,000 people listen at any one time to the broadcast, and it would have been good for them to hear that speech. It was vintage Senator Carr. Senator Carr, you run a close second to Jennie George. Next to Jennie George, you really do take the prize for being locked in the Cold War rhetoric of the 1950s. You are the last of the great Marxist‐Leninists. Your speech had everything in it, right down to blaming this government for cats and dogs: the budget is even going so far as to affect them.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not got the time to address, line by line, your ridiculous speech. I dare say that, when you send out, it will be to a very narrow audience. I simply say this to you, Senator Carr: on analysis, what about the Lindsay by‐election? That really does bury everything you said in your speech. What about the Lindsay by‐election? Lindsay is pure Labor heartland: John Curtin's old seat in full. You obviously are not hearing the message that came out of the Lindsay by‐election. Our budget has been accepted. The measures, as tough as some of them are, are being accepted because, for once, there is a strategy behind them, and that is a downward pressure on interest rates. That area of Australia, which is representative of the whole of Australia, utterly rejects the opposition's approach. The voters are utterly rejecting the Labor Party—your old heartland.

So as pleasing as it is to us on this side to hear that you are still locked in that time warp, Senator Carr, that tired old rhetoric is just not going down in the electorate. That is why I say I am very sorry it is not on broadcast. You talk about broken promises and destruction of economies. Senator Carr, we know who you worked for before you came into this parliament. You used to work for the previous Victorian government—the Cain‐Kirner government. Senator Kemp has just walked into this parliament and he knows only too well the destruction that was caused by the Cain‐Kirner government in Victoria where debt was ratcheted up to $32 billion.

Even John Cain, the disgraced former Premier, has bad words for you, Senator Carr. You only have to read his book to get his opinion of how you influenced the destruction of the Victorian economy—you and your left‐wing clique that totally ran the Victorian government during those miserable years. You were duly dealt with, you have escaped and come up here, but they would be gunning for you.

You talk about broken promises—goodness gracious! That has been the subject of many debates on matters of public interest in this parliament. You know the answer to that. It was put in a nutshell when your own federal director called the previous government, your government, liars. That is why you lost the last election—the public could no longer stomach your constant lies. It is in your own analysis, by your own federal director, Gary Gray, and you come in here and talk about broken promises.

I came in here with a script for the appropriations bill so I would be able to send it out to a very wide audience untouched by interjections. But Senator Carr has so provoked me that I have had to take up his absurd class warfare speech. He even attacked the good people of Gippsland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—That is a shame, as Senator Troeth says, to get down to that level of attacking the good farmers of Gippsland and the good people of Gippsland. And, as Senator Carr should know, the city of Sale has a fine education infrastructure and has not been at all badly done by in this budget. Senator Carr, you talked about the privileged in your ideological speech. What about the tens of millions of dollars—to the tune of $100 million—that the union movement received in direct grants from the previous government? It was cloaked under all sorts of odd and unusual programs and names, but we know they were direct grants into the pockets of the union movement to prop up their ailing administration and their falling membership. You were party to that too—and you talk about entrenching the privileged.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Carr, don't send your speech out. You are fortunate we are not on broadcast. Don't send your speech out except to that small band within the Trades Hall Council. I know your office is within a minute of the Trades Hall Council and I am sure Wally Curran, and a few old warriors like that, will still want to read it. But don't give it a wide spread, Senator Carr, unless you want to play directly into our hands.

The truth of the matter is that this government has a budget strategy and its budget has been well accepted by the Australian public. It is not often that I get such an audience as I have now. However, I am going to have to wind up my remarks so we can get on with the cut and thrust of question time. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I refer to your answer to a dorothy dixer yesterday in which you expressed concern, justified concern, about corporate executives enjoying excessive wage increases while demanding wage restraint on the shop floor. Are you aware that a prominent Liberal Party figure, Hugh Morgan, recently received a salary increase of $200,000 a year? Isn't it true that, as your government's nominee to the board of the Reserve Bank, he is charged with encouraging policies which moderate inflationary pressures, including those caused by excessive wage demands? The Treasurer said two days ago:

QUESTION.PARA: As far as the government is concerned, wage‐productivity outcomes based on restraint, locking in low inflation, are a two-way street. It is a question of not just the work force but management as well realising the potential that they have to lead by example in this area.
What credibility does Mr Morgan have as a guardian of low inflation and wage moderation? Are you satisfied with the example he is setting? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Conroy, for raising this question again. We have made our position very clear. There is an era which is emerging of low wage and salary increases. What we are looking at is a low inflation economy and wage and salary increases which are based on productivity gains. We have indicated that we expect all groups in the community to recognise that we are now in a low inflation economy and we expect all groups to have moderate demands in relation to wage and salary increases which recognise that low inflation level. We do not resile, Senator Conroy, from those particular statements. I am very happy to have the chance to repeat, once again, that this is the government's position. We expect all groups in the community to show restraint.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Labor opposition, by its behaviour, is indicating that it hasn't heard the message from the voters, delivered to it on 2 March, that they wanted a change of direction and elected the Howard government on a platform of `governing for all of us' and reconfirmed this on 19 October in the Lindsay by-election. What has the first Howard government achieved so far in implementing its policies? Importantly, what has it done to ensure that it has listened to the Australian community?
—Boring!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that Senator Collins regards good government as boring because when you look at the record of the Labor Party there were lots of pieces to be picked up by the new incoming Howard government. We did inherit a set of very unfortunate circumstances: three‐quarters of a million Australians still unemployed as a result of Labor's policy; foreign debt at enormously high levels; an incoming budget deficit after five years of growth of $10 billion—the Beazley black hole—for which the current Leader of the Opposition is responsible.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We need silence before we can continue.

—Finance ministers have to accept some responsibility and Mr Beazley, as finance minister, presided over a budget deficit of $10 billion whilst he told us there was no budget deficit at all. That was the first and major responsibility that the new incoming government had to face if we were to create the economic environment with which we could see increased job growth and rising living standards.

ANSWER.PARA: The first budget we brought down tackled head on the question of government expenditure. We were the first government for years that was prepared to take the hard decisions and face up to that budget deficit of $10 billion by cutting public expenditure. Labor was never prepared to do it. Labor's answer was always, `You borrow more or you tax more.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the last budget deficit you left?

—Senator Bolkus would well remember the fuel taxes going up, the wholesale sales tax going up—borrow more, tax more. The answer was a $10 billion deficit. In our first budget we tackled that deficit. We tackled public expenditure. We made the courageous decisions and all signs so far are that the public has endorsed us in doing so and wants us to get into place these appropriations and budget related bills that will bring down public expenditure.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, they asked us to do something about the debacle of public health and private health under Labor. Our policies to provide tax relief for people taking out private health insurance, giving them greater choice in protecting their and their families' health, remain in place, as well as our policy in forcing the wealthy to pay a higher Medicare tax levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a fraudulent one. You knew about it. You knew it was going out the other pocket—in one hand and out the other.
—That was a policy, Senator Bolkus, that your former colleague Senator Richardson said that he wished the Labor Party had the courage to implement, but of course it didn't.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, we made promises to older Australians, to our elderly, so disregarded by the previous Labor government. We said that it was time they were recognised properly and respected by government. We decided to retain twice yearly indexation of the pension, thereby maintaining the age pension at or above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and to provide for self‐funded retirees the same tax rebate as the pensioner rebate, taking the single person's tax-free threshold from $5,400 to $11,185—a promise by the new incoming government to elderly Australians, a promise that was made at the time of the election, and a promise to be implemented pursuant to the budget package passing through the Senate.

Fourthly, we addressed the issue of small business—small business that had it so hard under Labor. We reduced the provisional tax uplift factor to six per cent, delivering $180 million back to provisional taxpayers in the 1996‐97 year. We are moving, through the legislation before the parliament, to remove the job destroying unfair dismissal laws. There is a program in place that gives Australians hope, which is more than they ever got from you. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could Senator Hill further enlarge on some of the achievements of the Howard government in its first months in office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be pleased to. I have talked about taking the hard decisions to cut public expenditure. I have talked about what we are doing in relation to health to restore confidence in public health and to encourage people into private health. I have talked about benefits we are giving to older Australians. I have talked about some of the benefits we have given to small business. But now, given that I have been given the opportunity, I will remind the Senate also of our promise that capital gains tax rollover relief would be provided to enable people in small business to reinvest in larger businesses.

ANSWER.PARA: We on this side of the chamber want to see small business work. We want to see small business grow into large business. We helped them with tax relief to do so because we want to see them employ some of the mass unemployed that you left. On top of that, we put down specific promises for regional Australia, which was so disregarded by the previous Labor government. We increased assistance to isolated students, and, if I had the chance, I would go on further. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Minister, is it a fact that Patrick Shanahan of Elliott and Shanahan Research, when he was presenting his findings on the market testing of the creative concepts for the national gun advertising campaign to your ministerial committee, stated that during the focus group testing of the DDB Needham proposal he actually feared for his physical safety? Given the fact that Elliott and Shanahan were more critical of DDB Needham Adelaide than of any other of the four agencies, does the government's endorsement of DDB Needham Adelaide reflect badly on Elliott and Shanahan, and hasn't the political fix unfairly damaged their very good reputation as a reputable pollster?

—We have now had two days of hearings with the estimates committees for questions on this particular issue and we have had a number of question times in this chamber and in the other place. We have also agreed to another series of hearings with the estimates committees to deal with all the questions that have been raised. I have to say the premise of the very question that Senator Bolkus raised does seem absurd. I have no particular information on that.
—Will you check it? Take it on notice.
—Senator Ray, what normally happens here, as you well know—
—Senator Kemp, address your remarks through the chair, thank you, not across the chamber.

—Thank you for reminding me of that. I was being unduly provoked by Senator Ray. It is interesting that every time Senator Ray or Senator Bolkus asks me a question on this issue they get up and scurry out of the chamber, and then 10 minutes later the same question is raised over in the other place. Why don't you save everybody some time and scurry out now—do not bother to ask the question—and ask it over there if you want to. We are providing a vehicle for you to ask all these questions—good questions, absurd questions and questions with inferences, whatever you want to ask. I do not think I could add anything to the comments that Senator Bogus made to me. I will see if there is any other information I can give him.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice once again that Senator Kemp is not prepared to come clean on this. I also noted in his answer that he said that the government has agreed to another series of estimates to handle this issue. Given that I have just been advised by the chairman of the Senate legal and constitutional estimates committee that Senator Hill does not want that committee to reconvene, and given the fact that the national gun advertising education campaign is run by the Attorney‐General's Department, and that that committee has direct responsibility for the estimates of the Attorney-General, will you take up with your leader the question of that committee meeting again and can you clarify the government's disorganisation on this response?

—I must say that there have been some absurd follow-up questions, but that really takes the cake, Senator Bolkus. You know very well there is an estimates hearing scheduled for next Thursday night, which you will be at. It is already marked in your diary, Senator Bolkus, you will find. So there is no confusion on our part. You will have plenty of chances to ask any questions you like and we will provide answers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. I ask Senator Parer: will he detail the progress that the government has made on establishing a competitive national electricity grid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would very much like to thank Senator Ferris for that question because at long last we are talking about something which is of great benefit to Australia rather than these silly sorts of things being raised by the Labor Party, who are still licking their wounds about the fact they are no longer in government. Just have a look at them, Madam President. The same old crowd.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has allocated $2 million in 1996-97 to support the electricity reform initiatives. This will support the operation of the National Grid Management Council in facilitating the introduction of the national electricity market and allow for corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains scheme by 1 July 1997. The electricity supply industry used to be characterised by poor productivity, over‐investment and hidden cross‐subsidies. Electricity is a very important business input, and reducing the cost of power will make Australian firms much more competitive.

The Commonwealth and states are, therefore, implementing a range of reforms that will create a genuine national electricity market. New South Wales and Victoria now have competitive markets at a state level. Those states and the ACT will operate as a harmonised market from February next year on the basis of their existing state codes. The states and the Australian Capital Territory will be progressively harmonising their codes and will be introducing integrated dispatch and interregional hedging arrangements by July.

The Grid Management Council, under the chairmanship of Mr Landels, has done a great job. He should have a great amount of pride in the development of the national electricity code and in the establishment of two organisations that will run the market.

The National Electricity Market Management Company will be located in Victoria. I am sure Senator Ferris will be interested to know that the National Electricity Code Administrator will be located in South Australia. This agreement was reached by all the participants. The code will be formally submitted to the ACCC for authorisation as soon as the Senate passes the Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill.

I urge the Senate to recognise the importance of an electricity reform process which will lead to lower electricity prices, reduce greenhouse gases and offer higher levels of service. The question is often raised as to how it will reduce greenhouse gases. In the past, the states were constrained by their own boundaries, as honourable senators will probably know. This meant we had this oscillation from brownouts to oversupplies, and nothing challenged the minds of state ministers more than brownouts. We are now in a situation where there is a surplus of electricity in Victoria and New South Wales and somewhat of a shortage in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Bass Strait cable?

—Good interjection, Senator Harradine. This will mean the surplus power from Victoria will be able to go into New South Wales and South Australia and the surplus from New South Wales into Queensland and South Australia. As everyone would be aware, having generators at full capacity means there is less contribution to greenhouse gas effects.

ANSWER.PARA: The coalition is a forward looking government. The previous government, as I mentioned earlier, is still licking its wounds. It is clearly retreating into the past, almost—I thought to myself the other day—to the `how green was my valley' days. It is important that this particular reform be taken into account. It is a major reform. It is one where we now have the support of all the involved states within the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister please explain further the importance of a competitive electricity grid in the process of national micro‐economic reform?

—I would like to thank the senator for that supplementary question. Let me just repeat what I said before. It is very important for the future of this country that we actually progress the freeing up of the electricity market. It is a major reform. One of the interesting things is that there were some early difficulties, as senators will know, with regard to grid connections between certain states.
—Eastlink, for example.

—Yes, Senator Collins interjects and says, `Eastlink.' That is quite correct. In very cooperative discussions with the New South Wales government, with the relevant minister, Michael Egan, and with Mr Tom Gilmore, the Minister for Mines and Energy in Queensland, it was agreed that the grid connection would take place, although the route would be different. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, is it not a fact that page 11 of the Prime Minister's guidelines on ministerial construct specifically enjoins ministers to `not operate as traders' in the stock market? Is it not a fact that, in defending the circumstances of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism in relation to his holding in Bligh Ventures, the Prime Minister strenuously asserted that Mr Moore's holding was insignificant—that is, not suggestive of influence or control of that company? Minister, is it not a fact that, in relation to Ralsten Pty Ltd, Mr Moore holds nine of the 10 ordinary shares and all of the 750,000 fully paid redeemable preference shares? Minister, will the Prime Minister, again, ask his chief investigative officer, Mr Max Moore‐Wilton, to investigate these matters?
—This is a bit of a beat-up.
—Everything is a beat-up!

—A little while ago they were talking about tired questions. This one was asked yesterday in the House of Representatives. It was raised yesterday in the House, this morning in the newspapers and, finally, Senator Faulkner has woken up and come in here and asked about it.

BREAK.PARA: Just in case Senator Faulkner missed it, Mr Moore made a statement on this matter in the House of Representatives this morning. He explained the nature of the company. As you say, it is just a company with 10 shares—obviously, a family company. He said that it is not trading. He also said, even though he was not obliged to do so, that he relinquished his directorship. The guidelines—and, Senator Faulkner, as you quote them often I presume you have read them—do not prohibit the sale of shares from a private company; they prohibit your dealing with something that might be in conflict with your duties as a minister.

That has not occurred, in this instance. Trading has not occurred and, even though under the guidelines Mr Moore did not have to relinquish his directorship, he voluntarily chose to do so. In other words, Mr Moore has complied with the guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my supplementary question is this: Minister, why does the Prime Minister apply different standards to Senator Short and Senator Gibson than he does to members of the House of Representatives? Why does the Prime Minister readily sacrifice his long-term friends whilst failing to insist that his long-term enemies behave with similar propriety?
—The premise is, of course, invalid. The same set of rules apply to all ministers, and they are applied equally to all ministers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, yesterday you assured the Senate that you had performed all of your statutory duties before approving reefline fishing experiments within protected areas of the Great Barrier Reef. To be precise, your exact words were `I am reasonably confident' and `I think I certainly tried'.

QUESTION.PARA: Today I ask: do you stand by those answers, having had more time to research this issue; and was due process followed? In particular, did you make a decision on designating the proposal, as required under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act; and did you, prior to the question yesterday, write to the Australian Heritage Commission, as required under the act?

Finally, you gave a commitment to the Senate yesterday to provide all the materials; indeed, you said, `I am prepared to provide, obviously, all relevant materials because I believe in transparency in government.' As these are still not available, my staff and I still have not had access to them, can you guarantee that we will have access to them by the end of today's business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a minor communication problem and a little bit of a contest between Democrats at the other end because it was Senator Kernot who wrote to me yesterday and asked for access to the documents and I have written back to her this morning saying that I am looking forward to her staff member coming around, inspecting the file and taking copies of whatever she likes. Furthermore, I said that if she wants documents that are in the possession of GBRMPA, I will do my best to facilitate the production of those documents as well. So you can have whatever you like.
—Don't they talk to one another?

—They both put out press releases yesterday, Senator. What they ignored, of course, was the good science; that is what they ignored. They were so determined that this would be something that would advantage the fishermen that they prejudged it and wrote the press release accordingly—when, in fact, this experiment is to protect the fish. But they do not want that because they thought they could get a cheap political point from the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: But the documents are available for inspection, and I am happy that you do inspect them. What I said yesterday is that I believe I have complied with all the legal requirements. That is still my view. You draw assumptions in your interpretation of the law, I might respectfully suggest, Senator, which are not necessarily correct. In relation to the care that I took as minister to satisfy myself that this experiment was necessary to achieve the conservation objectives of the experiment, I went into some detail of that yesterday. In fact, when the brief was first delivered to me with the request that I agree to this—and I might say that it has been some years in build‐up, this particular experiment—

TALK.START.PARA: —About eight years.

—Eight years, is it? I thought it was about four years in the build‐up—quite a lot of money already as well. I went back to the scientists and asked them to further justify what they were seeking to do.
—How much money?

—You can ask the next question. I went back to the scientists and asked them to further justify the experimentation. It was only after the further information that they provided to me that I was satisfied, in fact, that it was warranted to achieve the conservation goals for which it had been designed.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister. Can I say that I have had—and I checked with Senator Kernot's office a couple of hours ago—no sign of any letter or any contact with your office, but I will go and check again. But I am amazed that you can suggest that we can protect fish in this small amount, some four per cent of the reef that is left protected, by fishing the areas out. I suggest that you talk to other scientists. So I ask, Minister: as well as consulting with GBRMPA, have you consulted with a range of other scientists representing other institutions and different points of view so that you have all the information before you of the scientific need or otherwise to carry out these experiments?

—The scientists were principally from AIMS and CRC in association, I presume, with James Cook University. But it has been interesting that since then scientists from elsewhere have also come out, particularly the one who attacked your press release yesterday, Senator, as being reckless and incorrect in its design, and who said that this is absolutely necessary to enable us to have the information base upon which to make sound decisions to protect the fish of the reef. If you remember, Dr Alan Butler said that, if you do not get the proper information, you will make the wrong decisions. We are seeking the best scientific information in order that we might conserve this very important national resource.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, are you aware of numerous public statements that have been made over the past few months that, if the traditional owners of the land on which the Jabiluka uranium deposit is located do not agree with the proposals by the new owners—ERA—for the mine, the original agreement signed a decade ago will be used for the mine to proceed?
