Have you received contrary written advice from your department that, under the provisions of the Land Rights Act, because of the change of ownership, in fact a new agreement must be negotiated before the Jabiluka mine can proceed?
—Madam President—
—28 March, to be precise.

—I was going to say that when the Aboriginal visitors that I referred to the other day came to see me they, in fact, had a copy of an early advice from my department that made assumptions which were very much in accord with what you have now put to me, Senator. I presume that that is the advice that you are referring to. I have answered the question several times and said that there are difficult issues of law in this matter. You may not understand them, but you are still trying to do your law course, as we know.
—I actually would like the question answered.
—What I am saying is that I am not actually here to give you a lecture in law. I am prepared to do it if you really want me to, but there are legal questions—
—All we can say is that you know more about the law than you know about the environment.
—I am doing a lot better than you did, but that is not all that hard.
—Read the newspapers and see what people are saying.

—The best that you could do was to call on Natalie, and that did not work too well, either. I know of that earlier agreement. The issue as to whether it remains a valid consent in relation to a proposed mine is one that will obviously be interpreted in due course. It is still open to interpretation. It relates, in part, to the issue as to whether the new proposal is that which was referred to in the previous agreement. So there are a number of these legal issues that are yet to be sorted out. As I said in the Senate the other day: even apart from the legal rights and responsibilities in this matter, I believe that the wishes of traditional owners should be respected.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The matter is, as Senator Hill knows, a serious one and did not require the sort of flippant answer that he just gave. To get to the core of that answer, the minister has confirmed that he did receive such written advice from his department, and this was months ago. I now ask: with all the resources that I know are available to him from the Attorney-General's Department or, indeed, any other department he wants to call on, is the minister now satisfied that that advice—which was very explicit—that a new agreement is required is, so far as your department is concerned, Minister, in fact accurate?

—Madam President, on a point of order: standing order 73(1)(j) precludes the asking in questions for a legal opinion. Senator Collins is now asking Senator Hill to give a legal opinion on the obligations relating to whether a new agreement must be entered into or not. The first question is within the standing orders, but the supplementary clearly is not.
—I think that Billy Bobsled ought to go back to standing orders school, Madam President.
—Order! Senator Collins, senators should be addressed in the correct manner, even if it is an aside or interjection.

—Senator Billy Bobsled, then. I know that he does not mind the appellation, Madam President. I was not asking for a legal opinion. I had confirmed by the minister that his department has given such explicit advice. I want to know from the minister: has he sought further advice from the Attorney-General's Department to satisfy himself—
—You didn't ask that. You are rewriting it.

—I will repeat the question, and the Hansard will show that it is the question. I am not looking for Senator Hill's legal advice. Is the minister satisfied that the advice provided to him by his department is correct? Or is it wrong?

—There is certainly no provision in question time for asking for a legal opinion, and Senator Hill should not presume to answer in that fashion but otherwise may answer the question that has been asked.
—We wouldn't get one off Senator Hill anyway. He got his degree in a weeties packet.
—And he knows it.
—It is better than being a bookie's clerk, anyway.
—Is that a problem in your arrogant world, Minister?

—You said that it was a serious question; give us a chance at answering it. The answer is that it depends on what consent is ultimately sought. That is what you do not seem to appreciate. When that consent is ultimately sought—if it is sought—this question of law would have to be addressed. I remind you, Senator, that that is not for me to decide. It is for me to decide what level of environmental assessment is necessary, and that is what I have done. Secondly, I have gone beyond that and have also, as you know, enabled a social and cultural impact study to be prepared which will give us further information, I hope, for the benefit of the Aboriginal people in that particular area.
—Is your department right or wrong?
—I have just answered that question—it depends on what consent is ultimately sought. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and Minister representing the Prime Minister. On Tuesday, in response to a question from Senator Lees, and today, in response to a question from Senator Bob Collins about uranium mining in relation to Jabiluka, you again indicated, while confusing the issues with the outcome of the Ranger social impact study, that you `think the rights of traditional owners in these matters clearly should be respected'.

QUESTION.PARA: I am aware, Minister, that at 7.00 p.m. on Tuesday night you did, indeed, meet with the senior traditional owner of the Mirrar people, Yvonne Margarula, and that she was very clear in her opposition to mining at Jabiluka. Will you now concede that the Jabiluka proposal can go no further, or will the social impact study be used as a means for the proponent, ERA, and the government to direct the local community to cope with yet another fait accompli? If so, following Senator Collins's question, what is your legal basis? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —She said that she was totally opposed to the mine. That is the first point. The second point relates to the purpose of the social and cultural impact study. That was a study requested by the Northern Land Council on behalf of the Aboriginal community because they were concerned about the consequences of development, tourism and mining upon the local Aboriginal people. We have facilitated the development of that. It has not been easy. We have determined terms of reference. We have determined a method of gathering the information and analysis of the information which is acceptable to the Aboriginal people. We have supported the funding of it, and that study is now taking place.

ANSWER.PARA: I am hopeful, as I believe they are hopeful, that it will provide a resource base that can help us better understand the consequences upon these people of the very rapid development that is taking place in that area in orther that public policy decisions in the future might better respect them in terms of their traditional cultures and ways of life, yet are consistent with what they aspire for for their children, which is education, jobs, et cetera—like all other Australians.

That is what that is about. It is not designed in any way to be any lever towards further development in the area. That is a separate issue. To the extent that they may be concerned that it is used in that way, I can assure them that it was not the purpose, as they know, because it was the Aboriginal people who asked for the study. I will do my best to ensure that it is not used in that way either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I did ask whether the decision—
—That is not a point of order. It is a supplementary question.
—No. The minister has not answered the question.
—Order!
—I stand on the point of order that Senator Hill did not answer my question.
—What standing order is that?
—What standing order do you want her to use, smart arse?
—Order! Senator Faulkner and Senator Campbell, do not interject.

—I am standing on a point of order to ask Senator Hill to answer the question in relation to whether or not he listened to the senior traditional owner and whether or not that means the mine will not go ahead. That was my question.

—My understanding was that Senator Hill had sat down. I accept, Senator, that he may not have answered the question as you wanted it answered. You may ask a supplementary question to follow-up the answer that he gave.

—On many occasions I have heard people asking somebody to answer the question. Senator Hill answered part of the question but not the whole question. Senator, please answer the question specifically. My supplementary question is: when the senior traditional owner has said no quite clearly, does this not mean that the mine does not go ahead? If your answer is that there are still other considerations to be taken into account, what does that mean for the 18 new uranium mines on your list of prospective mines? In particular, what does that mean for the eight in Western Australia, which seems to have won the lottery and got more than anyone else? What does this mean in terms of shoddy process for Aboriginal populations, for the environment in the future, if, when somebody says no, Senator, they do not mean yes?
—Try to answer that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do my best. Firstly, in your point of order you asked whether I listened. The answer is yes. Secondly, you repeated in your supplementary question: does that mean that the mine will not go ahead? That is not for me to say. My job is to give advice as a result of the environmental impact study. I will do that. As I have said, this mine will have to meet the highest environmental standards before I will give advice that it should go ahead on environmental grounds.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the mysterious 18 new uranium mines—which I read about as a revelation in the Financial Review—they were in a submission that was made to the Senate Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling, which took that list out of public documents. They are 18 mines that have been speculated about over years past, and it means no more than that. So it has no relevance to any particular mine at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, are you aware that the Victorian government intends to close a further 113 schools—two-thirds of which are in Labor electorates—despite the fact that only one-third of the seats in Victoria are held by Labor? Given that the federal government funds education in Victoria to the tune of $854 million this financial year, will the federal government ensure that the political bias by Mr Gude is brought to account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Collins, for that question. No, I was not aware that, in the distribution of any schools to be closed in Victoria, two-thirds were in Labor electorates, as you assert they are. I do not deny that they are, but I do not agree that they are either. I simply do not have that information to hand.

ANSWER.PARA: When you identify for yourself that apparently Labor holds only one-third of the electorates in Victoria—there may be good reason for that, of course—I gather the inference you are making, Senator, is that the Victorian government has used a Ros Kelly whiteboard. That is what you are suggesting. I do not assume for one minute that that is the case. I will make some inquiries as to the distribution of school closures in Victoria. If I have anything to add, I will come back and tell you.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to my colleague Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to a number of reports in the press recently which have commented on the government's proposed mechanism for administering the high income earners surcharge on superannuation contributions. I ask: can the minister explain why the government is proceeding with its announced policy on the high income earners surcharge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for this question. He has a longstanding interest in this area, and I certainly welcome the question from him and the interest that he is showing.

ANSWER.PARA: The major initiative by the government is about correcting the inequity of the Labor model. The high income earner contribution surcharge will make the superannuation system more equitable for all Australians while ensuring that superannuation remains an attractive savings option. I welcome Senator Conroy's announcement in the press today—thank you, Senator—when he said categorically that Labor supports the high income surcharge initiative.

He could not imagine the party changing its position. I thank Senator Conroy for that endorsement. He also went on to say in his remarks—and I think I am quoting him correctly—that the ALP was not exactly innocent itself, making many changes while in office from 1983 to 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not actually what I said.

—I think you were quoted as saying that in the press this morning. We welcome the analysis that he is showing. I went to some lengths in my speech to the ASFA national conference to address the surcharge issue and in particular to explain why the government would not change its broad approach to the collection announced in the budget. For the information of honourable senators, a key reason for this decision is that the alternative approach favoured by the superannuation industry would represent a substantial increase in the compliance costs of small business. Unlike Labor, this government has a commitment to reduce compliance costs to small business .
—What about your commitment not to introduce new taxes?

—Senator Sherry has just called out. I do not know whether he took the model he proposed through caucus or got the approval of Mr Beazley. But I wonder whether you explained to him when you decided to put that option forward that this would involve very heavy compliance costs for small business in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has always acknowledged that the implementation of the surcharge will involve costs and there has been no debate on that issue. We have consulted widely to ensure the lowest cost option would be implemented. We believe that these costs are minor compared with the benefits which flow from a fairer and more equitable superannuation system. The government believes the overall community compliance cost of reporting will be higher under the alternatives which transfer reporting obligations to employers.

There is nothing simple or cost effective about the alternative proposals which have been favoured by the superannuation funds. The preferred fund option would lead to yet further imposts on employers and small business. As noted in my speech, employers will be required to modify their current payroll systems. Many people in small business would be required to replace off the shelf payroll software packages and, of course, the 1996‐97 group certificates which have already been distributed to employers would need to be replaced.

Even under this alternative approach, superannuation funds would still be involved in the surcharge process. What the government is doing is engaging in extensive consultation to ensure the announced mechanism is introduced in as efficient, as equitable and as cost effective manner as possible. A joint ATO‐ISC industry implementation advisory group has been established for this purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response, for his concerns about high compliance costs, and I ask: can the minister further comment on the attitude of sections of the superannuation industry to the government's proposed mechanism for collecting the surcharge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have announced, the government is committed to the approach which was outlined in my speech to ASFA and sections of the industry should now accept this reality and focus on how to implement this approach in as cost effective manner as possible. Susan Ryan, who is well known to this parliament, has said on a number of occasions that she accepts the right of governments to govern. I look forward to ASFA making a positive contribution to the implementation of the option which we have now announced.

ANSWER.PARA: As part of these consultations, to ensure that the collection mechanism is introduced in the most cost effective manner possible, I will be meeting with Susan Ryan and other representatives of ASFA this afternoon. We will be discussing matters associated with the government's announced collection method. While there will be some costs associated with the introduction of the surcharge, there are also potential benefits for superannuation funds. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Are we correct in inferring from your answer to a question without notice from Senator Carr yesterday that the setting of quotas for government funded undergraduate student places is simply a matter of ministerial discretion? If this is the case, what is there to prevent your successors from succumbing to the ever increasing pressure from universities to make up the shortfall caused by your government's cuts by selling off more places? Have you briefed Dr Kemp on the guidelines you have decided to adopt? After the reshuffle when he is sent in to clean up the mess you have created, what is there to stop him changing your quota to only 70 per cent or 60 per cent of the total places in each course?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hogg for his question for two reasons. Firstly it gives me an opportunity to repeat what was indicated yesterday. Since there seems to be a pattern in this place of questions either being asked in the other place and then here, or being asked here and then again the next day, let me spell it out for you. Basically what you assert is that the conditions in relation to the sale of places to full fee paying Australian students will be in the guidelines, and that is correct; and the guidelines are not subject to disallowance, and that is correct.

ANSWER.PARA: That is exactly the same situation as is the case for the fees and regulations covering the sale to Australian postgraduate students, as established by previous Labor governments. That is the first aspect of the question that I choose to deal with. The second is your assertion yet again about our cuts to higher education and that does give me the opportunity to repeat it for you yet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —$1.8 billion worth.

—Senator Carr is interjecting and saying $1.8 billion. He just cannot face the truth. Universities are not being cut by $1.8 billion and he knows it, but he comes in here and he misleads every day. He has been told before there will be more increases in undergraduate places—5,000 more undergraduate students. Last time he was told that he took the opportunity to say that it was untrue. I notice he is not doing it today, probably because he recognises that it is true. He has finally caught up with the facts, I suppose. I do notice that he has not come in here and corrected the record, despite the fact that he comes in here week after week and interjects lies and mistruths into this place. He does not bother to come in and correct the record.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me repeat it for you again. Something like $680 million over four years will be coming out of university funding compared to something like $20 billion worth of funding being put in over that time. The savings that the government is making with respect to higher education are coming by asking for a higher contribution from students. That is, the people who get the benefit of going into higher education are the ones who are going to have to make a higher contribution. The contribution they are going to have to make is higher simply because they enjoy half the unemployment rate, higher incomes and a better pattern of employment for the rest of their lives. They are not asked to pay as they learn; they are asked to pay as they earn. They do not even have to pay a cracker under our system until they are earning $20,700, and even then it will only be about $12 a week.

So, in summary, Senator Hogg, the proposals that we have put forward for the reform of higher education are of great benefit to universities and of great benefit to students. The reasons are simply that the cuts to universities are very small. The total government funding per student remains effectively the same. If you judge quality by the dollars per student, there is no drop in quality for that reason. But if you accept that quality can be improved by increased competition, allowing Australian students to buy places, once the government‐funded places have all been filled, will give another injection of competition between Australian universities to repeat the sort of injection of competition when you allowed international students to come and buy places here. We will also return the HECS contribution from overloaded students, which will be of great benefit to universities who have got some unused space. Those sorts of things will increase the quality of delivery of higher education for Australian students. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question to Senator Vanstone. You failed to address the issue that I raised about your briefing Dr Kemp on this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —It may come as a bit of a surprise to you, Senator Hogg, but I am actually responsible for this area. Perhaps you have not read the administrative orders. I do not know whether you have got any spare reading time, but I could send them round for you if you like and you can have a good look. If you are interested in the discussions that I have with Dr Kemp, I meet with him regularly. I met with him this morning. He gets most of the briefings that I get and I get most of the ones that he gets. Have we discussed this matter? Yes.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, on 10 September the Senate disallowed Austudy regulations and reinstated the dependent spouse allowance which is paid to students who have a dependent spouses or at least one dependent child. More than seven weeks later this allowance has not been paid, nor have students been told that they are eligible to apply, and some students who have tried to claim the allowance have been turned away from the department. Minister, why has the dependent spouse allowance not been paid? Does it have anything to do with the claims that it has been removed from the DEETYA computer and that it cannot be reinstalled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of that claim having been made. I will investigate that claim and get to the bottom of what the problem is. The disallowance of those regulations, however, does of course raise another matter, and that is the inadvertent disallowance of a range of other Austudy benefits to students in drought affected areas that was not mentioned in the debate. In the keenness of yourselves to dispose of this area, you disposed of a whole lot of other things as well, so determined were you to proceed.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not recall, Senator, hearing you comment about whether you regret that and what you would do now when new regulations are brought forward, as they will be. You will have the opportunity, of course, to say whether you will support the remainder of the regulations that were inadvertently disallowed when they are brought forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, will you give an undertaking that you will look into this matter? Will you tell us now when these struggling families will be paid, and will you give consideration to allowing those people who are eligible to claim dependent spouse allowance to lodge retrospective applications? Will they be allowed to get retrospective payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have already indicated to you in response to your first question—I do not know if you were listening—that I was not aware of the claim, that I would investigate it and that I would get to the bottom of it and come back. As to the question of payments, let me look at the question of whether people who have not yet applied would also get retrospective payments from the day the regulations were disallowed. People who have made an application would be in a different situation from people who have not yet made an application, so I will happily look into the detail of that as well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, are you aware that on 19 July in Townsville the Prime Minister, at a dinner for coalition supporters, said:

QUESTION.PARA: We took a decision in relation to a development at Port Hinchinbrook a couple of weeks ago.
`We took.' Also in relation to the Port Hinchinbrook project, he said:
What the development of this country is all about is encouraging risk‐taking in private sector development.

Given concerns expressed by the Heritage Commission, the World Heritage Unit and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, is it not up to you, as Minister for the Environment, to be discouraging risk taking when it comes to developments such as Port Hinchinbrook and applying precautionary principles?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we should act in a precautionary way, but yes, we should also encourage economic development. The different with this government is that we are prepared to work to achieve both goals. We want to see economic development and we want to see jobs, but we want to see such development conducted in an environmentally responsible way. I guess that is the difference. Your trouble was that you gave us a million unemployed. Your recipe was a disastrous failure. We believe that by sound judgment and being prepared to take hard decisions, both objectives can be achieved, and that is the way in which we will operate.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, why does the Prime Minister state `we took a decision' when the decision under the World Heritage Act is solely up to you and you have told us that the decision was taken by you and you alone?

—Madam President, Senator Faulkner asked me that question in 245 different ways at the estimates committee and my answer remains the same: I made the decisions that I was obliged to make under the relevant legislation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, yesterday mention was made of the new government shopfront for the provision of income support for Australians. Could you please inform the Senate as to the progress of this important initiative, which will be of enormous benefit to those in need, and advise the Senate as to why the Community and Public Sector Union is threatening strike action? Could it have anything to do with the possibility that they have a union election around the corner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —How perspicacious of you, Senator Knowles. One does wonder whether the union is desperately trying to find a leadership issue on which to base an elec tion campaign for itself. To put such an important project in jeopardy is very sad. My department—together with Senator Vanstone's department—has established a joint working party that has been addressing the major issues in regard to implementing the new shopfront agency. I am advised by my department that they have received some very positive feedback on the initiative from staff from all over the network. I myself have visited Social Security regional offices around five states and, on the whole—in fact, entirely—in talking to me they have expressed considerable interest in the project because my staff realise that the better the service that goes to the customers, the less distressed the customers are when they actually receive attention from the staff, the less aggression there is and, therefore, a very much better working environment for the staff.

ANSWER.PARA: Government assistance through this measure is going to be a great deal more accessible to busy Australians. The new agency is going to have a charter and will have guaranteed standards of service. The public sector will provide a level of service equal to or better than the private sector. It will reduce the complexity which constituents find when they go to receive help and will avoid the waste of time that they currently experience, having to provide the same information to the two departments.

We are now seeking to find a chief executive who has the necessary skills, expertise and experience for such an important position. There will be something like 20,000 public servants and something like $40 billion worth of expenditure. It is a big job for a very capable man or woman. The Remuneration Tribunal will be consulted on the salary that will be payable.

Sadly, the Community and Public Sector Union has arranged meetings of the staff to consider the government's reforms and, as I have mentioned, these will lead to improvements in service delivery, not reductions as are being suggested by the CPSU. At this stage, it is uncertain how many staff are involved in these meetings, which are still proceeding. As I said, the discussions which I personally and the senior officers of my department have had with staff in regional offices about the agency and the benefits it will provide to the community and staff have been very positive.

I have personally responded to the CPSU about their general concerns and I now understand that they finally agreed to meet with my department to discuss the initiative. The government has offered consultations to the CPSU on the agency and I am glad that they have now agreed to take up the offer. It is unfortunate, however, that they are pursuing industrial action before they are fully informed of the measure and before they fully appreciate the benefits to their members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senators Bob Collins and Margetts today, relating to the Jabiluka uranium mine.

Madam President, I did not hear anything from the minister to indicate that he disputed that the senior traditional owner of the Mirrar people has the authority to make a decision in this regard. The reason the minister did not say that is that he knows that the senior traditional owner, Yvonne Margarula, has the authority to make that decision for the Mirrar people.

There are parallels here in relation to situations where judges make decisions on whether or not, when a woman says no, they mean no or really mean yes. In this particular case, it could not have been clearer what the response was from the senior traditional owner. If that is the case, then the legalities of that become extremely important. The situation with social impact studies is that over time—and even the Northern Land Council are very concerned about this issue—social impact studies have been used by government and proponents to be the vehicle for managing an issue.

BREAK.PARA: The Northern Land Council, in their submission to the uranium inquiry, indicated very clearly that that is their concern. They want to make sure that there is a real commitment in any social impact study so that the views of the people in the Jabiru region are taken fully into consideration. They do not want yet another report done on them. They certainly do not want a report which is a vehicle for a proponent for a later attack.

The interesting thing is that the minister is not committing himself to whether or not he accepts the decision of the senior traditional owner, yet the company does. In a letter to the Northern Land Council, the ERA has said `the company accepts with disappointment your decision'. So the company has accepted that decision. They accept the authority by which that decision is made. The minister is not yet admitting that same authority. He has spoken to the senior traditional owner. He knows that there is no lack of clarity in that decision. To continue without admitting that is a breach of proper process. That whole lack of proper process has been very obvious all through the latest issues with regard to any additional moves for uranium mining by this current government.

The current new mine at Ranger‐3 did not go through with the proper environmental impact statement. There may well have been blame on the previous government for giving that approval, but it did not go through with the proper environmental impact statement. This proposal at Jabiluka is not the same proposal that it was before—it is not the same company—and therefore it cannot go ahead without the proper approval process. If the minister in any way thinks that is the case, we have to wonder about anything that the minister has said in relation to uranium mining. He has always set the highest levels of environmental standards, but so far all we have seen is shoddy process. So far he has only said that the views will be taken into consideration.

What we need to know from the minister right away for the benefit of people who are having their poverty used against them instead of having those things addressed separately from uranium mining is to make sure that the minister understands that no means no and find out what his government is going to do in response to relieving that concern and pressure that they are feeling at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this issue. The Mirrar people have made their wishes abundantly clear. Through Yvonne Margarula, who spent time this week speaking with many of us in this place, including the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), their wishes are very clear. They are united. There is no dissent among the people who own that country.

SPEECH.PARA: The support goes further than just this particular group of traditional owners. It includes other traditional owners in the area who will also have foisted upon them many of the other impacts that will come from mining. Listening to the people who are promoting this mine as of great benefit to Aboriginal people, the only reasons they give are reasons that relate to the provision of basic services—services that the territory government or the federal government should be providing for them. Why should people be forced to see their land destroyed and their land mined in order to get basic health services? Why should people be forced to agree to mining in order to get decent housing? Now I hear a Northern Territory government minister suggesting that they have to have their land mined in order to improve the educational opportunities for their children. What has happened to the Northern Territory government and its responsibility to these people?

When I was able to visit this part of the country earlier this year I was appalled at the quality of housing that many of these people have to endure. I could find very few benefits flowingd to the community other than some of those benefits provided by way of tourism facilities that will earn an ongoing income for these people. In terms of actual benefits, they are very few and far between. Indeed, if you look at the amount of money earned by the company and the small amount of money that has found its way back into the hands of the local Aboriginal people, it has been minute, to say the least.

People ask, `If they are going to get economic benefits, why on earth do these people not want their land mined? Surely they can put up with some of their land being mined and get the benefits that flow from it.' In speaking to people, both during my trip to Kakadu and also here, there is a vast number of reasons. Firstly, it relates to wanting to protect their land for environmental reasons, in particular. They do not want further intrusions onto their land. They want to protect their culture. They do not like what they see happening, thanks to the mine that is already there, and they do not want any further intrusions into their way of life.

These people believe that the first mine was forced upon those who were speaking for the traditional owners at that stage. They were left with virtually no option but to agree to the mine going ahead. Many of the undertakings that were given then, particularly the undertaking that Aboriginal people will continue to have a direct say in what was happening to their land, have never been fulfilled. In particular, they talk about the lack of contact with the Office of the Supervising Scientist and their inability to get briefings on particular issues, such as the discharge of contaminated water. They had to resort to court action about 18 months ago to stop a release of contaminated water onto their land. Yet they were promised that this simply would not happen, that they would be consulted on an ongoing basis, that they would be kept up‐to‐date with what was happening and that they would have free access to data that related to the environmental impact of mining.

When you look through the many problems that this mine has caused for the traditional owners, you can well understand their objections. Hopefully, this government will not only listen, as the minister has promised to do, but will actually take notice of what they are saying and act in accordance with the wishes of the traditional owners. There is not just a legal obligation to do so; there is surely a moral obligation on us to listen to the traditional owners. Many of the traditional owners are concerned that this government may be planning to attempt to circumvent the law, change the law and find other ways of forcing—as they feel that their forebears were forced—the traditional owners to put up with this mine.

Only time will really tell whether or not this government is going to stand by its current legal obligations and the moral obligation we all have to listen to the traditional owners and to protect this very special part of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it appropriate to rise and make a few comments in this debate because I was one of the senators involved in the references committee that visited Kakadu National Park and a number of other sites in recent times. As all senators know, significant contributions were made from a range of Aboriginal groups to that inquiry, both publicly on the record and, on a number of occasions, privately during the afternoon and after hours. The information we gained was most useful. It was certainly most useful to me as I have had little exposure to this issue and to the problems that the Aboriginal people face in those communities.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it appropriate to put on the record my preliminary observations as this debate goes on and before we trundle off to a range of other sites in the next two or three months. I must admit that the clear impression that I got was that the Byzantine world of Aboriginal politics equals that of the trade union movement. For every 17 persons, there are 18 different perspectives and different views and there appears to be no unanimity and no cohesion in those. I suppose it is no different in that respect from any other organised grouping in our society.

I must say that the firm impression that I gained after hearing submissions from a range of Aboriginal groups and their representatives from the Northern Land Council and others is that there is no unity of view. What was conceded both privately and publicly on the record in Hansard is that there has been a range of developments in that area that have occurred by and large against the will of a range of Aboriginal communities.

BREAK.PARA: Nonetheless, it has occurred in the past and further development is almost inevitable. The groups expressed the view that they were opposed to economic development, to European development, to tourism development, to mining development, to uranium mining development and to any other form of metal mining. But the clear impression that I did not gain was that they were opposed to uranium mining per se, and that was clear from specific comments they made both privately and publicly. They had been opposed to the development and they wished it to cease. However, they also recognised both publicly and privately that the development would occur; and hence their appropriate response, as expressed by the leadership of the Northern Land Council, both in the press and to us privately, was for a range of negotiations to be entered into and concluded relatively quickly so that some of the financial benefits that might be available could be distributed to the Aboriginal people and the Aboriginal communities in those areas.

They did not want development but it had occurred and it would continue to occur. Their primary position, as expressed by their leadership and my understanding from reviewing the transcript in recent days, is that their best interests were advanced by entering into the negotiating process to gain some benefits for these people. There is nothing remarkable about that particular conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —They said the same about Coronation Hill.

—I do not know. We did not discuss Coronation Hill. We certainly did discuss Ranger and Jabiru. In respect of the services that are provided or not provided by the Northern Territory government, in my view there were quite legitimate criticisms made as to the lack of education services, the lack of schooling and the lack of support mechanisms provided to a large range of other communities in those not so heavily populated areas.

BREAK.PARA: Indeed, it was remarkable to me that the Northern Territory government has not taken steps to ensure that young Aboriginal children attend schools and education institutions and receive some benefits. Although I do not come to this conclusion finally, it appears to be the position of the Northern Territory government that a lot of services that we take for granted in traditional urban areas—particularly schools and the like—are not provided almost as a policy measure because some of the Aboriginal communities receive a form of royalty spread over many years in exchange for allowing development of mines and other things on their land sites. I thought it best to put on the record, from my impressions from that committee to date, that there was no widespread or unanimous—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop made the point that the Aboriginal owners do not want development in their land. He went on to say that they were not concerned about uranium mining per se. I got the exact opposite message in speaking to traditional owners when I was at Kakadu in April this year. Senator Bishop then went on to say that, seeing development is going to occur, we then have to look at the best way in which that can be levied in the interests of the Aboriginal people. There is a loss of logic there. The best interest of the Aboriginal people is for the uranium mine not to go ahead. That is what they want. That is what they made clear to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) in this parliament just the night before last.

SPEECH.PARA: In the minister's answer today, he said two things. Firstly, he said, `If that was the wish of the Aboriginal people, their wish should be adhered to.' Secondly, he said, `However, we are going on with a whole range of other processes and investigations with a view to having a uranium mine.' There is an inherent inconsistency there and all the alarm bells are ringing. If the minister is going to be honest and straight on this matter, he would be saying that he has now heard the Mirrar people, that he knows clearly from their leaders that this mine is against their wishes and, because he stands for them as the arbiters of this matter, that is the end of it. What is the point of proceeding further down the line?

BREAK.PARA: The minister is trying to dupe not only the Senate but, far more importantly, the people who are involved. We can draw only that conclusion because on the one hand he is saying that he will respect their wishes but on the other hand he is hell-bent on getting around their wishes. What an invidious position to put these people in. At least, it shows a complete inability to understand the anxiety they have. They feel they got rolled in the establishment of the Ranger uranium mine. They know they were deceived by the promises of the goods and the largesse and the improvements in their life that were going to come out of that. They wish that mine had not gone ahead.

Now we look at Jabiluka. The people involved there know that it is against their interests. They have had the trial run. They have seen the broken promises. They have seen the broken land. They have seen the broken hearts. They have seen the broken lives. Yet we have a minister saying that he will abide by their wishes: `I know you don't want to go ahead, but I am proceeding anyway.' That is what he is doing. He is proceeding with a series of moves aimed at forcing this mine on that land against the wishes of those owners. It is duplicitous, it is dishonest and it is disgusting.

The minister ought to be ashamed of himself for the way in which he is misleading not only those people. The intent of this government is to foist that mine on them, regardless of their wishes. It is going to be a case of this nation standing with that small group of all mightily important people, their land and their wishes as the government proceeds down that line.

This issue will escalate because this minister is hell-bent on escalating it. He is not going to stick with his word. If he were, he would accept the situation now. He would save the further expenditure. More particularly, he would save further heartache for these people. It is a deplorable process that he and his government are engaged in. At least the people of Jabiluka have come here and told him what they think. It will be to his eternal discredit if he continues down this road of perfidy as far as their interests are concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the order of the Senate of 31 October 1996, adopting the Selection of Bills Committee report No. 13, be varied as follows:
The Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill 1996 not be referred to a committee.
I move this motion at the request of the Australian Democrats' whip, who originally requested the referral of the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

I seek leave to give notice of a motion relating to the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the Senate approves the proposal by the National Gallery of Australia to construct an extension to the existing Gallery in Parkes, Australian Capital Territory, for the purpose of conducting temporary exhibitions.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received letters from party leaders requesting variation to the membership of committees.

INTERJECT.PARA: That senators be discharged from and appointed to committees as follows:

PARA.TAB: Discharged: Senator Forshaw
Discharged: Senators Crane and Forshaw
