DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the bill as a whole and government‐Democrat amendments 1 to 7 to schedule 1. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to read the sheet of paper I gave to Senator Campbell before the luncheon break. It is the address of the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to the Young Liberal movement on 8 January 1996.
—A great organisation.
—I understand you were a previous office holder. He said:

BREAK.PARA: It has never been our policy to cut wages. We stand for better pay for better work.
Under a Howard Government you cannot be worse off but you can be better off.
I give this rock solid guarantee. Our policy will not cut your take-home pay.
Employees will be given the choice to remain with the current award system, or a Certified Agreement, or enter into a workplace agreement.
Another quote is from a statement addressed to the Freight Congress on 6 October 1995. I think my colleague Senator Bishop referred to this statement this morning. The Prime Minister said:
No worker in Australia under the Howard industrial relations policy can have his or her award conditions taken away.
My question to Senator Campbell is: will he confirm that these are statements from the Prime Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the bit of paper. I thank Senator Sherry for providing it to me. I believe Senator Sherry is an honourable gentleman. If he says that they are accurate extracts from speeches by the Prime Minister I would take his word for that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did give Senator Campbell a copy of these quotes from the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, just before the luncheon adjournment in the belief that he would be able to validate that they are direct quotes from the Prime Minister. Let me quote the Prime Minister again. He said, `It has never been our policy to cut wages. We stand for better pay for better work'—and I do emphasise quite deliberately the words `better pay for better work'. Given the Prime Minister has enunciated this principle and objective, why don't we have this objective in the bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see that the opposition supports John Howard's policy on industrial relations as stated in the quote, Senator Sherry. As Senator Sherry well knows—and there is thunderous agreement in most respects on this clause; that is why it is interesting that it has taken in excess of five hours to get to this stage—almost all of the terms of your proposed amendment to the objects section are in line with ours with just a couple of exceptions.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, I have answered the question about better pay. We have indicated in the objects the words `improved living standards'. That is a more thorough measure of the object of increasing living standards for Australians across the nation than something as described by yourselves in your amendment as `better pay'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might indicate to the chamber that it is best to refer to the Prime Minister as Mr Howard rather than John Howard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly not on first name terms with the Prime Minister. I know Senator Vanstone referred to him as `sport' the other day. I am not sure what sort of first name reference that was. I am not sure what the Prime Minister's reaction to that would have been.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell, I do not treat your analysis of our amendments in this schedule as lightly as you appear to do. There are some very critical and important differences that we are making in our amendments. The Prime Minister has used the term `better pay'—a very strong pledge. I would be interested to know whether you categorically stand by the Prime Minister's pledge of `better pay for better work'. I submit again: why not adopt, as we have, the Prime Minister's pledge in the objectives of this act?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given the answer to that question.
—You didn't respond to my first question which was: do you stand by the pledges of the Prime Minister in respect of this issue of better pay?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation has been before the opposition and all senators for many months now. It has been the subject of a long inquiry. The government believes that its election commitments are reflected in this legislation and that is what we are here to debate. That is the answer to your question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not answered my question, Senator. I am asking you: do you stand by the Prime Minister's pledge of better pay for better work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently the question goes unanswered. Let me shorthand the real objective of the legislation to this: it is a means of promoting the economic fundamentalist viewpoint that the law of the jungle should prevail and that as few impediments as possible should be put in the way of those who have and those who are rich to improve their situation and let those who have not, those who are poor, those who are vulnerable and those who are unprotected fend for themselves as best they can. Let the devil take the hindmost.

SPEECH.PARA: It is salient to look at some of the quotes from the national press on this industrial relations legislation which we are debating here today, following the announcements over the weekend by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) of their final agreement coming out of some 50 hours of discussions behind closed doors and two months of discussions in which the public just did not know what was going on. In the Australian Financial Review we have an analysis by Stephen Long, which says:
In the wash up, with the spin‐doctors gone, business has emerged as the big winners from Peter Reith and Cheryl Kernot's IR compromise. And business groups scored a clear points victory in lobbying
Amendments Ms Kernot sold as employee protection were actively lobbied for by business . . .

Business has had a hands down win over the interests of the employees in this country. Those with the power have had that increased at the expense of those without the power. Sure, the gloss can be put on it. Sure, it was great to announce this over the weekend without warning or proper analysis being able to be applied before the media had been fed what the Democrats and the government wanted them to be fed. But it has not hoodwinked everybody.
The objectives of the bill might be seen better by some of the other comments. For example, Alan Wood in the Australian said:
Given its history, the latest version of the Bill is better than Reith expected to get, although he cannot afford to say so because he still needs Kernot's co‐operation to get it through.
In other words, Kernot was fooled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kernot.
—Yes. I must not shorthand in the way the media does.
—Well, not here.
—You are absolutely right. Thank you for calling me up on that. In other words, Senator Kernot was fooled by the charm, the wit and the ability to negotiate of Mr Reith.
—I wouldn't call it that—charm and wit!

—I read that in the papers—that he had some degree of it, and I do take in some of the things that I read in the papers. I do not know whether it said wit, but it did say charm. Clive Mathieson said in the Australian on 28 October:

SPEECH.PARA: Economists have lauded the prospect of an amicable Senate reception to the Workplace Relations Bill . . .
Economists said Friday's agreement between the Federal Government and the Australian Democrats appeared to retain the thrust of the original Bill . . .

He might have said `the prospect of an amicable Senate reception from the government and Democrat benches', but I doubt it is going to come from elsewhere. This is not amicable legislation. This is legislation which is going to make vulnerable workers in workplaces around this country very clearly disadvantaged. There is nothing amicable or lovable in this legislation for those people.
Katharine Murphy in the Australian Financial Review on the same day said:

Re‐inserting tough secondary boycott provisions into the Trade Practices Act, with no caps on damages which could be awarded against unions—but allowing consumer and environmental boycotts to be exempted.
She went on to say:
This involved a significant concession on the Democrat side, as the party's pre election policy opposed the restoration of sections 45D and E of the act.
In other words, the Democrats broke their pre-election policy to make this major concession on secondary boycotts.

I have been talking with representatives of the Maritime Union of Australia today and the consequences of simply that concession by the Democrats are enormous for many people who would otherwise have protection under the law in Australia. One of those of course will be what has become known as the `ships of shame'.

In Australia at the moment we have one of the best situations in the world for helping people who cannot help themselves. For example, sometimes ships sail into our ports under flags of convenience and seafarers on those ships are living in deplorable conditions. Sometimes they have not been paid for 12 months. They cannot get off the ship because they would lose all that pay anyway. They cannot argue with the ship's captain or the owners because it is well known that some of them at least have been thrown overboard during the night for doing so. They cannot stand for themselves. But once they enter our waters the maritime unions come to their assistance and those ships do not leave here until, at least, the conditions are improved to acceptable standards and until, at least, the sailors have been paid their fair pay for the work they have done.

Australian ports are welcoming to those people—but not after this legislation, because the prime ability of the unions to be able to boycott those ships and their commerce is being taken away by this legislation. They will be under threat of fines of up to three‐quarters of a million dollars for taking action. They lose that power. It means that those ships coming into Australian waters are going to be doing so with little less inhibition on the mistreatment of their workers than they have elsewhere in the world. We are going backwards in that regard.

I will have quite a bit more to say on that issue when we get to the relevant section in the legislation. As far as the objectives of this bill are concerned, why can't we call a spade a spade? Why can't we say this bill aims to make it easier for the employers in this country—particularly those with power and a bank of silks, a bank of barristers, behind them—to advance their position as against those employees who might be without tertiary education, who might not have their first language as English and who might be isolated in their workplace but who know there might be 12 other people in a queue at the door to take their job if they complain or try to get their rights as they have been able to through union representation in the past?

This is a bill whose objective—whether its architects know it or not—is to further divide this country of ours. It is a bill which deserves no amicable reception in this place. It is a bill which ought to be rejected by the Senate, and, if it were not for the Democrats, would be rejected by the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like Senator Campbell to give a response to this particular matter of ships of shame. As I understand it—and his advisers are here and I would like a response—the MUA has very actively taken up the issue of seafarers who are being ripped off, and I do not use that term in too strong a sense. Many international seafarers are ripped off, and we should be proud of what the MUA has been doing.

BREAK.PARA: The MUA, through various forms of industrial action, has very successfully ensured that where seafarers have been very clearly underpaid—and I have to say the pay is pretty miserable on some of these international vessels—they are paid back pay. I understand there are actually cases on record regarding seafarers and their failure to repay the back pay when they return to their particular country, whether they return on the vessel they arrived on or are flown back for whatever reason.

If they do not repay the back pay the MUA has successfully pursued and gained for the seafarers who have been disadvantaged, who have been oppressed—and I do not often use the term `oppressed' in industrial relations—in some cases they end up in prison. Certainly, they end up without a job, but they can end up in prison.

I would like Senator Campbell to indicate, or get some sort of indication from his advisers, whether the government endorses this sort of approach by international seafaring companies. In what areas, with respect to our international objectives, will action be taken by the government to ensure this sort of behaviour does not go on?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the government does not endorse that sort of activity. The question that Senator Sherry has raised is an important one. However, it does not relate to the objects of the act. I am happy to provide a detailed response to the question when the relevant schedule is debated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to note that you are not happy and the government does not endorse this sort of approach. We will certainly take this matter up with respect to the 45D and 45E provisions. Senator Murray is back in the chamber for this debate and, with respect to the seafaring example I have just given, I think he should really rethink the Democrats' position with respect to these international seafarers. There are other examples, but this is a very good bad example of the sorts of international practises that are transferred into this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Given Senator Campbell's indication on behalf of the government that he does not condone this sort of behaviour, I would certainly welcome at least Senator Murray's review later when we get to the particular provision and Senator Campbell's reconsideration of this matter to ensure that organisations like the MUA can pursue justice on behalf of international seafarers who visit this country. I strongly urge Senator Murray to rethink the matter.

Before I forget, Senator Campbell, I gave you an opportunity earlier to endorse the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard): `We stand for better pay for better work.' You sat silent. I will give you one more opportunity to endorse the Prime Minister's remarks. If you sit there silent, we can assume only one thing: you do not endorse the Prime Minister's remarks with respect to better way for better work. So I give you that further opportunity now, Senator Campbell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very kind of Senator Sherry to do so. I have given a response on behalf of the government. I think it is now the fourth or fifth time Senator Sherry has asked the same question. I have told him the government's position. I sat silent because I had already answered him three times before. I put the position. I told him the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The Prime Minister's statements have now been put into practice in this piece of legislation. The Senate now has an opportunity to debate them.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not shirking the question at all. I do not need to. The Prime Minister has said those things. He meant them. He is earnest about it. He has appointed Mr Reith to be his Minister for Industrial Relations. The legislation has been created. We have gone through a long debate on this matter, and I am sure we have a long time to go as well.

BREAK.PARA: The consultation process was long. It was very open, very public. Might I say, it was far more public in contrast to the former Prime Minister's negotiations on crucial bits of legislation like native title. That is the response. You can keep asking the question, try lots of different ways, but I believe I have answered it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Murray, could I just indicate that the committee is considering schedule 1. It may not be possible to consider it properly without relating it to something that is going to come up in subsequent schedules, but it would be best if we could speak about schedule 1 in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —We certainly will revisit the issue at much greater length under the secondary boycott schedule, but I think it is relevant to these amendments, particularly since they concern the International Labour Organisation standards, which we have put back into the bill. I will briefly respond to some of the issues which have been raised today.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to make the point that secondary boycotts are illegal under the current law, and that situation has not changed. The Democrats' view was that it was a political impossibility to ask a coalition government to change law which had been established by the coalition and the Labor government. Whether this workplace relations bill is passed or not, secondary boycotts by maritime workers, even on environmental grounds, are illegal.

Proper concerns have been raised about the ships of shame: ships flying under flags of convenience of countries which do not comply with international maritime working standards entering Australian ports. This issue has been properly raised. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has wide powers to force ships flying under flags of convenience to comply with international maritime safety standards, including the power to detain ships and prevent them loading or unloading until environmental and safety standards are complied with.

Last year the authority inspected 2,712 foreign ships, with 247 ships having been destined for repairs. Also, it has recently received considerably increased funding—which is one of the areas in which the government has increased funding—to enable its inspection services to complete implementation of the recommendations resulting from the House of Representatives Ships of shame inquiry.

The Democrats will oppose any attempt to reduce safety standards and conditions on ships in Australian waters. We understand that these issues are in legislation which is separate from the workplace relations bill. It is shipping reform legislation that will be dealt with in due course, and we will support appropriate amendments to it when it comes before the Senate in order to maintain proper standards in Australian shipping.

The Maritime Union, as has been outlined correctly by Senator Sherry, have played a very strong role in attempting to get international standards on ships improved and also in trying to make that work, particularly in Australian waters. We have had an approach from them today—as have all sides of the house, I would hope—in which they have raised concerns about human rights abuses and their ability to deal with those.

We have answered them on matters relating to industrial action, and it is my opinion that those matters have been dealt with appropriately in the bill. But with the human rights abuses, we have asked for a briefing from Minister Sharp. Once we have that advice, we will consider how we should respond on this matter. I advise the Senate that, once we have had that advice, we will come back at an appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I also just want to raise some matters with respect to Senator Murray's earlier contributions, the first made this morning and the second just then, on the issue of international obligations. As I understand Senator Murray's argument, he says that the amendment they have proposed—which is the insertion of an object (k)—is sufficient to cover issues that we are raising and that, therefore, there is no necessity to insert into the objects section the opposition's proposed amendment, which would be to insert the words `encouraging the right of employees to bargain collectively'.

SPEECH.PARA: Adherence to international conventions of course is something that is required by governments who are signatories to those conventions. Australia has a fairly good record in terms of being a signatory and adhering to ILO conventions. The problem, however, as I see it, is that in this legislation there is, firstly, the removal of very important objects that are in the current act which of themselves ensure that the act is directed at protecting employees' rights, whether they be rights with respect to conciliation and arbitration, rights with respect to organisations or rights with respect to award entitlements.

If objects in an act are to mean anything, then the people who will be affected by the operation of the act have to understand them. I do not think there is any doubt that those involved in the industrial relations system in this country understand the intention and the impact of the current objects of the act. They have been there for a very long time, and there are numerous legal and other precedents to ensure that people clearly understand what is intended.

But here we have a new act which does substantially change the objects, firstly, by the removal, as I have said, of some very important objects, such as the object to encourage the registration of employee and employer organisations under the act. That is something that has been in there since the act, I think, came into force in 1904. So the removal of such an important object sends a very strong message to the participants—a message particularly, I would say, to the employers that `you are now free to put pressure on your employees not to join a union'.

That may not be the intention. But that type of a change, the removal of such a longstanding and fundamental part of the objects of the act, as I have said, does send a strong message. If under the current act, as we have seen in recent years, major companies such as CRA have endeavoured through various means to force people out of unions, to prevent people from negotiating collectively—if they have been able to run that campaign through their work force—then, by removing objects such as the one I have just mentioned, they will say that they have a green light to go for broke, and a whole range of other employers will pick up on that.

The fact that there is an ILO convention, which Australia is a signatory to, that requires the encouragement of collective bargaining is something that we all in here know and something that industrial relations practitioners know, but it is not something that is generally known by the work force and people out in the country. People do not carry around with them copies of ILO conventions. I do not think that there are too many senators who carry them around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gough does.
—He certainly does.
—Nor acts of parliament.

—That is right; they do not carry around with them acts of parliament—but they are going to have to carry this one around with them for a while. Given, firstly, that we have the removal of some very important objects and, secondly, that other sections of the act which really carry out the objects have also been neutered, deleted or amended in such a way that the rights formerly enjoyed by trade unions and workers are not only not going to be expressed in the act but also in some cases will be denied to them, it is important on this occasion to make sure that these objects are understood and do not have to be interpreted in the way that they will have to be interpreted if they stay in their current form.

SPEECH.PARA: We will come back to the issue of section 89A. I have already argued that it is one thing to have an object in the act which refers to resolving industrial disputation by conciliation and arbitration, which is in the current act, but, of course, it is another thing when, in the current act, there is a whole process which ensures that all award provisions can ultimately be arbitrated by the commission. In this bill we have an object, which I accept the Democrats have amended, which relates to conciliation and arbitration of industrial disputes. But then we have another section which severely limits the application and the intention of that object. It does not ultimately leave it—even as a last resort—for the commission to arbitrate on all award matters.

This legislation, as I have pointed out, takes awards that currently exist, and may have existed for many years, rips them in half and takes out a whole range of provisions. That, in my view, is not a process of simplification, which is what was intended and stated to be in the coalition's policy. That is a process of removal by legislation and then forcing employees to go back into a bargaining position to try to get those conditions back—and not even back into an award.

If the employer and employee agreed on a specific provision which, for instance, relates to health and safety in that industry and want to have it in a consent award, they would not be allowed to. They have to have it in some attendant agreement, because the allowable matters do not allow for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There won't be consent awards.

—That is correct. And that is notwithstanding that the parties would like it in a consent award. There are very good reasons why you should be able to have consent awards, and I will be moving to other sections later. Many employers in industries subject to rise and fall clauses in contracts will tell you that you need certainty. Therefore, quite often they need an award regulation through an arbitral process to enable them to seek adjustment in their prices—for instance, in relation to wages.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come back to the ILO position. I have been to the ILO on a number of occasions and have had a fair amount of experience with it in my 18 years in the industrial relations system and working for a trade union. I can tell you that the hardest thing in the world is to get an agreement at the ILO. If you think that we are going to be spending a bit of time in this chamber debating these issues, then note that the ILO will debate the meaning of a word for weeks.

For instance, to get any recognition of the term `trade union' at the ILO is virtually impossible. The resolutions that come out of ILO committee meetings and particular industries have to have been agreed to. So you get down to the lowest common denominator, where the workers' groups, the employers' groups and the government groups agree on the terms of a resolution or convention, or whatever it is. They will always use the words `workers' representatives' or `workers' organisations'.

We have battled and battled to get the ILO to accept that, generally speaking, trade unions—certainly in the case of free and democratic unions—are workers' representatives. But they do not like the term `trade union'. It is also the case with the concept of collective bargaining. Getting an agreement at the ILO that it should be a fundamental principle that workers have the right to collectively bargain took a lot of effort. From my experience, it is still not something that employers generally throughout the world actually like. If they can find a way to dodge it, they will.

So I would ask Senator Murray to rethink his position on the opposition's amendment. Our amendment will add strength to his amendment which refers to a recognition of international obligations. It actually adds to it. The problem that I have is that if you do not have specific reference to collective bargaining, for instance, or to, as Senator Sherry has said, commitments to better pay, then those who are preaching that these things exist will be the very first who will endeavour to ensure that it does occur.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Campbell going to respond? We have the minister, Mr Reith, here. Perhaps we could facilitate him to move a little bit closer to Senator Campbell to provide some advice, because we are not getting very far when we do not get a quick response. Do you want me to go back to Better pay for better work ? Perhaps the minister can confirm Better pay for better work and why we do not have it here—Mr Howard's own statement in the objectives of this bill? Can you get some further advice on this?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I do not need further advice. Mr Howard, in his long and very successful political career, has made many statements of fine principle and fine rhetoric that do not need to be put into the legislation. That is the response I have made to that, I think, now seven times, Senator Sherry. I will keep making it for as long as you want to stay here. You obviously want to stay here for a long time. It is now six or seven hours, and we have not got past the title, as Senator Boswell says. We know how these things work. We have been there before.
—We are still waiting on your answer in several areas.

—There was nothing else, Senator Jacinta Collins. Senator Forshaw just made a nice second reading speech. It was a speech. It did not seek any information about the objects. There were no other questions.
—Answer the other questions then.

—The only point that deserves a response, which I will give to you, is that Senator Forshaw—and the record needs to be corrected—said that a lack of recognition of registered organisations in the objects will tell employers that they now have open slather to go and tell workers they are not allowed to join unions. That is behaviour that is actually specifically prohibited by schedule 16 at 298K and 298L. It is proscribed behaviour. That is the only thing I need to respond to, Senator Collins, because it is the only point Senator Forshaw made that requires a response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just wondering whether what you should do is drop the objects clause altogether. We have had, as you said, eight hours of the—
—It is a policy.

—I know it is policy but, if you keep the objects in the act, you are going to have this policy discussed in the commission and in the court again and again. I was just wondering whether that is a good thing. I just want to mention `a literal'. It has probably been corrected, but the draft I have talks about the `principal object'. I think there should be an `s' in there. I have an appetite for literals. Is that right? Is it just the object of the act?
—Yes.

—All right. I just ask you to look at how this has developed. I am going back to the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act, 1 February 1904, which had the objects of the act in section 2. Those objects were ones that fitted in with the constitution in the sense that it talked about promoting goodwill in industry and settling disputes. It kept itself concerned with that particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: That seemed to continue until the last government introduced the Industrial Relations Act 1988. The act then talked about settling industrial disputes, which promotes the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia. What the act was saying was, `Look, let's promote industrial peace as a means towards that.' A concentration of the whole act was upon settling industrial disputes.

It seems that what has happened here in these latest proposals is that we have made a quantum leap beyond the attempt to settle disputes in the work place, to make for a happy workplace and to go after all these other things such as low inflation and international competitiveness. I am just wondering whether that opens up such a Pandora's box that it becomes a problem keeping those objectives there.

I think the discussion over the last couple of days is a great illustration of just what will happen. I have not met a lawyer who does not want to get through the case quickly and smartly and directly. What happens is that parliamentarians give them all these words to play with. What else can they do when they are given these things, when these words of wisdom are forced upon them by the legislature, but interpret them in the court? I think that is what is going to happen with this act. There is going to be a long involved process of sorting through these objectives.

I was just wondering whether—I do not want an answer now—the act wouldn't run more smoothly once it is put through. Wouldn't you save a lot of difficulties before the commission and the courts if you restricted these objects and, indeed, perhaps abandoned them? Otherwise, you are going to get long discussions in court as to whether or not a particular situation promotes international competitiveness and that sort of thing. I know from past days that lawyers are very learned in economics and know all these sorts of things, but even they might take different points of view. What I am really asking is: isn't this very productive of a lot of litigation, which could better be avoided by striking out a lot of these objects and perhaps even abandoning the courts? The act speaks for itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to draw attention to the difference between the opposition's object, particularly that referring to effective bargaining in (f), and the original government position and the deal proposal coming from the coalition and the Democrats, where they refer to effective agreement. The simple position is that the bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: (e) providing a framework of rights and responsibilities for employers and employees, and their organisations, which supports fair and effective agreement‐making and ensures that they abide by awards and agreements applying to them . . .

The opposition supports a system of fair and effective bargaining and proposed subclause (e)(ii) gives effect to that support. But the very important difference which I would like to put to the Democrats—I think perhaps the government is beyond the pale, because they really are seeking to disadvantage all workers—is that I do believe they are trying to get a result that is fair. The trouble is that the Democrats have accepted the completely passive approach of the coalition, and that is that it is all by agreement. There is no sense of the real dynamic that exists in industrial relations: where people bargain, where they are empowered to argue it out, in many cases being helped by unions; of course, the employers are helped by their employer associations.

PARA.BREAK: That is a fundamental tenet of the system. It is a system that gets over the imbalance of power between the employee and the employ er—with the natural power that the employer has over the employee—giving the rights to the individual, that is, the employee, through a collective process. I think this is important because the bargaining process is essential for people who are disadvantaged—people with poor English, women, and others. People of any type who are not skilled in negotiation need to be helped. The emphasis on bargaining is important. The words `effective agreement' are completely passive and are not acceptable. I do believe that it is naive for the Democrats to go along following the coalition in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to return to another area where the Democrats have been equally naive, and that is with regard to the other section dealing with the other objective that has been referred to, bargaining collectively, and the implications for the seafaring industry. It is not good enough to talk about the ILO alone, and my colleague has referred to the limitations of the ILO. When we talk about industrial relations on the waterfront, we are talking about very hard people. The people involved, the employers involved world wide, are some of the toughest employers in the world. Seamen and waterside workers on so many occasions over so many years have been prepared to stand up and risk all on the basis of fighting out human rights issues. They have done it time and time again. The Liberal Party, in a previous guise under the leadership of Pig Iron Bob, sold iron ore overseas. There has been case after case. There has been betrayal by the conservatives and the common law experience of workers on the waterfront is that they have always stood up for human rights.

With that background, it is very disappointing to hear the Democrats' Senator Murray wimp out. He said that the ordinary maritime safety legislation is going to be the way the horrendous cases of disadvantage to seamen who come to our shores from across the world are going to be dealt with. The experience has been that some of the very large employers in international seafaring will take that union on and set out to bankrupt the union.

Unless we face up to our responsibilities when we vote on the objectives, we will be allowing the naked power of capital, internationally and in Australia, to dominate. I do not care whether the Minister for Industrial Relations or his parliamentary secretary do not like it. The truth is clear. That is what the government is setting out to do. Unfortunately, the Democrats are acquiescing in the government's objectives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Campbell's response to my interjection earlier, there are several areas where we are actually still waiting for responses to questions. I think Senator Campbell might have implied earlier that some of the answers we were seeking were ideological in nature and that we were not going to get anywhere pursuing those avenues. But I would like to go back to one clear area at least, because there are some technical aspects of the bill that pertain to this proposed change in the objects.

SPEECH.PARA: In the current act, the objects refer to awards without prescribing them just as minimum safety net awards, which is currently being proposed. Relevant in that sense and relevant to the objects, we need to look at how awards are proposed to be restricted. In the agreed Democrat‐government position, dealing with proposed section 89A, we have the introduction of a new word, and I think that the government should at this stage give us some indication of how they propose it to be regarded or defined or what it should mean. I ask the parliamentary secretary to please inform us how we are meant to regard an `exceptional' matter when we take into account this change in the objects in terms of their now just referring to minimum safety net awards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no reference to the word `exceptional' in the objects. While I am on my feet, I will respond—
—That is a cop‐out.
—You can ask me again, but that is the answer. There is no reference to the words `exceptional circumstances'.
—But there is a change to the reference to the awards.

—In the objects. If you want to debate the award section, you can debate it in a future schedule. If you want to get to the next schedule, we can have a vote on these amendments that are before us. While I am on my feet—I was trying to seek the call when Senator Collins got to her feet—I will respond to a couple of matters that Senator Cooney raised. I might say that, in this debate, which has been wide-ranging and has been very long to date, the one person who has actually raised some substantial issues that do require response has been Senator Cooney. As I said to the Senate earlier today, I have kept copious notes of the contributions of all senators—over 20 of you now, over nearly six or seven hours—
—Three hours to go.
—So we are saying three hours before we vote on this?
—Just answer some questions, will you?

—I was answering a question from Senator Cooney, Senator Collins. The issues that you raise, Senator Cooney—we have discussed this outside the chamber—did relate to how the workplace relations act will assist in giving effect to Australia's international obligations. You raised a series of specific questions in relation to that, and the officers have very kindly put together a table which I think in a very effective way throws light on those important matters you raised. Senator Sherry, I had sought agreement from Senator Cooney to actually have that table incorporated in Hansard . I think he was going to raise it with you. I seek leave to incorporate this table in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: How the Workplace Relations Act 1996 will assist in giving effect to Australia's international obligations

ROW.ENTRY: Relevant aspects of Workplace Relations Act 1996

ILO C87, the Freedom of Association Protection of the Right to Organise Convention, 1948; International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR); International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR)

Protected industrial action—provides for the right to strike as required by ILO C87 and ICESCR. Protection against discrimination on the basis of union‐membership (and non‐membership)—as required by ILO C87, ICCPR and ICESCR.
ILO C98, the Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining Convention, 1949
Provision for certified agreements and protected action—encourages collective agreements, as required by ILO C98.
UN Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW); ILO C100, the Equal Remuneration Convention, 1951
Division 2 of Part VIA provides a remedy, ensuring equal remuneration for men and women workers for work of equal value. (The principal object, awards and certified agreement provisions also assist.)
UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (CERD); ILO C111, the Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) Convention, 1958
Principal object, awards and certified agreement provisions, and provisions prohibiting termination on specified grounds, contribute to preventing and eliminating discrimination on relevant grounds.
ILO C131, the Minimum Wage Fixing Convention, 1973
Provision for conciliation and arbitration establishes a system of minimum wages for relevant employees.
ILO C156, the Workers with Family Responsibilities Convention, 1981
Division 4 of Part VIA guarantees 12 months parental leave.
ILO C158, the Termination of Employment Convention, 1982
Division 3 of Part VIA provides for Federal system employees, and supplements State unfair dismissal systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other matter you just raised, Senator Cooney, did relate to the objects of the act, and you suggested that we might remove that entire section from the act. Certainly that would make it easier to get to the vote on schedule 2.

BREAK.PARA: There are two points in relation to that, Senator Cooney. Firstly, your own party—you may disagree with your party—has moved a substantial amendment in its own right. In many of its words and sections it is, as I said earlier, in thunderous agreement with the coalition. You mention international productivity, which I know Senator Bishop is concerned about. You mention rising living standards, and so forth. So, Senator Cooney, I presume your previous intervention in the debate was speaking against the opposition's own amendment.

PARA.BREAK: The objects of the act, as you would know, do provide a general guide to what the legislation is about. A court may be called on to adjudicate on a matter arising out of the operation of the act and, in so doing, may be required to determine the meaning of a provision in the act. If the court considers that in taking account of the wording of the provision alone its meaning is unclear or ambiguous, the court will take into account the objects of the act as an aid to the interpretation. I think you would have known that already. The coalition clearly would like to see these objects included in the act. We think they are important, and we wish their con sideration by this committee of the whole a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that. Yes, the sorts of comments I made about the objects in the bill clearly apply to the amendments that I think we have moved from this side. What has happened is legislative creep. I am not too sure when objects were first put into the act, but they were very modest objects when first put in. But now it seems—I used the word `parliament' advisedly before—that the legislators seem to be intent upon putting most policy statements into an act which has to be interpreted, and I am not sure whether it is a wise thing. Perhaps we can get some information about when objects were first put in, what the basis of that was, and why we have suddenly, as a parliament—I do not want to be party political about this, Senator Campbell—launched forth to encourage, as it will, advocates to give tribunals and courts lectures on economics, social policy and all sorts of other things that I think we as legislators would be better able to deal with. That is what worries me a bit. I am not sure whether we can get any help on that as to when these objects were first put in—when objects of any sort were first put in. This really becomes, I suppose, the insertion of a bill of rights into a piece of legislation. It is a very interesting legal concept.
—I will go to the Parliamentary Library and check that for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up a contribution from Senator Murray. He is, unfortunately, not with us at the moment. We do not have a Democrat representative here, but nevertheless I know that what I have to say will be listened to. I refer to paragraph (e), which says that the object of this act is to provide a framework of rights and responsibilities for employer and employees in their organisations which supports fair and effective agreement making. What about the plight of those seafarers coming into Australia who, when they come under the umbrella of Australian law, have no rights when it comes to agreement making.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray said that he would consult with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) on the matter and come back to the Senate on it. That raises two important things about these objects if they are to be carried out and true, and if the designers of the legislation are going to stick with them. Are the Democrats going to insist on an amendment to the legislation if it infringes these objects—if it is found that those seafarers are left unprotected under this legislation, as the Maritime Union say they are? I am concerned that after such a long piece of negotiation, the Democrats do not in fact know the answer to that. They are assured that the ships will be safe—they will looked over and their seaworthiness will be ensured—but they do not know about the human beings aboard.

The maritime unions have an extraordinary and meritorious record in this country of looking after those interests. That is where we all ought to be alarmed that this legislation is disempowering those unions to continue that job. If that is the case, we are moving to a situation where we will also be removing the protection for people under the law in this country to ensure that their rights, their freedoms and their ability to not only make agreements but also have the employers honour those agreements are not taken away by this bill.

So we have an objective set out here, but the reality is that the bill is doing the exact opposite to the objective. It is internally inconsistent. We ought not, as a house of parliament, allow for that contradiction. I think we should have the facility to come back and amend this set of objectives, if Senator Murray finds that the Maritime Union's ability to protect seafarers in Australia is being trammelled. It is a very serious point that has been raised by the unions.

I am concerned that the Democrats were apparently not aware of this problem. I am concerned that after the agreement has been struck, advice now has to be sought from the minister. But I am much more concerned that, on the public record, Senator Kernot has indicated that they have signed a document which binds them to the provision of this legislation. I ask, through you, sir, what the Democrats are going to do if they find that this appalling change of fortune for seafarers coming to this country is, in fact, embodied in this legislation and the government says, `But we're not going to change it because we're out to get the unions, particularly on the seaboard of this country.'

What is the bargaining power for Senator Kernot in that situation? Has she or has she not signed away her right to rectify what is manifestly a very great wrong being perpetrated on not 10, 20 or 100 but thousands of seafarers who will come to this country over the decades to come? Are we returning not only to the `ships of shame' situation but also to a deliberate trammelling of the process whereby maritime unions have been able to come to the aid of those people? On a raw reading of it, if they exercise the power they need to to pull up the flag of convenience shipowners and their captains, they could face a three‐quarter of a million dollar fine for taking such action. It would put them out of business.

We would end up with a situation that apparently pertains in New Zealand where the best the unions can do is say, `I hope your ship is going to Australia because over there they have not yet got the draconian industrial relations legislation that we have in this country which ties our hands. The best we can do is picket.' Is that going to be the situation pertaining in this country after the passage of this legislation? If it is, the Democrats have an invidious responsibility on their shoulders to change it now, to know exactly what they are doing as far as this legislation is concerned. I do not care whether or not Senator Kernot has signed on the dotted line: honour says she must put the plight of those people before that hasty signing of a document—a signing away of her rights.

I appeal again, through you, sir, for the Democrats to look closely at the objects of this bill and make sure that they are fulfilling those objects as laid out and, in fact, have not signed an agreement which does the exact opposite to what, in particular, object (e) in this bill purports to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to Senator Campbell relates to a part of paragraph (a) where it talks about `international competitiveness through higher productivity'. How does this apply to industries—and I am not arguing against higher productivity—that are not in the international marketplace? What is the government expecting from industries such as the retail sector, the hospitality sector and the service sector? How does this have any force and where do we find its force later on in the legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who suggests that the hospitality and service sectors are not in the international marketplace needs to know a lot more about the hospitality and service sectors. We are in the international marketplace in those sectors. I have already answered the substantive part of your question in my response to Senator Bishop just before the luncheon debate.

—Then what is meant, in particular in the retail industry, by international competitiveness? Is international competitiveness a reference to the lower rates of pay which might apply in overseas nations? Does that also apply to the service and the hospitality industries, if we acknowledge that they are in competition with overseas countries? Is that what that objective is getting at?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could pursue the point, Senator Campbell. A couple of moments ago you said I referred to international productivity.
—International competitiveness and productivity.

—Yes. That is the point we are trying to address. There is no such thing as international productivity. Nations certainly do compete but there is no such thing as international productivity. It is a domestic concept related to domestic economies. During the luncheon debate, I took the trouble to get some information from the Department of the Parliamentary Library and they advised, on the June figures to this year, that 16 per cent of GDP production in this country relates to the export of goods and services and 84 per cent relates to domestic production. Of that 16 per cent that relates to export production, the overwhelming majority is from the minerals, agricultural and mining sectors, which, as you know, are heavily capital intensive with little, and certainly declining, labour content.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis that 84 per cent of our production is related to the domestic economy and the overwhelming majority of our export GDP relates to capital intensive industries, how does any emphasis at all on international competitiveness in the domestic economy result in higher employment, improved living standards or low inflation? How does it have any relevance to the domestic production side of GDP in this country? That is my question. It appears to me that the emphasis on paragraph (a), as the prime objective, has an internally contradictory outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I heard Senator Bishop speaking on the D'Entrecasteaux National Park Protection Bill last week I was actually very impressed and would not have thought I would have to make the suggestion that I am about to make, which is that if he went to the Parliamentary Library to get that information, he should perhaps spend a little more time there and read a little more about the concepts of productivity and international competitiveness. I do not make that as a serious suggestion to Senator Bishop because I am sure he knows the answer to the question he has just asked.

SPEECH.PARA: To basically assert, as Senator Bishop does, that international competitiveness is not important to the domestic sector of the economy is quite absurd as far as I am concerned. You are advocating that we need to be productive and internationally competitive in the sector of our economy that creates exports in either goods or services. Is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asserting that productivity is a domestic concern. It comes from domestic industries—industries that are totally domestic and totally related in this country. International competitiveness, whilst it may be important in a range of areas, has no relevance at all to the production process of either goods or services for the domestic economy. The price of a can of beans in Coles in Western Australia is irrelevant to anything else in the rest of the world. Hence, if that argument and conclusion is right, this objective is incorrect. That is the proposition I am putting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —From memory, the Heinz factory was one of the factories that went to New Zealand. Anyone who works in the domestic economy creating goods and services to be consumed domestically is, even though Senator Margetts would like it to be different, competing as far as import replacements go. You cannot totally divorce, as you seem to want to do, the concept of productivity from international competitiveness. It is quite crucial that our domestic industries are competitive internationally whether we compete externally or compete with import replacements.

SPEECH.PARA: You cannot advocate that we have an inefficient service sector. If you have, for example, tourism, which is a massive industry and a very big employer, as Senator Hogg referred to, it needs to provide internationally competitive levels of service. If Australia gains a reputation for having internationally uncompetitive levels of service—if all the people who work in our restaurants and hotels provide services to tourists who come to Australia—we will very rapidly have reduced employment because people will stop coming here. The two are linked, Senator Bishop. I do not take your assertion. I think the objects of the act retain their integrity.

If we want to have a very long debate about this and if we want to go through to 7.20 p.m. and not have any votes on these amendments—if that is the opposition's tactic and will—it is a more interesting subject to talk about than some of the other subjects. If we want to do that, I am happy to have that debate. I find the subject fascinating. If Senator Sherry wants to indicate that he does not want to have a vote until 7.20 p.m. because that is his tactic not to have any votes prior to us rising tonight, I welcome this debate. I do find it very important and very interesting and a very important part of the objects of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow up that point briefly. I am sure that Senator Sherry will deal with the question of the timetable of this debate. I will not purport to do that. This question of international competitiveness through higher productivity concerns me. I think it touches on a matter that Senator Hogg was raising, and I do not think there was really an answer to it.

SPEECH.PARA: How relevant to the achievement of the objective of international competitiveness through higher productivity is the cost of labour? How much of that focus does this principal object of the act direct to the Industrial Relations Commission and the parties by the passage of this bill, as it may well be amended?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I presume you are doing what Senator Cooney is doing and speaking against your own opposition amendment No. (1). It has not been moved yet. Maybe the opposition is backing away from the concept of productivity. Clearly, from your contributions to the debate and that of other senators, you are backing away from productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very hard, but I am beginning to understand why the Labor Party in government had problems. If a parliamentary secretary has to stand here and explain to the opposition what productivity means, what international competitiveness means and what higher living standards mean, I think the people of Australia can begin to understand why you made such a hash of industrial relations when you were in power, such a hash of the economy and such a hash of employment, and cost millions of people their living standards.

BREAK.PARA: This government is committed—it is in this bill—to higher living standards, international competitiveness, productivity and more productive and effective workplace relations. I thought you backed those concepts by proposing opposition amendment No. (1), which backs all of those concepts. If the meaning of any of those words are unclear to you, I strongly recommend that you go up to the library with Senator Bishop. There are lots of good books on international competitiveness. There are lots of books about how you measure it, lots of debate about it, lots of discussion about it and lots of discussions about the concept of pay. Most of the papers that are coming out now say that international competitiveness has very little to do with pay rates; it all comes down to effectiveness and efficiency.

As I said to Senator Bishop, if your objective is to stay here until 7.20 p.m. and have a discussion about productivity, international competitiveness, living standards, various measures of it and what the impacts are, it is a fascinating debate, but it has very little to do with getting into the core sections of this bill, which Senator Sherry has assured us we will get to.

If your objective is to fill the time between now and 7.20 with these sorts of notions, I guess it will be an interesting debate, but it has very little to do with the details of the bill. In fact, they are not contentious because, Senator, your party has agreed—I presume at its caucus—even though you do not seem to have moved this amendment yet. Maybe you are backing off from it. All of these words are actually agreed. They are entirely non‐contentious because they are in your own amendment. The Labor Party amendment No. 1 reads:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . encouraging the pursuit of high employment, improved living standards . . . international competitiveness . . . higher productivity and a flexible and fair labour market . . .

All of those matters are non‐contentious. If you have so many problems with them, I have made a suggestion to Senator Mackay: go to Senator Sherry's office at lunchtime and cross them out with crayon. She was going to cross out `the pursuit of high employment' because she is backing off from that. Labor does not want high employment as an object of its industrial relations system in Australia. You do not want `productivity' and Senator Bishop does not want `international competitiveness'. Borrow Senator Mackay's crayon and go to Senator Sherry's office, maybe at afternoon tea time, and cross it all out. Tell the Australian people that you do not want the industrial relations system to have those objects. We do but, if you do not, do not proceed with your amendment. It is quite easy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of points in response to that diatribe—and that is what it was. I referred to the finishing time of 7.20 earlier because that is when we will finish considering this bill today. There was no reference whatsoever to the time that we will vote on this particular schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to you, Senator, that it is the first time in my six years here that I have ever heard a parliamentary secretary or a minister on a number of occasions refer senators to the library on important questions. I do not recall that my colleagues or I did this when we were in government. If that is the sort of tack you are going to suggest, all you are doing is exemplifying your own ignorance. I would also make the same comment in respect of your comments about afternoon tea, sandwiches and crayons—if that is the best that you can do.

I raise the undertakings given by the Prime Minister and the importance of (a). We are in support of (a) and, as you have pointed out, it is included in our amendment. What we want to know is why you will not include other concepts in these broad principles and how you see the outcomes of the other schedules in this bill—how you see the various changes that you are proposing to principle (a) are going to affect the Australian economy in respect of unemployment, et cetera.

I return to that second commitment of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. He said that, under a Howard government, you cannot be worse off but you can be better off. Do you stand by that undertaking of the Prime Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —That question is on No. 8; I have responded to that. I responded that the Prime Minister's commitments were commitments which we have made, which he has made, which are reflected in this legislation. The reference to the library, Senator Sherry, was something that Senator Bishop made and I suggested that, if he was getting information from the library, it is a very good place to get more information on those issues.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is becoming your excuse for not answering questions, Senator—`Refer people to the library.' That is your problem. In respect of the statement `you cannot be worse off but you can be better off', what I am simply asking is: do you stand by the Prime Minister's undertaking, yet again, or are you going to remain silent on the Prime Minister's own undertaking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been following this debate if not in the chamber then on the monitor in my room. I am getting concerned at the lack of responses, the lack of answers and the flippancy with which the parliamentary secretary is treating the questions which come from this side of the chamber. This is an extremely important bill to the people of Australia, to the workers of Australia. It is a very important bill to us on this side of the chamber because of our affiliations with the trade union movement and the fact that many of us here publicly admit that we have got very distinct links with the trade union movement, and we are very proud of it.
—Ask your question? Have you got a question?

—I have got the floor and I am talking. You sit there and keep quiet. When you are asked a question, you should respond. You have no right to ask me questions when I am making a contribution to the committee—no right at all.
—Could you speak through the chair, please.

—Mr Chairman. We are asking on this side of the chamber some very important questions, crucial questions to us and crucial questions to the people that we purport to represent in this parliament of Australia. We are not getting responses. One of the core commitments that was given to the people of Australia prior to the election was that no worker would be worse off by the introduction of the Howard industrial relations legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We look for evidence of that commitment in the objects of the bill, and it is not there—it is just not there. We seek clarification from the parliamentary secretary. We are not even given the decency in the committee, in the parliament, of a minister having carriage of the bill. We are not even given that decency with this very important piece of legislation.
We ask very definite, very genuine questions and we are flippantly told to go to the library.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or not answered.

—Or not answered; he just sits there dumb. I can understand that the parliamentary secretary might not have the competence, I can understand that he may not know what he is talking about, but we have a right—we have more than a right; we have an obligation—to get these answers out of you, to get an understanding of what the government is about in putting forward this particular bill. We have to persist with what we are doing. That is what we are elected for; that is what the people of Australia voted for in the March election and in the election before that when others were elected to this place. We have to fulfil those obligations to the people who put us here—and it is not only us; it is other senators in the place. We have obligations, but there are obligations on the other side of the chamber as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I would hope that you have had your little bit of fun with your flippant answers, with the arrogance that I suppose anybody who reaches the front bench is entitled from time to time to show, to put on display. I think it is about time now that we got back to the real issues. We are asking simple questions. We want progress on the bill. There will be progress on the bill, but give us some answers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the question? Firstly, Senator McKiernan enjoys talking about personalities and so forth. Is Senator McKiernan genuine in his view that we have not answered a question? Senator Sherry has asked one particular question about eight different times. I have given a response, but he does not like that response.
—You have not answered the question.

—I do not answer it in the way you like. To speed this up, Senator McKiernan and anyone else who believes there is any matter that has not been dealt with should raise it now and I will provide a response. I believe that I have dealt with every issue that has been raised by 20-something senators over the past six hours. Senator Cooney raised the only detailed substantive point that was not a debating point.
—That's not correct.

—It is not totally correct. It is an exaggeration, Senator Sherry; I will pay you that. There were a number of other issues that I responded to. Anyone who wants to read the Hansard will see that. Senator McKiernan, if there is an issue or a question that you, from monitoring this debate, believe we have not answered, then please raise it and I will answer it for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to return to the point I was making before Senator Campbell pointed to our amendments as being identical in terms of the words I referred to when I was asking the question about international competitiveness through higher productivity. I think the senator should have regard also to point (b) in our amendment, which does not appear concurrent with the passage in the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, I was asking about the effect the government sees with the bill as it is expected to be amended in terms of wage levels. In the absence of guaranteeing in the objects that no employee will be worse off, is it the intent of the government that that should be read as having regard to the wage costs overseas as an important object in setting salaries? I think that is a critical matter in relation to the operation of this bill because the objects clause will no doubt be the subject of debate before the Industrial Relations Commission and elsewhere. That is the question I am asking. I make that differentiation, hoping that I will get an answer.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)
