INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 5) to page 4 (line 21), omit the item, substitute:
The principal object of this Act is to provide a framework for cooperative industrial relations which promotes the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia by:

PARA.TAB: (a) encouraging the pursuit of high employment, improved living standards, better pay, low inflation and international competitiveness through higher productivity and a flexible and fair labour market; and

(b) guaranteeing that no employee will be worse off as a result of the implementation of this Act, and in particular, that no trainee or apprentice will receive less take home pay than the relevant entitlement under the applicable award; and

(c) within the framework provided by this Act and with the protections provided by the Commission, ensuring that the pri mary responsibility for determining matters affecting the relationship between employers and employees rests with the employer and employees at the workplace or enterprise level; and
(d) enabling employers and employees to choose the most appropriate form of agreement for their particular circumstances; and
(e) providing the means:

TAB.TAB: (i) for wages and conditions of employment to be determined as far as possible by the agreement of employers and employees at the workplace or enterprise level, upon a foundation of minimum standards; and
(ii) to ensure that there is an effective award system providing secure, relevant, and consistent wages and conditions of employment; and

PARA.TAB: (f) providing a framework of rights and responsibilities for employers and employees, and their organisations, which supports fair and effective bargaining and ensures that they abide by awards and agreements applying to them; and

(g) ensuring freedom of association, including the rights of employers and employees to join an organisation or association of their choice, or not to join an organisation or association, while maintaining the rights of employers and employees to organise and bargain collectively; and

(h) encouraging and facilitating the development and registration of organisations of employers and employees, and ensuring these organisations are representative of and accountable to their members; and
(i) enabling the Commission to prevent and settle industrial disputes

TAB.TAB: (i) so far as possible, by conciliation; and
(ii) where necessary, by arbitration; and

PARA.TAB: (j) assisting employees to balance their work and family responsibilities effectively through the development of mutually beneficial work practices with employers; and

(k) respecting and valuing the diversity of the work force by helping to prevent and eliminate discrimination on the basis of race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin; and
(l) ensuring that labour standards meet Australia's international obligations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe I mentioned that in relation to the opposition's own principal object it is certainly an improvement on the government's principal object. It is an improvement even on the Democrat‐government amendments. However, there are elements in it which, right from the beginning, we still thought were inappropriate and perhaps have been part of the whole process of leading to where we are now on industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Those issues have been brought out in the debate—the fact that there is still as a principal object international competitiveness in that form and that it is still gearing towards economic rationalism. It is one form of economic rationalism as opposed to another, albeit that I do fully recognise that the ALP's amendments do include much more appropriate recognition of the need for bargaining and real rights and understanding and observance of conventions.

It is not that I do not recognise that the opposition's amendments are better than the original principal object or even the amended version of the principal object. It is just, funnily enough, that we like ours better. We will be moving ours should this one not receive majority support.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 4 (after line 6), after paragraph (f), insert:

PARA.TAB: (fa) encouraging the right of employees to bargain collectively; and

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment in document 214 we have called the `Murray amendment' on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I remind the Senate and particularly Senator Murray, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, that we were particularly impressed by his observations in the Senate Economics References Committee report. I will not quote again for the record. I did so earlier.

This amendment reflects the views as expressed at that time by Senator Murray on behalf of the Australian Democrats—encouraging the right of employees to bargain collectively. We believe that the objectives of the act should reflect that very clearly. Senator Murray worked long and hard to put forward his recommendations to this committee. We were particularly impressed by them and we urge the Australian Democrats to join us in supporting an amendment that reflects their own views.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the amendment in document 214 in a similar vein to what I mentioned before in that we supported the Democrat‐government amendments to what we thought were inadequate objects. It certainly makes the inadequate objects a little less inadequate. Therefore, we will be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 5) to page 4 (line 21), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the section, substitute

(1) The principal object of this Act is to provide a framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes which promotes the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia by:

PARA.TAB: (a) encouraging and facilitating the making of agreements, between the parties involved in industrial relations, to determine matters pertaining to the relationship between employers and employees, particularly at the workplace or enterprise level; and
(b) promoting industrial harmony; and
(c) providing the means for:

TAB.TAB: (i) establishing and maintaining an effective framework for protecting wages and conditions of employment through awards; and
(ii) ensuring that labour standards meet Australia's international obligations; and

PARA.TAB: (d) providing a framework of rights and responsibilities for the parties involved in industrial relations which encourages fair and effective bargaining and ensures that those parties abide by agreements between them; and
(e) enabling the Commission to prevent and settle industrial disputes:

TAB.TAB: (i) so far as possible by conciliation; and
(ii) where necessary, by arbitration; and

PARA.TAB: (f) encouraging the organisation of representative bodies of employers and employees and their registration under this Act; and
(g) encouraging a high level of consultation between employers and employees and their organisations; and

(h) helping to prevent and eliminate discrimination and workplace harassment on the basis of race, colour, sex, sexual preference, transgender identity, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin; and
(i) encouraging employers to provide employees with access to training and career path planning; and
(j) encouraging and promoting collective bargaining; and
(k) through all these measures, pursuing the goal of satisfying work for all employees.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: Australia's international obligations include obligations under the ILO Convention Concerning the Termination of Employment at the Initiative of the Employer (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 10 to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 ), the ILO Convention Concerning Discrimination in Respect of Employment and Occupation (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 1 to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 ), the Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) Recommendation, 1958, adopted by the General Conference of the ILO on 25 June 1958 and also known as Recommendation No. 111 (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 9 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988), the ILO Convention Concerning Equal Opportunities and Equal Treatment for Men and Women Workers: Workers with Family Responsibilities (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 12 to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 ), the Workers with Family Responsibilities Recommendation, 1981, adopted by the Geneva Conference of the ILO on 23 June 1981 and also known as Recommendation No. 165 (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 13 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988), the ILO Convention Concerning Equal Remuneration for Men and Women Workers for Work of Equal Value (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 6 to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 ), the ILO Convention Concerning Minimum Wage Fixing, with Special Reference to Developing Countries (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 5 to the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 ), the Preamble and Articles 1 to 6 of the ILO Convention Concerning the Application of the Principles of the Right to Organise and to Bargain Collectively (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 16 to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 ), the Preamble and Parts I and II of the ILO Convention Concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 15 to the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 ), the Preamble and Parts I and II of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 8 to the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 ), and the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women (a copy of the English text of which is set out in the Schedule to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 ).
(2) In this Act:
discrimination has the same meaning as in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 .
workplace harassment means conduct by a person which:

PARA.TAB: (a) threatens, intimidates, offends or humiliates another person in the workplace; or
(b) is unwelcome and discriminatory in relation to another person in the workplace; or
(c) constitutes failure to take appropriate action to resolve workplace conflict;

SPEECH.PARA: in circumstances which a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated as being threatening, intimidatory, offensive or humiliating to the person harassed.

As I mentioned before, the Greens (WA) reject the concept of issues such as international competitiveness and so on being incorporated into the principal object of the legislation which will determine the wages and conditions we will be forced to endure in future years. Instead, when we looked at the various elements of the principal object, like the ALP we realised that, rather than try to make individual amendments, the best thing to do would be to rewrite a new principal object. Therefore, that is what we have done.

BREAK.PARA: We have proposed an alternative clause that is based on the existing object clause in the Industrial Relations Act. Our amendments to that clause include: firstly, the promotion of industrial harmony, which is certainly a part of Greens policy through and through; secondly, encouraging a high level of consultation between employers and employees and their organisation, which likewise is very much part of Greens policy; thirdly, deletion of the reference to the desirability of reducing the number of organisations in an industry or enterprise; fourthly, encouraging employers to provide employees with access to training and career path planning; fifthly, encouraging and promoting collective bargaining; sixthly, incorporation in the discrimination clause of workplace harassment and extension of the clause to incorporate people with a transgender identity; seventhly, the incorporation of the goal of satisfying work for all employees; and, eighthly, the incorporation of a note with respect to Australia's international obligations.

On the last point, it is important that we do not just see something as meeting Australia's international obligations without having some idea of what they are. So we have mentioned those relevant obligations, agreements and commitments Australia has made in the object of the bill, and that is set out there in the note following our new principal object.

We do believe those objects, such as prevention of discrimination and prevention of workplace harassment, are important in the object. Part of getting a fairer Australia and a more productive Australia that is meeting people's needs is through actually making sure that, as far as possible, workplaces are in harmony and groups of people are not singled out for poorer treatment than other workers, for whatever reason.

I would like to commend my amendments to the Senate. I hope this can be seen as a model instead of a narrow viewpoint that somehow or other we will translate economic rationalism—or irrationalism, as I call it—or economic fundamentalism and put that in as the object of the workplace relations bill. Instead, we should be seeing what it is we are hoping to achieve in the workplace. This is what I think we should be hoping to achieve in the workplace so we do actually have a more productive workplace with better outcomes for all people involved. I commend my amendment to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Schedule 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Schedule 2, item 2, page 5 (line 20), omit "give particular", substitute "give".

This amendment is a small amendment to reduce the requirement for the president of the commission to give consideration to deploying state dual appointees. It deals with particular matters from a stronger `give particular consideration' to a less directory `give consideration'.

We can see some merit in the president's inviting dual appointees to join in the hearing of appropriate cases—for example, as members of full benches—but we believe the independence of the commission means these decisions should be left entirely to the president. As such, we propose moderating the weight the president would have to give to such appointments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I indicate on behalf of Labor that we do oppose what is proposed with respect to schedule 2, `Panels of the Commission'. We propose to delete this schedule, which makes industry panels of the commission optional rather than compulsory and which emphasises hearings of the commission by members of state industrial authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we oppose this amendment is that for a very long time the industrial panel system has been very successful in encouraging industry specific knowledge. Commissioners do develop specific knowledge about specific industries which can be very useful at times in dealing with both award matters and disputes that pertain to the panel. We believe this should not be put at risk by being at the discretion of the president, whoever that president may be from time to time. There is no reason for a preference for state members when issues of federal jurisdiction organisations are involved.

I was pleased that Senator Murray spoke in supporting this. There is obviously a tag team match between Senator Campbell, representing the government, and Senator Murray, representing the Democrats, with respect to their deal. We have seen other tag team operations, but I was pleased Senator Murray did speak on this amendment because it goes to only one word—that is, `particular'.

Frankly, we are not fussed whether you include `particular' or not. I do not know whether the Australian Democrats were convinced that this was some massive concession the government was handing out to them. Frankly, we can really see no good reason as to whether this amendment should be supported or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a nice word, though.

—It might be a nice word, but it is the effect the word has. Whether it is in or not, our advice is that it is of no particular consequence. Senator Murray might indicate to the Senate chamber why the word `particular' is being deleted. Why is it of such magnificent significance?

—Magnificent was definitely not the view we had of it. Senator Sherry is quite right: it is a minor, small, almost technical amendment. However, we did consider it an inference, if you like, that the president was to be given a far more directory role. I cannot really add to the motivation that I put up when I proposed it. Our intention was merely to claw it back a bit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Claw it back a bit? The Democrats got the word `particular' taken out, which Senator Murray has admitted is of little or no consequence. I would love to be bargaining against you, Senator Murray, if that is the maximum concession you could extract from the government on schedule 2. I would indicate, as I said earlier, we do oppose this schedule 2. On behalf of Labor, I do not intend to take up further time in debate. We are cognisant of time in terms of dealing with the debate on this bill. A significant amount of time was spent on the first schedule—and rightly so—with the objectives, and the principles laid out are very important. Therefore, I do not intend to make any further contribution on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

This change is part and parcel of the changes elsewhere in this bill with respect to the overriding power of state jurisdictions and the abolition of the bargaining division of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may note that Greens amendment No. 2 is precisely the same as the ALP's amendment No. 2. Therefore, we will be supporting their amendment because it is the same as ours. But in terms of the Democrat‐government amendment, it is slightly better than that which existed before. It is of no great consequence, and I see no point in opposing it, but, by the same token, I will be voting to delete the entire schedule. Therefore, it is simply a tiny change rather than the change that should be occurring.
Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

—The way in which we will put it will be that schedule 2, as amended, be agreed to.
