TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (line 2), after "filing" insert "and approval".

Amendment No. 9 is a technical amendment. It reflects the fact that the new part VID, which is to be inserted by government amendment No. 134, will confer on the Employment Advocate functions relating to the approval of AWAs and ancillary documents. The Employment Advocate, which was a central element of the coalition's pre‐election policy statement entitled `Better pay for better work', remains an integral element of the proposed new AWA scheme.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be opposing government amendment No. 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 9 amends clause 83BB, which outlines the functions of the Employment Advocate, to add the additional function of approving Australian workplace agreements. We obviously accept this amendment because it is an improvement in the bill as it stood. It might be worth noting, however, that we do oppose the move to individual contracts or AWAs. Consequently, we really do, in that sense, oppose the need for an Employment Advocate. But as we know this will be shoved through no matter what the rest of the community think, we will not oppose amendment No. 9.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (after line 14), at the end of section 83BB, add:
(2) In performing his or her functions, the Employment Advocate must have particular regard to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the needs of workers in a disadvantaged bargaining position (for example: women, people from a non-English speaking background, young people, apprentices, trainees and outworkers); and
(b) assisting workers to balance work and family responsibilities; and
(c) promoting better work and management practices through Australian workplace agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to require the Employment Advocate to have particular regard in the appointment to their functions to the needs of workers in a disadvantaged working position such as women, migrants, young people and outworkers; assisting workers to balance their work and family responsibilities; and promoting better work and management practices through Australian workplace agreements.

The approval function follows on from the amendments to schedule No. 11, which will allow the Employment Advocate to approve AWAs where there is no doubt that they fulfil the `no disadvantage' test. This ability to approve clearly above‐award agreements will allow a fairly simple administrative procedure to formalise the largely unregulated above-award contracting already going on in most small business workplaces. It will be quite clear that any AWA which looks doubtful will be referred to the AIRC in accordance with a protocol developed by the President of the AIRC with the concurrence of the advocate.

The three considerations that will be added to 83BB place a heavy onus on the Employment Advocate. The importance of these provisions will become apparent as we move through schedule 11—that is why I make reference to them now—particularly in relation to judgments that the advocate has to make about the bargaining process.

The amended bill will contain a wide range of protections of the bargaining process, including a requirement that all AWAs include appropriate provisions on discrimination; the requirement that the AWA is offered to all comparable employees in the same terms as should fairly or reasonably be offered the AWA; the requirement that the employer explain the effect of the AWA to the employee; and, most importantly, the requirement that the employee generally consents to making the AWA.

The considerations will also be important in the development of the information statement, prepared by the Employment Advocate, which all employers will be required to give to employees prior to signing the AWA. The considerations will also be important in the general assistance provided by the Employment Advocate to employees and employers, particularly in relation to representation for breaches. This also relates to proposed 83BB(2)(c), which carries a very pro‐active function—the requirement for the advocate to actually promote better work and management practices and to do that through AWAs. That could involve the development of pro forma clauses or agreements, seeking to present ideas to parties in developing an AWA and trying to improve productivity or fairness in the workplace. These are important considerations, and I commend amendment 10 to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the amendment, but, as Senator Margetts indicated in relation to the earlier amendment, only because it does make the Employment Advocate a little more palatable. When we get to the end of this schedule, we will be, of course, voting against the entire concept of an Employment Advocate. But what we are seeing vis-a-vis the government and Australian Democrats deal does soften the provisions somewhat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This becomes a little problematical. Amendment 10 also amends, as has been mentioned, clause 83BB to note that the Employment Advocate must have particular regard to certain issues in carrying out his or her functions, including the needs of disadvantaged workers, and to assist workers in balancing work and family responsibilities. Obviously they are admirable things to include in the role of the Employment Advocate.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that proposed subclause (c) says:
. . . promoting better work and management practices through Australian workplace agreements.

If we were to agree to amendment 10—in the past we have agreed to amendments which we thought would make a bad situation a little better—we would be seen to be agreeing that promoting better work and management practices can be done through Australian workplace agreements. It is not our opinion, on the balance, that that is the case.

PARA.BREAK: I know that in this particular instance the amendments are going to go through, anyway, because the deal has been signed. However, I do not want to put my name to an amend ment which says that better work and management practices will be achieved through Australian workplace agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We propose a series of amendments which can be moved in four parts. The Greens (WA) amendments relate to the functions of the Employment Advocate, the independence of the Employment Advocate, the delegation of the advice role to the community based advice centres and, finally, equity and access issues to do with the authorised officers of the Employment Advocate. I seek leave to move amendments 3, 4, 5 and 7 be moved together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 3, item 2, page 7 (after line 26), after paragraph (c), insert:

(ca) investigating the particular needs of women, persons whose first language is not English, young persons, disabled persons, part‐time and casual employees and others who may be disadvantaged in the labour market, and providing assistance and advice;
(4) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (lines 7 to 10), omit paragraph (g), substitute:
(g) providing free legal representation to an employee in a proceeding under Part VID or Part XA, unless the Employment Advocate determines that the employee's case is without merit.
(5) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (after line 14), at the end of section 83BB, add:
(2) An appeal lies to the Commission against a determination of the Employment Advocate under paragraph (1)(g).

(7) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (line 28), after "functions", insert ", other than the Employment Advocate's powers and functions in relation to prosecution, inspection and assessment of breaches of AWAs or contraventions of Part VID or Part XA,".

These amendments relate to the functions of the Employment Advocate. Amendment 3 requires the Employment Advocate to investigate the particular needs of women, persons whose first language is not English, young persons, disabled persons, part-time and casual employees and others who may be disadvantaged in the workplace and then to provide advice and assistance to these workers. The reality is that many of the people who fall into the categories listed in the amendment are going to become increasingly vulnerable in the move to individual contracts, which would be, unfortunately, such a fundamental part of this bill if it becomes law.

Amendment 4 includes a clause that requires the Employment Advocate to provide free legal representation under part VID, the Australian workplace agreement section of the act, or part XA, the freedom of association section of the act, unless the Employment Advocate determines that the employee's case is without merit. Amendment 5 provides for an appeal to the commission in relation to the determination by the Employment Advocate on free legal representation. Amendment 7 prevents the Employment Advocate from delegating its powers and functions in relation to prosecution, inspection and assessment of breaches of AWAs or contraventions of part VID or part XA.

On amendments 4 and 5, as I have said on a number of occasions, it is really quite important that, if you have agreements—and they really are agreements—and there is no bargaining that is actually part of the bill, and those so-called agreements are broken by the employer, the employees have at least the ability to access a remedy.

If companies have the ability to use their wealth to use the law against or intimidate employees, then it is hardly a fair contest. We think that, if people have a case that needs to be answered, they do need to have access to legal representation. If that is not available, then I guess it has to be admitted that are not dealing in any way, shape or form with anything like a level playing field. Both the ALP and the Greens have admitted that we do not see that this is any way, shape or form a level playing field. But if there is no access to legal assistance, then what we have is a farce.

Amendment 7, as I have mentioned, prevents the Employment Advocate from delegating its powers and functions in relation to prosecution, inspection and assessment of breaches of Australian workplace agreements. What on earth is going to happen if we have this precedent set, perhaps again and again, of delegating out prosecution? Who eventually is accountable for administering a law in that sense, to the point of prosecution, if those powers can be delegated out? I do not think it is appropriate that we have an Employment Advocate delegating those powers.

The perception of bias or the perception of corruption cannot be far from the surface when such important powers are delegated out. We believe it should also not include the delegation of powers of inspection, assessment of breaches of AWAs or contraventions of part VID or part XA because, basically, you can certainly delegate out advice functions. We look at that in our amendments. There are, I believe, not enough people around within the Employment Advocate to actually provide the full advice that we think is going to be necessary for all of the people who are going to need assistance with Australian workplace agreements. The assessment of breaches as a delegated function, I think, is not appropriate.

Therefore, I would urge the Senate to support Greens' amendments 3, 4, 5 and 7 because, if there is any semblance of access to remedy, at least we have to see whether or not there is any support for providing the resources for that. If the argument is that we have only provided $2.9 million for staffing for the Employment Advocate, you will have to ask: how will that assistance be available? If that Employment Advocate is, as has been mentioned, an employer advocate, how do you divide $2.9 million worth of staffing resources so that you really do provide—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's $12 million, isn't it?

—It is $2.9 million for staffing. The $12 million is mostly for the buildings and everything else—the overall cost. My understanding is that the actual amount available for staffing the Employment Advocate is $2.9 million per annum. That really is not going to go very far. We did estimate that, even at $50,000 per staff member, you are looking at between 50 and 60 staff—and in Western Australia maybe five or six. If the minister has different ideas from that, perhaps he can let me know. Perhaps they are intending to pay their staff less, and that might mean there might be more. However, it is hardly going to be enough to deal with all of the kinds of issues that are going to arise as a result of concerns people have about Australian workplace agreements. So I do urge support for our amendments 3, 4, 5 and 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to respond to two points that I think Senator Margetts may not have total information on. I just want to help her with some information. Firstly, there is the delegation of powers which she expressed concern about. The delegation only refers to Commonwealth officers and state officers. In the Commonwealth's respect, I am advised that they would be officers employed by the Office of the Employment Advocate. At the state level they would be officers of the various industrial relations departments. You may well have a concern about that, but I do not see there is a need for your concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there is the resourcing of the Employment Advocate. You mentioned a figure of $2.9 million. The figure is actually $12 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that was the budget for staff.

—Sorry. You mentioned that as the budget for staff. But $12 million is the resource, and that is quite considerable. My advisers say that there is no break-up provided. Twelve million dollars is provided, so I would be genuinely interested to find out where you got that information from. I am sure the minister in the other place would be interested, too.
—My office advises that the source of information is the project budget measures statement. Is this not the source of information you are using?
—We will all check our sources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, you could look at estimates transcripts. I think we did ask some questions about this, but I cannot recall the exact monetary responses we got in respect of the issues we asked about.

SPEECH.PARA: We will support the Greens' amendments. I just indicate to Senator Campbell, the parliamentary secretary, in case you think we are a little light on our contribution at the moment, we will be reserving the bulk of our contribution until we get to the end of these amendments. Obviously we have indicated that we are opposing schedule 3. We will be advancing arguments for our general opposition and also for our fall‐back position in support of our amendments in respect of schedule 3.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some more information on the $2.9 million. Apparently that was a half year guesstimate of resources based on some uncertainty as to when the act would come into effect. So that was the source of that figure, but it is $12 million for a full year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak against the amendments. We believe that amendment 3 is adequately dealt with by the changes to the performance of the Employment Advocate's functions in 83BB. Therefore, we oppose the amendment as unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to amendment No. 4, the onus on the advocate under the proposed bill to provide representation is already very high. The amendment, in our view, pushes that onus much too high. The fact that we are providing pre-vetting of agreements before they take effect to some extent reduces the need a little for representation, and we think the limited discretion in (g) should be retained. Indeed, the amendment could have the unintended consequences of removing resources from the advocate's important approval and vetting roles to representation. So we oppose that amendment.

Amendment 5, schedule 11, will provide that doubtful AWAs will be referred to the AIRC. We have also expanded the right to bargaining agents to appear in hearings. Given the higher approval conditions set down and the limited discretions given to the advocate, we do not believe that this amendment or the appeal is necessary.

We are opposed to amendment 7. If we are to get full value for money out of the higher cooperation between states and federal industrial authorities invested by this bill, we must provide some degree of flexibility to both the commission and the advocate on how they get there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As a point of clarification, the part of the industrial relations portfolio budget statements that I was referring to was on page 62, subprogram 1.6. That does separate out salaries and others, which was different from the statement that Senator Campbell made earlier. He did make some clarification but, in fact, that is what the statement said on page 62. It does separate out salary from other costs. The columns are headed `Salaries', `Running costs' and `Other'.

SPEECH.PARA: So I am assuming the `Other' relates to the setting up of offices and so on. We do not know from this statement what the subsequent year's allocation might be or whether it is going to be $12 million a year or whether there will be differential running costs for subsequent years. Perhaps you will be able to enlighten us, but it does say, `1996‐97'. Obviously, there will be different salary outcomes based on when this starts in the 1996‐97 year, and, obviously, `Running costs' and `Other' does not relate to salaries. There have been establishment costs; I am assuming the other running costs would not necessarily be the same in subsequent years. We have no idea from this statement what the subsequent allocations will be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very reliably informed that they are only guesstimates and that no decisions have been made as to those break‐ups.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the transcript of the estimates committee before me. I have the portfolio budget statements that we looked at in the estimates committee. We have the breakdown there, as Senator Margetts has pointed out, of salaries: $2.915 million. I seem to recall a figure from somewhere of $30 million over three years. Would that be correct?
—I will take that on notice, Senator Sherry, if that is okay with you.

—Would it be correct to assume—given the very high other costs of $9 million‐odd and salaries of almost $3 million for what will obviously be less than one year of operation in 1996‐97—that the salary costs will be substantially more than the $2.9 million for a full operational year?
—As I said earlier, no decisions have been made in relation to that.

—Do you have information on how far upwards the salaries figure will be revised—it is obviously going to go up—particularly now that you have got a fair idea of the outcome of this bill, given the deal you have between yourselves and the Democrats?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think at that stage that would have been pre‐empting the Senate debate and no‐one involved wanted to do that. Clearly that might have changed a little bit since then but, as I said, I am happy to provide you with further details and you have got a series of estimates processes coming up. I think this is really wavering into the areas that are quite properly—I am not saying you should not raise them and I have tried to give you as much information as I can—meant for consideration by the estimates process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got estimates coming up next year, after the delivery of the May budget. I would just make the point that it is not unusual—certainly we did it when we were in government and I know this government has done it in a number of other areas—to commence processes of cost evaluation before knowing the outcome of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give you one good example which I have been involved with—the proposed sale of Commonwealth Funds Management. I know that the minister has been ensuring that a whole process has begun on tendering for its ownership and the legislation has not even got to the Senate. So I do not necessarily accept your premise, but I will not press the issues. We would certainly like details of the costs as soon as possible once the legislation has been passed and certainly before next year, and there are other ways to obtain it if we do not get it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —These issues are very pertinent to the questions of what kind of remedy and assistance is available to people on Australian workplace agreements. The Employment Advocate has been used so often in the debate by the government as the means by which we can be assured that decency and fairness—and whatever other words have been thrown around—can be attained.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I am asking these questions is that we are going to get to the stage of finding this bill rammed through by agreement. So how long will it take before the first people are lining up at a door that does not exist yet to get assistance?

The kinds of questions I am asking in relation to my amendments are: roughly how many people can you assume will be available around Australia to assist them? If our figures have been wrong, perhaps let us know because does it mean that there will be coverage in regional Australia? Does it mean that each state will be covered in some way?

We assume that, when royal assent of this bill has been given, the individual contracts will start coming in, like the situation in Western Australia. Hamersley Iron was ready on the knocker when the Western Australian legislation came through. So we are not talking about something in the dim, distant future or something that might start occurring some time after a bill goes through because the evidence is clearly not that.

The evidence clearly is that those companies which would like to access the ability to put their workers on Australian workplace agreements are not going to be waiting until royal assent for their preparation. They will be ready on the knocker. A number of corporations and companies—a whole load of businesses throughout Australia—will be ready on the knocker for whenever this bill comes into law.

Therefore, if there is no real idea of what kind of numbers of actual people in places will be available, then any assurances we are given about the Employment Advocate are going to seem rather hollow. What will be the situation if, after this bill has gone through and whenever it is likely to get royal assent, we do have a line‐up of people who do not know where they can go or, worse still, you do not know where they can go to get that assistance which you claim will be the linchpin of fairness for Australian workplace agreements. I think it is fair that I am asking such questions. What kind of idea do you have of the spread and the number of people who might be available for resourcing these centres? What kind of spread could we expect if this bill goes through?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right, Senator Margetts; they are quite appropriate questions to ask. The government is, of course, quite keen to ensure that this legislation is an overwhelming success and that parts of it, like the Office of the Employment Advocate, work and work well and are accessible to people. The government is now doing that sort of work and, as I said to Senator Sherry, we will provide to the Senate the detailed responses to the questions that you have asked but those details are not available at the moment. Those sort of decisions are in the process of being made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to ask Senator Campbell a question. Given that the Employment Advocate will take on a sort of inspectorate role in relation to AWAs, I wanted some advice as to what is to occur to the section of the department which used to do the inspectorate role in terms of awards. I think it has most recently been called awards management section. I wonder if you can indicate whether or not the department will continue to play that role as inspectorate in terms of awards in the same way it has in the past, and whether or not its resources are going to be downgraded in order to provide inspectorate services within the Office of the Employment Advocate?

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the proposition, the Employment Advocate will take on inspectorate‐type services for the monitoring of AWAs. The debate we have been having has been about whether the allocation of funds is going to be sufficient for that task. I, like Senator Margetts, have some concerns about that proposition, because I think we found last time the coalition went down this path in the 1970s that the structure they set up to replace trade unionism in the Industrial Relations Bureau failed to meet that task of monitoring, inspecting and enforcing awards. So I would like to know what the relationship is between those two roles within the Office of the Employment Advocate and what funding and resourcing is going to be made available for the respective sections.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the inspectorate functions within the department will not be downgraded; they will continue to do the work they are doing on awards and certified agreements. As we have said earlier, additional resources will be made available through the OEA for the new functions in relation to AWAs. But your specific concern is in relation to resources. The same division will be doing the same inspectorate and the resources will be maintained at the same level.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to you that that is not quite correct. If we look at the portfolio budget statements for Industrial Relations, there is a reduction in salary allocation for the department. It will obviously have to affect the operations of the department. Will it affect the area that Senator Evans has referred to, because of that reduction in staffing allocation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to correct what I said in relation to the same level of resources. I am advised that there have been reductions there, but they are the same reductions that have applied through the general savings and efficiency dividend type processes that have been applied across the Commonwealth through the budget.

—Perhaps I could get down to a more basic question which the parliamentary secretary might be able to answer. Surely there must be an answer to this question. Has there been a decision as to whether there will even be state offices or has there been a general decision that these functions may be delegated to state authorities? Has there been a decision as to whether each state will have an office?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition government would fully expect that that would be the case but, as I have said earlier, those administrative decisions have not been taken. As I have said to both Senator Margetts and Senator Sherry in relation to these questions, I have given an undertaking to provide that information when those decisions are made.

—I want to ask a couple of questions that pertain to this matter. In particular, because of the issue of funding of staff, there is a provision to authorise persons who are appointed or employed by a state or a terri tory. In relation to that matter, and connected with another matter that I will raise, I would like to know if any arrangement has been pursued to this point for such delegation of appointed or employed persons with state or territories authorities to perform the functions delegated by the Employment Advocate? And I think consequentially making the assumption ultimately about the passage of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 this year, is there a proposed or intended date for the operation of this act? What timetables are we looking at to put in place the employees in question or the delegations in question?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very reliably informed—if this adviser is not wrong—that those decisions, as I have said in relation to the other matters, have not been made. In relation to negotiations with delegated authorities such as the states and the territories, as you mentioned, again the government regards that that would be premature. The commencement date clearly has not been considered at this stage. It would be extremely premature to do so. Of course, the administrative arrangements would need to be put in place as we move towards defining a commencement date.
—Chairman, can the minister, through you, assure us that this act will not come into operation until all of these arrangements are properly put into place?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the assurance you are seeking is understood. Clearly, the government wants to make this legislation work and make it work well. We want to put all of those arrangements in place before the act commences, particularly for Senator Margetts's queue that she is envisaging—probably in Kununurra, are you thinking, Senator Margetts, or somewhere else?
—Karratha.

—Karratha maybe. We obviously want to make sure that all of those arrangements will be put in place before that is the case. The government is quite keen to make sure that, when this is implemented, it is a roaring success and it all fires up and works like a well‐oiled machine. That is the intention and I think that is the assurance you sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are on the role of the Employment Advocate—talking about the inspectoral role—I ask the parliamentary secretary to comment on whether or not the powers and the role of the inspectorate will be equal to or as wide ranging as the current powers available to the award inspectorates. Obviously, we have serious concerns about the secrecy involved with AWAs and the likely negotiations with a lot of employees without representation. So I am trying to home in on the breadth of those powers, as well as the resources available to them. It might be best dealt with in a later section, in which case I will put that on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (line 19), after "Employment Advocate", insert "(other than powers or functions relating to the approval of AWAs and ancillary documents)".
(12) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (after line 20), at the end of section 83BC, add:
(3) A direction by the Minister is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .

These two amendments are about the independence of the Employment Advocate. Amendment No. 11 makes it clear that the advocate cannot be directed by the minister in the performance of the approval functions. The vetting of AWAs, in our view, is such an important function that it must remain with the advocate. Amendment No. 12 clearly establishes the statutory independence of the advocate, that is, ministerial directions to the advocate will be disallowable instruments. In some circumstances, it will be appropriate for the minister to give directions to the advocate, for example, in relation to financial admin istration and Public Service employment guidelines. But in other cases it would be inappropriate for the minister to give directions and those directions should be reviewed to ensure that parliament has a say in the continuing independence of this office.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, Labor will be making a more broad ranging contribution when we get to the end of this section. On this particular matter—`A direction by the Minister is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A'—why has the government not ensured that the Employment Advocate is totally independent? Why should there need to be any direction whatsoever by the minister to the Employment Advocate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 11 does amend the section relating to the minister's direction to the Employment Advocate by inserting a subclause that limits the minister's ability to direct in relation to the approval of Australian workplace agreements. We oppose ministerial direction as a matter of principle, but this is at least an improvement on open slather ministerial direction. We will, therefore, support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 12 further amends the section relating to ministerial direction by making ministerial directions disallowable instruments. Again, whilst we do not support ministerial direction, this is an improvement on unfettered ministerial direction and we will be supporting the amendment. However, whilst we will be adding other amendments, we also, in general, do not like the schedule. So, whilst we are hoping to make some improvements, we think the best improvement would be to get rid of the entire schedule.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Sherry's previous question in relation to the Employment Advocate, the gist of which was that you thought he should be entirely independent and not receive any ministerial direction whatsoever, the advice I have at the moment is that basically it leaves it open so that, for example, if the minister wanted to give a direction for special assistance to a particularly disadvantaged group, he would be able to do so through this enabling provision. However, in the event the minister was to give such a direction, clearly that direction, because of these provisions, is both published and disallowable, which I am sure the chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would applaud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Just following that through, I would have thought that, if the bill is ultimately passed, the act would empower and direct the Employment Advocate as to his duties in a very broad sense. I am extremely curious, given the answer, as to what directions might be given which are not already in the act. I would have thought that there is already direction in the objects of the act, if the objects ultimately become part of the act, to look after these specially disadvantaged people, or other classes of people, that you suggest might be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the concern that this provision generally raises—I take note of the comments of Senator Murray about them perhaps being administrative—would be better contained in relation to administrative instruction. Certainly, I would take it that the powers which would be vested in the Employment Advocate under the act would be subject to the financial provision by government for services. That will be a matter, as I understand it, proposed to be the subject of annual reporting to the minister and to the parliament.

Otherwise, I fear the circumstance will arise, as it has done with similar aspects of the industrial relations law in Tasmania, where there is provision for the minister, and only the minister—outside of the parties to an enterprise agreement in that state—to intervene in proceedings. In the case of the minister not intervening by regulation in a particular matter, the minister is open to criticism because he or she is the only person who can intervene.

If you follow this process of having to be gazetted, the steps which would need to be taken for the minister to intervene in any matter may well occur after the actions that the minister wanted to intervene in had taken place. It would seem to me to be a particularly clumsy aspect of this bill. It seems also to me to be drawn from other examples. My only experience of a similar example was an utter failure. I think that was evidenced in the evidence that the committee took when it went to Tasmania about the operation of the industrial relations legislation there and the complaints that the former enterprise commissioner made about the non-intervention of a minister in those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator O'Brien raises important issues, but we do believe that we have dealt with it properly in the legislation. For the sorts of reasons I explained in my earlier intervention, it is open. It is not only disallowable; it has to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette as well. That is a notice to the world that the minister has made this direction. They also have to be recorded in the annual report. There is a whole belt and braces approach to ensuring that, should the minister choose to make a direction in that regard, it is open for the world to see that that direction is being made.

SPEECH.PARA: To go back to the earlier point of your discussion, the functions are well and truly enumerated in the bill, as you would have read. This is a way for the minister to direct the Employment Advocate, particularly in an area where there was a need. For example, if you or another honourable senator were to come into the place in a couple of years and say, `Look, this is an absolute disaster; you said in the Senate two years ago, Senator Campbell, you were going to look after disadvantaged young Aboriginal people and there are examples all around the north-west of Australia or Queensland where they are not getting access,' the minister could create such a direction to ensure that the Employment Advocate assisted those people. That would be a quite proper direction.

BREAK.PARA: If this provision was not here, that sort of feedback and direction could not be made. With all of the checks and balances and disclosure as to when the minister does make a decision, publishing in the Gazette, publishing in the annual report and making it disallowable, it is very transparent to the community as to what those directions are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether this particular section as it is drafted carries out the objectives that the parliamentary secretary has told us about. He said that this section is aimed at enabling the minister to guide the Employment Advocate into particular areas where help is needed. But I am not sure that, as expressed, that is what this does. The particular section says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette , give directions specifying the manner in which the Employment Advocate must exercise or perform the powers or functions of Employment Advocate.

It does not say that the minister will be able to direct the Employment Advocate as to those people he or she will help or in what direction he or she will do it. It really goes to the issue of the machinery provisions as to how he is to carry out the particular objectives. It does not, as I read it, in any way deal with the objectives to which the Employment Advocate may direct his efforts.

Even if this section does allow the minister to direct the Employment Advocate as to where he or she might best place his or her efforts, does it not, as has been said, give the minister an overriding power? No doubt he or she would normally exercise it properly, but I doubt whether the minister would be the one who would be exercising the power. Does it not give those who in fact exercise the power the ability to pick and choose between those who may be helped and those who may not be helped? As has been pointed out before, does that ability that has been given to the minister not take away—to a significant extent in any event—the ability of the Employment Advocate to act independently?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having served with you on our committee, Senator Cooney, I am very aware of how genuine your concerns are. We do not think so, and I think we are protected because of that belt and braces approach to transparency.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —On the running sheet, the note says that government‐Democrats amendment No. 11 is in conflict with Greens (WA) amendments Nos. 6 and 10. I am not sure that they are in conflict. I think they might relate to each other; our advice is that they do not conflict with each other. But this is a further extension. I seek leave to move my amendments Nos. 6 and 10 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (lines 15 to 20), omit section 83BC, substitute:
The Employment Advocate is not subject to control or direction by the Minister.
(10) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (lines 12 to 13), omit subsection 83BF(2).

It is the Greens' belief that, if the Employment Advocate is to be effective, it must be independent of government and ministerial direction. In the aftermath of this move to individual contracts, an effective independent source of advice and assistance is absolutely essential.

Industrial relations law is complex even for those with a reasonable grasp of law and the industrial relations system. If an illiterate worker is given a contract by a prospective employer, they need to have the confidence to turn to an organisation such as a union or the Employment Advocate for advice that is seen to be independent of government interference. This was highlighted by the National Pay Equity Coalition in their submission to the committee. They stated:

The Employment Advocate is not independent. The Employment Advocate can be directed in carrying out his or her functions by the minister and the staff are public servants provided by the secretary of the Department of Industrial Relations.

We received what were intended to be assurances by the parliamentary secretary who said, `Don't worry; they will be from the Department of Industrial Relations.' But I do not think that necessarily helps. The provision that the Employment Advocate can be sacked for `incompetence and inefficiency' is another control mechanism. The submission concludes the section about the independence of the Employment Advocate by stating:
The role can have no credibility while it is subject to direct ministerial control and direction
Amendment No. 6 simply omits section 83BC and replaces it with a new section 83BC `Independence of office' which simply states:
The Employment Advocate is not subject to control or direction by the Minister.

Amendment No. 10 is a consequential amendment which deletes the reference to annual reporting of ministerial directions under section 83BF. If our amendment No. 6 is successful, the minister will not make any directions and therefore will not need to be reported to. I think it is reasonable if there are firm statements of goals for an Employment Advocate that that office is able to carry out those functions. I do not think it will be necessary for the minister to say, `Operate in this office or operate in that.' If there are firm functions, then, as a so‐called independent advocate, it should be possible for that responsibility to be taken, providing those goals are clearly stated, and the need will direct the operation, I would assume. I cannot see that ministerial directions in this sense, or having people operating under the direct control of the minister, will be of assistance in creating that independence which I think will be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that we support these particular Greens amendments. I also indicate that this issue of independence is very important to us. We will be dealing with that matter when we get to the end of the government‐Democrat amendments and we deal with our own proposed amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (13) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (after line 2), after subsection (1), insert:
(1A) The Employment Advocate's functions under Part VID relating to the approval of AWAs and ancillary documents can only be delegated to a member of the staff referred to in section 83BD.

This amendment will prevent the advocate from delegating any of the approval functions to anyone other than staff of the advocate. We believe that the approval function is so important that it must remain with the Employment Advocate's office itself, exercisable only by the staff provided to the office, by the public servants allocated to the office by the Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this but only on the basis that it is a slight improvement on what is an overall very poor deal that the Democrats have entered into with the government in respect of supporting the Employment Advocate. It does improve it minutely.

—I am a little confused here about whether we are in fact limiting the staff to the Employment Advocate or whether, by the delegation, we will have included in that not just the staff of the Employment Advocate but also the delegated staff from the Department of Industrial Relations. If that is the case, if I am not mistaken, then on balance I think, to be consistent, I would not be able to support government‐Democrat amendment 13.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —We are supporting this amendment, but I ask Senator Murray what effect that will have. The Employment Advocate's function under part VID relating to the approval of AWAs and ancillary documents can only be delegated to a member of the staff referred to in section 83BD. Section 83DB states:

SPEECH.PARA: The staff necessary to assist the Employment Advocate are to be persons appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and made available for the purpose by the Secretary to the Department.

That would seem to be very wide. Indeed, you might have people outside that who are much better equipped. We are supporting this amendment, so it will go through, but I just wonder what the practical effect of that is. It seems to me that you might in fact want to delegate outside, given that you have got a very wide power of delegation within it. Senator Murray, as your amendment reads, you could refer the approval of AWAs to any class of public servant within the Employment Advocate's office. It seems a very interesting situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, Senator Cooney, you make some good points. Our concern was obviously most of all to do with the wide delegation to persons who might not be appropriate in this function. This amendment inserts a new subsection. Without modification, the current section would have allowed the Employment Advocate's functions relating to the approval of AWAs or ancillary documents to be delegated to any person employed or appointed by the Commonwealth, a state or a territory. We thought that was a greater evil.

SPEECH.PARA: The new subsection prevents the Employment Advocate from delegating his or her approval function to persons who are not `staff' made available—it will not be the typist—to the Employment Advocate by the Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations, pursuant to the proposed section 83BD.

Under amendments proposed to schedule 11 of the bill, new part 60 of the act would confer various functions relating to the approval of AWAs and ancillary documents on the Employment Advocate—in other words, giving him considerable powers. This amendment will ensure the Employment Advocate is only able to delegate his or her approval function to public servants made available to him or her by the Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations. I would redirect your question to the government in that I am quite sure they would make sure that the persons appointed were appropriately senior, appropriately trained and appropriately competent.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (8) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (line 2), after paragraph 83BE(1)(b), insert:
and
(c) a person who is appointed or employed by a community‐based advice centre.
Note: Working Women's Centres and Women's Legal Centres are examples of community‐based advice centres.
(9) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (after line 6), at the end of section 83BE, add:
(4) After exercising powers or functions under a delegation, a person referred to in paragraph (1)(c) is entitled to reimbursement from the Employment Advocate of reasonable costs.

These amendments relate to the delegation of the Employment Advocate's advice role to community based advice centres. As indicated earlier, the advice role of the Employment Advocate is going to become increasingly important with the advent of individual contracts. The Greens propose that this advice function would be most appropriately delivered by community based groups, such as working women's centres and others, and that the Employment Advocate should be able to delegate that role to such groups and remunerate them accordingly. The National Women's Justice Coalition made the suggestion in their submission to the committee and stated:

If, as a result of these major changes, individuals are to be left to enforce their rights, public education about rights at work must be undertaken. In this context we note with disappointment the abolition of the Outworkers Entitlement Campaign which would have informed particularly isolated workers of their basic rights, especially those from a non-English speaking background. Employees will also need access to independent advice services to help them understand their entitlements and enable them to negotiate appropriate pay and conditions. We recommend that the Working Women's Centres and the Women's Legal Services should be involved in the provision of information, education and advice and should be properly resourced for this purpose.

Amendment 8 allows for the delegation of these roles by the Employment Advocate and amendment 9 requires the reimbursement of reasonable costs to those community based centres. It is my understanding that there will not be sufficient staff available at the Employment Advocate to provide that advice. If that Employment Advocate is operating for both the employee and the employer, then it seems reasonable that people should be able to access advice that they can feel comfortable with in relation to Employment Advocate services.

There are people who are already providing that kind of advice—they are already very strained in their ability to provide the services that are being required of them even now—but it does not seem unreasonable if, in reality, people are seeking independent advice and are directed to these other sources of independent advice that those sources be able to access resources and some form of remuneration for the service they are providing. That is why I am commending amendments 8 and 9.

If as an outcome of the bill, which is likely to be passed, we are going to put a great deal more pressure on people providing services, I believe it is reasonable that those services be at least adequately resourced. Otherwise, we are in fact limiting people to a one‐stop shop.

I refer to one particular example of women union officials ringing the office of the workplace commissioner in Western Australia to get advice but were told to go to their union or told to go somewhere else. You wonder in this instance who in fact is resourced to give that advice. If people will be directed to other bodies to provide the advice which I do not think the workplace advocate will have the resources to provide, then it is not unreasonable to make sure there is some ability to provide resources to those groups who will be necessary, I believe, in the process of providing that absolutely essential advice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate we will support the Greens amendment. We will deal with the matters raised more generally at the conclusion of the government‐Democrats amendments.

—These amendments are, in our view, unnecessary. Community based advice centres are primarily that—advisory. The bill already makes it clear that the advisory functions of the advocate can be delegated to them, under subsection 83BE(2). For that reason, we oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to respond to that. Senator Murray said that the bill makes it clear that advice functions can be delegated. We know that. If there is reasonable recognition in the bill, some actual official recognition, that says that those functions can be delegated, then the centres to which the functions will be delegated will be resourced reasonably. It is not unreasonable to say that if functions are delegated then resources are also delegated. If the functions but no resources are delegated then the whole thing becomes somewhat farcical.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (after line 24), after subsection 83BG(1), insert:

(1A) The Employment Advocate must not appoint a person as an authorised officer unless that person has received or is receiving training in the provision of advice and information to disadvantaged groups, which include, but are not limited to, women, persons whose first language is not English, young persons, disabled persons and part‐time and casual employees.
(12) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (after line 24), after subsection 83BG(1), insert:
(1B) The Employment Advocate must ensure that an authorised officer working with persons whose first language is not English has appropriate language skills.

The Greens feel that the Employment Advocate should appoint officers who are trained in the provision of advice to disadvantaged groups and also appoint sufficient officers who have appropriate language skills for workers from non-English speaking backgrounds.

Again, the Employment Advocate will play an increasingly important role. It is important that the officers of that body have appropriate skills to deal with vulnerable workers. The National Pay Equity Coalition also highlighted this issue in their submission. They stated:

The Employment Advocate should be required to ensure staff are adequately trained to provide advice and information for members of disadvantaged groups. Provision will have to be made for translators to be employed and/or funded and for Employment Advocate services to be widely available at the local level perhaps through contracting with youth organisations, working women centres, migrant resources centres or youth access centres, et cetera.
Amendment 11 deals with the need for authorised officers to have received or be receiving training in the provision of advice to disadvantaged groups.

Amendment 12 deals with the need for authorised officers to have appropriate language skills. We realise this training might not be able to be right on the knocker should this bill come into force. However, it does not seem unreasonable that those people who undertake that role should be in the process of receiving training to make sure they are able to handle those requirements.

It is obviously the people from the most vulnerable groups who have these greatest concerns. They want to know that there will be recognition that this last line of defence, the Employment Advocate, is going to be not only possibly able but able to handle properly these kind of concerns from the most disadvantaged groups who are already being shown to be disadvantaged by enterprise bargaining, let alone what we are likely to see under individual contracts under the Australian workplace agreements. I commend amendments 11 and 12 to the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the amendments. As I said earlier, we will make a broader contribution on this matter when we reach the end of the government‐Democrats amendments.

—These essentially are again, in our view, unnecessary, although argued with merit—the first, and by that I refer to amendment 11, because this is a requirement that does not apply to inspectors appointed to awards management branch under section 84 of the current Industrial Relations Act. One would expect that these inspectors are likely to be those authorised by the advocate under section 83BG to be authorised officers.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 12 does have merit but I believe is picked up largely under the new requirement for the advocate to have particular regard to workers of a non-English speaking background under new paragraph 83BB(2)(a). Such regard would obviously extend to appointing authorised officers capable of conversing with such workers. For those reasons, we oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I do think I need to make a comment in relation to Senator Murray's statements. So far awards have been put together in a certain way, with the negotiation of unions, in Australia. However, where there has been negotiation and agreement up to now is in relation to the 1993 industrial relations bill, which allowed for enterprise agreements. In the 1993 bill it was the Greens also who, amongst others, were calling for the ability of those people in the work force without English as a first language and who were in a minority in the workplace to be taken into consideration. We were out there batting for the same groups of people back in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say that there were some improvements in the 1993 bill for enterprise agreements. It is not sufficient to say that the awards management branch does not have those skills and requirements. Awards were quite different from, firstly, enterprise agreements, which did end up with some changes which allowed for checking to make sure that minority groups within an enterprise agreement were satisfied and understood the conditions .

Secondly, what we are dealing with here is individual contracts. That makes it much more important in relation to those skills being available than was the case under awards, because at least with the awards people knew what they were up for. They did not have to individually fight the system. They did not have to individually negotiate their own agreement. That is what the difference is, and that is why it is even more important.

I do not think it is sufficient to say it did not exist under the awards management branch, because this is a whole new shooting match. Therefore, it is not unreasonable to say that if any assurance is to have credence it should be the assurance that those people who are most vulnerable will not be worse off under this bill. I cannot see anything but them being worse off if they do not have those assurances that that assistance is going to be part of the system.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer now to government‐Australian Democrat amendment No. 14, which proposes new section 83BT. This, in our view, is a very important provision. It makes it clear that the Employment Advocate can publish and make available copies or extracts from AWAs and ancillary documents provided the identity of the parties is kept secret. Obviously the EA would have to have regard to the right of the privacy of the parties in accordance with established privacy principles, but this would be balanced against the important public interest considerations in ensuring that appropriate bodies, such as HREOC, have the information to track what is happening in the labour market and whether it is fair. Salary comparisons are particularly important in determining whether equal remuneration or equal pay principles are being applied.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment fits the requirements set out by the unions, ACOSS, HREOC and the Senate inquiry that the content of AWAs must be capable of research and analysis to ensure that trends in bargaining are tracked. The provisions would also, for example, allow the Employment Advocate to reproduce clauses or whole AWAs which could serve as models for future agreements.
It should also be pointed out that even the restrictions on disclosure of the identity of the parties does not apply where the disclosure is authorised by the AWA party or by regulations. I move:
(14) Schedule 3, item 2, page 16 (after line 17), at the end of Division 4, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 83BT Publication of AWAs etc. by Employment Advocate

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to section 83BS, the Employment Advocate may publish or make available copies of, or extracts from, AWAs or ancillary documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, with respect to section 83BS, the secrecy provision, we oppose that. I do not intend to make that a major focus this afternoon. When we get to awards later on I am sure we will have a lot to say about this secrecy provision because we do not believe it is appropriate and we oppose it very strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to be very brief because I do not want to make a comment when we get to a broader debate in opposing this section later on. I am surprised you say, Senator Murray, that this is a very important amendment when the word `may' is in there. If it was the word `shall', I could understand. But the final decision about the publishing of anything is left with the Employment Advocate. The Employment Advocate decides that if he or she is not going to publish then they are not going to publish. Again, we do not see, frankly, that this is much of an improvement other than that `perhaps some information may be published'.

You raise the issue of the researchers. They may not get access because of the word `may'. If you wanted to limit it purely to researchers for publication and some overall evaluation of the worth of AWAs, why not have the word `shall' in there and some quite specific provisions in relation to access for researchers as matter of right? We certainly do not see anything significant or very important about the word `may' when the Employment Advocate can still do what they like.

As for the broader issue of secrecy provisions, we vehemently oppose them and I am sure we will make much more comment about that later on when we get to award matters. As far as I can see, this is a bit like the discussion we had earlier about deleting the word `particular'. It looked like a magnificent victory, but, frankly, does not mean a great deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, the minister clearly indicated to us that he was happy to accept that it was highly desirable that, in as many circumstances as possible, this informa tion should be made available along the grounds that I have outlined. I am sure the government benches can confirm that.

—I cannot quite see that 83BT has any effect at all, because it is subject to section 83BS. Section 83BS is the law. It itself defines what may be released, because subsection (1) sets out what is to be precluded from the public. With that provision subject to section 83BS, it does not seem to me to take the matter any further at all.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to take this opportunity to provide to the Senate the confirmation that Senator Murray sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment 14 of the Australian Democrats and the government adds a new section relating to the publication of Australian workplace agreements by the Employment Advocate. This obviously, as has been mentioned, appears to be better than what existed. Honourable senators might note that on document 217 I will be moving two amendments—my amendments Nos 1 and 2—to amend the amendment. So, whilst I might agree to the amendment as an interim, I would agree with the speakers so far that the word `may' is not sufficient.

SPEECH.PARA: If we do in fact have a situation—and governments, as we well know, have no direction over the Employment Advocate—they will not be able to tell them how many they should or should not make available. If the Employment Advocate decides not to make many documents available, if they have had strong arguments from employers that the world as they know it will end if they publish documents even without names, it may well be that the government has no control over the level of secrecy that actually ensues as a result of that.

Whilst we might support the amendment, I flag that I will be seeking to amend the amendment to replace the word `may' with the word `must' and include in that the normal ability to keep the names of the personnel private, which does not then impinge on people's privacy. Therefore, although I support the amendment as it stands, it is only as a means of trying to improve it further so it actually does provide some means for people to get access to assistance in relation to their individual contract. Therefore, I seek leave to move my amendments to the proposed amendment.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Omit "may", substitute "must".
(2) At the end of section 83BT, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) In publishing or making available information under subsection (1), the Employment Advocate must ensure that any personal information, including the names of employers and employees, is deleted to protect the privacy of the parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, I think Senator Murray has been conned by the government in this area for the reasons that have been outlined by Senator Cooney and Senator Margetts and the issue I raised. We have very strong views about secrecy. We will be expressing them in the award section, but I think it is appropriate to remind Senator Murray over and over again of page 342 of this report. I need read no further than the first sentence, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats believe that AWAs should not be secret documents.
Amendments (Senator Margetts's) negatived.
Government-Democrat amendment No. 14 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 3, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I said in the beginning that the outcome should probably be that the schedule should be opposed, and I guess I knew what the outcome of our amendments would be. It is my opinion on balance that the employment advocate perhaps had the potential to have some better elements in it than what it has ended up with. But, in the final wash‐up, without the amendments we have asked for, it really does not have a lot to commend it. Unfortunately, I do not think it will have the ability to provide anything like balanced or independent advice or advocacy.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact it is providing advice, if you like, for two sides of an argument simultaneously builds into it an automatic conflict of interest. Therefore, I would agree with the ALP that, overall, opposing the schedule is the wisest thing to do. Quite frankly, if those very small things we thought would be necessary to provide some sort of assistance to people, some sorts of assurances, cannot be agreed to, we are really left with something which probably does not deserve support at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

—I do have notes here, and I will mention them to you so you know what I have in front of me. If the schedule is agreed to, you would then move by leave that schedule 3 be reconsidered and then you have further amendments to the document.
—So long as it is clear that is the technical procedure we have to go through.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 3, as amended, agreed to.
Motion (by Senator Sherry)—by leave—agreed to:
That schedule 3 be reconsidered.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

Employee Ombudsman means the Employee Ombudsman referred to in Part IVA.
(2) Schedule 3, item 2, page 7 (line 12), omit the heading to Part IVA, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part IVA—The Employee Ombudsman and the Employment Advocate

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 3, item 2, page 7 (after line 12), after the heading to Part IVA, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 1A—Functions, powers etc. of the Employee Ombudsman

PARA.TAB: There is to be an Employee Ombudsman.
The Employee Ombudsman has the following functions:
(a) providing assistance and advice to employees about their rights and obligations under this Act;
(b) providing advice to employees about their rights and obligations under any applicable award, certified agreement or AWA;
(c) investigating on behalf of employees alleged breaches of awards, certified agreements and AWAs, and any other complaints relating to awards, certified agreements or AWAs;
(d) investigating on behalf of employees alleged contraventions of any of the provisions of this Act;
(e) providing free representation to employees in:

TAB.TAB: (i) the making, varying or terminating of an AWA;
(ii) any proceedings for approval of an AWA, its variation or termination; and
(iii) any other proceedings under any of the provisions of this Act;

PARA.TAB: (f) providing aggregated statistical information to the Minister;
(g) any other functions given to the Employee Ombudsman by this Act or any other Act.
The Employee Ombudsman is not subject to control or direction by the Minister.
The staff necessary to assist the Employee Ombudsman are to be persons appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and made available for the purpose by the Secretary to the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) As soon as practicable after the end of each financial year, the Employee Ombudsman must prepare and give to the Minister a report on the operations of the Employee Ombudsman during that year.

PARA.TAB: The Employment Advocate has the following functions:
(a) providing assistance and advice to employers (especially employers in small business) about their rights and obligations under this Act;
(b) providing advice to employers (especially employers in small business) about their rights and obligations under any applicable award, certified agreement or AWA;
(c) providing assistance to employers in small business in the development of AWAs;
(d) investigating on behalf of employers in small business alleged contraventions of Part XA of this Act;
(e) providing free representation to employers in small business in any proceeding under Part XA of this Act;

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (lines 15 to 20), omit section 83BC, substitute:

PARA.TAB: The Employment Advocate is not subject to control or direction by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 3, item 2, page 8 (line 26) to page 9 (line 6), omit section 83BF(2).
(7) Schedule 3, item 2, page 9 (lines 12 to 13), omit subsection 83BF(2).
(8) Schedule 3, item 2, Division 2, page 9 (line 16) to page 11 (line 35), omit "Employment Advocate" (wherever occurring), substitute "Employee Ombudsman or Employment Advocate respectively".
(9) Schedule 3, item 2, page 10 (lines 10 to 19), omit subsection (1), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) An authorised officer appointed by the Employee Ombudsman may exercise powers under this section ( compliance powers ) for the purpose of:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Schedule 3, item 2, page 15 (after line 6), after Division 3, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 3A—Appointment, conditions of appointment etc, of Employee Ombudsman

PARA.TAB: (1) The Employee Ombudsman is to be appointed by the Governor‐General for a term of up to 5 years.
(2) The Employee Ombudsman holds office on a full-time basis.

(1) The Employee Ombudsman is to be paid the remuneration that is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. However, if no determination of that remuneration by the Tribunal is in operation, the Employee Ombudsman is to be paid the remuneration that is prescribed by the regulations.
(2) The Employee Ombudsman is to be paid such allowances as are prescribed by the regulations.
(3) This section has effect subject to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 .
The Employee Ombudsman must not engage in any paid employment outside the duties of the office without the Minister's written approval.
(1) Subject to section 87E of the Public Service Act 1922 , the Employee Ombudsman has such recreation leave entitlements as are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

(2) The Minister may grant the Employee Ombudsman other leave of absence on such terms and conditions as the Minister determines. The terms and conditions may include terms and conditions relating to remuneration.
The Employee Ombudsman may resign by giving the Governor-General a signed resignation notice.

The Employee Ombudsman must give written notice to the Minister of all interests, pecuniary or otherwise, that the Employee Ombudsman has or acquires and that could conflict with the proper performance of the Employee Ombudsman's functions.
(1) The Governor-General may terminate the appointment of the Employee Ombuds man for physical or mental incapacity, misbehaviour, incompetence or inefficiency.
(2) The Governor-General must terminate the appointment of the Employee Ombudsman if the Employee Ombudsman does any of the following:

TAB.TAB: (a) is absent from duty (except on leave of absence) for 14 consecutive days, or for 28 days in any period of 12 months;
(b) becomes bankrupt;
(c) applies to take the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors;
(d) compounds with his or her creditors;
(e) assigns his or her remuneration for the benefit of his or her creditors;
