(g) engages in paid employment outside the duties of the office, without the Minister's written approval.

PARA.TAB: (3) If the Employee Ombudsman is:

TAB.TAB: (a) an eligible employee for the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976 ; or
(b) a member of the superannuation scheme established by deed under the Superannuation Act 1990 ;
the Governor-General may, with the consent of the Employee Ombudsman, retire the Employee Ombudsman from office on the ground of physical or mental incapacity.

PARA.TAB: (4) For the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976 , the Employee Ombudsman is taken to have been retired from office on the ground of invalidity if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Employee Ombudsman is removed or retired from office on the ground of physical or mental incapacity; and
(b) the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 2 gives a certificate under section 54C of the Superannuation Act 1976 .

PARA.TAB: (5) For the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1990 , the Employee Ombudsman is taken to have been retired from office on the ground of invalidity if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Employee Ombudsman is removed or retired from office on the ground of physical or mental incapacity; and
(b) the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 1 gives a certificate under section 13 of the Superannuation Act 1990 .

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister may appoint a person to act as Employee Ombudsman:

TAB.TAB: (a) if there is a vacancy in the office of Employee Ombudsman, whether or not an appointment has previously been made to the office; or
(b) during any period, or during all periods, when the Employee Ombudsman is absent from duty or from Australia or is, for any reason, unable to perform the duties of the office.

PARA.TAB: (2) Anything done by or in relation to a person purporting to act under this section is not invalid merely because:

TAB.TAB: (a) the occasion for the appointment had not arisen; or
(b) there was a defect or irregularity in connection with the appointment; or
(c) the appointment had ceased to have effect; or
(d) the occasion to act had not arisen or had ceased.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 83BQ Other terms and conditions of appointment

PARA.TAB: The Employee Ombudsman holds office on such terms and conditions (if any) in respect of matters not provided for by this Act as are determined by the Governor‐General in writing.

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Schedule 3, item 2, page 15 (line 10), after "the", insert "Employee Ombudsman or the".
(12) Schedule 3, item 2, omit section 83BS, page 15 (line 19) to page 16 (line 17).

We are reconsidering schedule 3. That is the procedural process we have to go through in order to deal with the amendments that we have circulated. As I indicated earlier, we are fundamentally opposed to the creation of the Office of the Employment Advocate and my colleagues will outline a range of their concerns about the creation of this position and the associated officers.
We believe the Employment Advocate is totally ill-conceived and unnecessary. In fact, it reminds us in many ways of the old Industrial Relations Bureau.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's just as faulty.
—Exactly. One of my colleagues will comment in greater detail about the old IRB, but it certainly seems to us that this is the recreation of the old IRB in another form.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe the Employment Advocate is ill-conceived because it has potentially conflicting functions of advising and representing both employees and employers, and I am sure my colleagues will draw the Senate's attention to the areas in which that conflict occurs. It is unnecessary because all the proposed functions of this new Employment Advocate can be, or are, performed by the Department of Industrial Relations. We had an example of this earlier when my colleague Senator Evans and others asked questions about the budgeting.

We already have the Department of Industrial Relations providing advice and assistance about awards, AWAs and investigations into breaches or contraventions. Why set up another bureaucratic organisation—I do not use the term `bureaucratic' as a form of abuse—a dual purpose organisation, a second organisation, when we already have an effective operating organisation in the Department of Industrial Relations?

I recall the rhetoric of the government in the lead-up to the last election—certainly, for years preceding that—complaining about bureaucratic overlap, duplication and additional costs. As we touched on earlier, the Employment Advocate will cost $12 million in the first year. We do not have the budget details for subsequent years, but it will certainly be substantial. Why this added cost?

As a matter of observation, we have heard complaints from the government about the enormous size of some of the acts. We often had reference to the various tax acts in respect of their expanding nature, their detail and of hundreds of pages being added. As a consequence of this whole range of amendments, we will be adding to the industrial legislation. As a matter of principle—for reasons we have outlined and will continue to outline—we just do not believe it is an appropriate approach. The commission files AWAs. Why are we creating another organisation to overlap? The Employment Advocate that is proposed is also flawed, because it will provide free legal representation only where it considers this would promote the enforcement of the provisions of the act.

Senator Margetts, in her questions earlier, raised the issue of what the budget allocation will be in respect to people who want to access it. We do not know what it is going to be at the moment. Knowing this government's performance with respect to budget matters—we have already seen it with legal aid—there will not be sufficient moneys allocated even in the restricted form in which it is proposed under these provisions. We also have the additional problem of its independence being compromised because it is subject to ministerial direction, albeit we now have a disallowable instrument.

In our fall back amendments that have been circulated we create another body called the Employee Ombudsman. That is obviously not our first priority. That Employee Ombudsman is to provide advice, assistance and representation to employees only. The provisions concerning the Employment Advocate are amended so that it will provide advice and assistance to employers only. So we eliminate this conflict of interest embodied within the government's schedule 3. Also, the Employment Advocate that advises employers will be able to represent small business employers. We also provide for free legal representation that is not subject to any qualification, and we ensure that both bodies are completely free of ministerial direction.

In briefly outlining some very fundamental concerns about the Employment Advocate and in outlining our proposals, my colleagues will make contributions about specific areas of their own concern. But I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the report of the Senate Economics References Committee and quote Senator Murray again—surprise, surprise! Page 343, under the heading `Office of the Employment Advocate', states:

The Democrats do not agree with the conclusion of the Majority report on the role of the Employment Advocate, although we share the concern that the role and the independence of the Office are not properly refined in the bill. Professor Ron McCallum argued that the office is being given two largely incompatible roles of advising employers and employees on AWAs and investigating breaches. He concluded that these two roles would be difficult to operate together. He advocated the adoption of the Employee Ombudsman model from the South Australian legislation, which has the function of advising employees only.
The Democrats see merits in this approach. So do we—we see merits in this approach.

So I am happy to dub this amendment that we are to move the Murray amendment No. 2. We are happy to move, at the urging of the Australian Democrats, an amendment that is based on the fundamental flaws they saw in relation to the Employment Advocate. It really is a matter of regret to us, Senator, that, in reaching your deal with the government—the apparently signed, sealed document that has been circulated—you did not recognise the fundamental flaw that you did recognise some months ago when the committee was meeting and then reporting.

As I say, we are fundamentally opposed to the creation of the Employment Advocate, but we do believe that, if we have to compromise by putting forward these fall-back amendments that you suggested, it is certainly better than what we are confronted with in respect of the Employment Advocate both in the original bill and the amendments that we have just been considering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very obvious that Senator Murray has been rolled in his party room on these issues, because there is no doubt that the deal that has been done is incompatible with the report.
—You will find that you get rolled in yours occasionally, too.

—Thanks, Senator Ferguson, but perhaps not as much as you do. The deal that has been done obviously overrides the principled position which was put in the supplementary report which was placed before the Senate with the credibility of Senator Murray behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry has already put before the Committee the ALP's position on the splitting of the Employment Advocate into bodies that do not have internal conflicts of interest. In relation to a body of this sort, there is nothing in history which is able to demonstrate and, therefore, convince us that this is workable. That a conflict of interest is fundamental.

BREAK.PARA: A similar body called an enterprising bargaining unit was established by legislation in Tasmania. I had the personal experience of dealing with a case involving an enterprising bargaining unit in the relevant department which was charged with the responsibility of similarly advising employees and employers and facilitating these sorts of agreements. The conflict of interest was impossible to overcome.

It came to a point where a group of employees, all under the age of 20, employed in a small bakery in Burnie were confronted with an agreement which had been drafted by the enterprise bargaining unit—the equivalent of this Employment Advocate. They were advised of their rights in relation to the agreement—whether it was right or wrong or whether there were any problems with it. At the same time, that unit—the equivalent of this Employment Advocate—was advising the employer on how they would go about getting the agreement approved. It was an impossible conflict of interest.

The agreement ultimately was not approved in that case. In these cases we will be dealing with one-to-one circumstances. But ultimately the unit was disbanded because it was so fundamentally flawed as an authority which would purport to give advice to both sides of the picture.

We go on to other questions. Even if you can get over that fundamental problem, which I suggest you cannot, the Employment Advocate, who is obviously one person, is going to have staff to do all this work. The advocate is going to delegate some of those duties to persons who are employed by a state or a territory, apparently, and they are also going to delegate functions to other persons, who, at this point, are not identified.

PARA.BREAK: I turn to the function of the Employment Advocate. They are going to look at these Australian workplace agreements and make a judgment as to whether the agreements satisfy the tests that are laid down in the legislation. There is nothing in this bill which says anything in relation to the standard of the person—what qualifications or training that person would undergo. On the other hand, the Industrial Relations Commission has a signifi cant team of professional people who are able to review these matters in the light of legislative tests and make decisions.

BREAK.PARA: I would think that the Democrats, and certainly Senator Murray, would have to be extremely concerned that what is going to come out of this is some bureaucratic arrangement whereby class 2 or class 3 public servants are going to be making these decisions that at the moment are being made, in a variety of circumstances, by members of the Industrial Relations Commission. For example, in the state of Tasmania this would be effectively the equivalent of a deputy presidential member of the Industrial Relations Commission. But in this case there are no guarantees whatsoever, other than it is going to be vetted by the Employment Advocate, but more likely by a delegated Commonwealth public servant who is appointed or employed under the Public Service Act of 1922.

Of course, that act might change. There has been some comment in the media about what might or might not happen with the Public Service Act. So the next thing that we might find in relation to this bill is that the intent is outflanked by a change to that act. So there are not very many guarantees at all that the Democrats have received in relation to the Employment Advocate and there are no certainties.

To the extent that the Employment Advocate can delegate powers only to that class referred to in 83BE(1)(a), there is at least a little certainty, but not very much. But the other functions can be delegated to any person who is employed by a state or a territory. No qualifications are specified in the bill. No requirements are specified in the bill. The functions can be delegated to any person. It is a pretty shoddy piece of legislation in that regard. Section 83BE(2) states:
(2) The Employment Advocate may, by written instrument, delegate a function referred to in paragraph 83BB(a), (b) or (c) to any person.

Effectively (a), (b) or (c) are the advisory functions—either individually to employees or employers or collectively to those two groups. There is no certainty as to who the Employment Advocate might appoint. There is no direction in the legislation. If the Democrats are relying upon ministerial direction, the only power they have over that is possibly having that matter come before this Senate and disallowing it.

So there is no positive power that this body has in relation to those directions. It is only a negative power. So, if no direction is given and if it is an inadequate function, this parliament has effectively said, `We have no control other than by perhaps censuring the minister.' So this is an aspect of the legislation that is full of holes.
I heard that under New Zealand's legislation the Hell's Angels motorbike gang were setting themselves up as bargaining agents. Perhaps it is possible that they will be seeking to become advisers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have negotiated with people like that myself.

—Yes. It would be a very interesting exercise to establish these people as advisers. In trying not to be too flippant about it, I understand that some employer organisations have stated that they would be prepared to accept the responsibility of giving this advice. Recently, I put before the Senate an example where, under the Tasmanian legislation, an employer organisation did just that in relation to the enterprise legislation that applies in the state of Tasmania under state law. It was an entirely unsatisfactory position: the employer controlled the circumstances, and the employees were receiving advice from the employer's industrial relations adviser. At the same time, when the unions sought to give advice, the employer directed employees to tear up a small written document—which made a few basic suggestions—and throw it in the bin.

BREAK.PARA: So here we have a situation where the Employment Advocate can legitimise that and say, `Well, we are directing the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to be the adviser to the employees and the employers in connection with AWAs, to advise about the relevant award and statutory entitlements and about the relevant provisions of the act.' That really is an entirely unsatisfactory set of circumstances that arises out of the bill before the parliament. It ought to be reconsidered in that light.

I can only say that, in terms of the many other problematic aspects of this bill, when you combine this extremely shoddy schedule with the tests that are to be applied—and I accept that the Democrats have made some moves to make them somewhat more acceptable—to this absolutely unworkable and demonstrably flawed section of the bill, it is going to be a disaster in implementation.

When you come to the question of how many people will be needed to perform the functions that are required—remembering that there is nothing in this bill which guarantees just how many agreements will be approved—you need to consider that there is a possibility that there will be many thousands of employees who are asked whether they want to sign an agreement. If you take the most generous view in the world about how people will have real freedom of choice—which we have said in many cases will not exist—and there are thousands of people out there who want advice, where are they going to get it?

Certainly, with the budgetary allocation that has been suggested, there is no way that the Employment Advocate is going to be able to employ people and establish offices in all of the centres and all of the regions where employers operate around the country. I can tell you that, in my state and in most others, the state governments do not have the resources to provide the advice. The state governments do not have the resources to do the policing. They do not do it now in relation to their own state awards, so why are they going to accept an additional responsibility unless the Commonwealth is going to give them additional funds? The state governments are basically going to say, `If you're not going to pay us, why would we want to be appointed?'

So more money is going to come out of the budget if you are going to do this properly but, if you are not going to do it properly, this provision will be a sham. In terms of the evidence, this provision will be a sham. There will be no proper advice. You will have the situation where there will be pressure. If the agreements are going before the Employment Advocate, how many public servants are there going to be available to vet the agreements and give them proper consideration? How much are you going to pay them? You have been talking about how much money the Labor Party needed to spend. If you are going to do this job properly, there will be many millions of dollars that need to be put into this area. Alternatively, it just will not work properly and it will be even more unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do want to respond to a number of the points that Senator O'Brien has made, because I think in many respects they are based on either false premises or perhaps an intention to create the belief in the community that this Office of the Employment Advocate is going to be some sort of disastrous event for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very hard to believe that anyone could seriously advocate that the establishment of an office, well funded and well resourced, which is there to provide information and advice to both employees and employers, with a special mandate to look after disadvantaged employees, with the opportunity to delegate its authority—
Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —For Senator Margetts's benefit, to community centres that might have special affinity—
—But no resources.
—Senator Margetts interjects that there are no resources. She came into this place less than an hour ago—
—You said, `No resources to the community centres.'

—Senator Margetts, I have been standing here and I have been monitoring, relatively closely, what has been coming out of my mouth. I did not say that at all. The point I will make, however, is that you came in here about an hour ago and said, `These people are only getting $2.9 million a year.'
—No—to community centres.
—When I corrected you and said it was actually—
—That is a gross distortion of what she said.
—She said $2.9 million. Did she say $2.9 million?
—She asked you a question about centres.
—Yes, that is right, and we clarified it and clarified it and now she is saying there are no resources.
—We didn't want to give any money to them. It is a waste of money.

—I know you would not give any money to them. The Greens do not want to give any money. This is the position: the Greens have said that, if we supported the Green amendments, they would have supported the Office of the Employment Advocate. We all saw the Green amendments; we saw what Senator Margetts very eloquently argued in terms of amendments.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Murray and I argued why we did not need those amendments. We established, at least to the agreement of the majority of senators, that those changes were not necessary because the bill as it stands achieves what Senator Margetts wants. After that, she said, `Well, sorry, I would have actually supported the Office of the Employment Advocate because it might have worked.' I think she said, `It might've worked.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `might.'

—It had a possibility. But because she did not get her way on some of those amendments, that was it. She is prepared, even though there is going to be AWAs out there—as she knows—to take the position that there is no independent and free advice to people. She is prepared to deny that. She has already admitted that the legislation is likely to go through, that there will be Australian workplace agreements, and that people will need help, that people from non-English speaking backgrounds will need help, that young people will need help, women will need help, all of the disadvantaged groups within the community—
—You can do that through the department.

—I will move to that argument. She does not want this office that will, we have said, be available to people. We will be able to delegate it down to other organisations and community centres. But you are saying, `No, we don't want that advice to be available. We would rather let those people do it.' The alternative, as Senator Sherry interjects—and I presume the Greens back this—is that you roll it into the department. You, Senator Sherry, were talking—
—The department can provide the free legal advice, but you have cut the budget.

—I am advised, just to reinforce that point, Senator Margetts, that the government is considering delegating and contracting advice given to the community groups. That means resources. Maybe you will change your mind and vote for the schedule now.
—You can wait till Monday.

—I look forward to seeing you on Monday. That is quite right. The point I was getting to was that I have been implored by my Western Australian colleague Senator McKiernan to answer your questions, and I will. You have set about creating this bureaucracy. We are actually setting up a different organisation to deal with the Australian—
—Another bureaucracy.

—We are not. It is within the department, within the division. What you are saying is, `Take a division that has already got a defined role.' We are creating a whole new structure with these workplace agreements, and we are setting up an advice giving organisation. It has different functions to the division that deals with it at the moment. It is not ill-conceived, as you said, and it is certainly far from unnecessary. We want to give this a special set of functions and powers. That is what we have just spent the last couple of hours debating.

BREAK.PARA: We have made it independent, but we have given the minister the power to give these directions that we were debating earlier. We believe that it is necessary. To have the AWAs system in place without an Employment Advocate out there, which is clearly what Senator Margetts and the ALP would envisage, would, of course, disadvantage many people. We actually want to advantage these people. We want to give them this flexibility, they can stay in awards, they can stay in certified agreements, or they can move to AWAs and make these arrangements.
Consideration interrupted; progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja criticised me yesterday—I should add, amongst other days—for using a figure of 40 per cent in the higher education statement to indicate the student contribution to education in Denmark. She preferred the use of another column of figures in the same OECD table showing Denmark at 1.2 per cent, neglecting, however, to add that in that column it shows Australia as zero. As a measure of what students contributed in 1992 to education, this is clearly silly.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had the department look at the matter and the bottom line is that neither column of figures from the OECD seems to provide a very satisfactory basis for the comparisons we are after. So much so in fact that the OECD has told the department that the table will not be included in future publications. Nobody is misleading anybody here. We are all just labouring—the OECD included, I might add—in good faith in a very messy statistical area.

PARA.BREAK: The note from the department, which I am happy to provide, confirms this. I table a note from the department in relation to this matter, coupled with the table from the OECD docu ment and the explanatory definitions behind that table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the adjournment debate tonight to again highlight what has clearly been an exercise in ratting on the Tasmanian public by the current government, and particularly in respect of the now member for Bass, Warwick Smith, who, I must say, has not read Mr Howard's ministerial guidelines in terms of honesty, because he, on a number of occasions, has been totally dishonest with the people in Tasmania, particularly the people of Bass.
—Senator, I think you have just expressed yourself in a way that reflects upon the member of another place. Perhaps you should rephrase your statement.

—Madam President, can I say that it certainly gives the appearance of being dishonest with regard to things that Mr Smith says. When I read some of the public statements that he has made, then I think that will become a bit clearer. I go firstly to the issue of the Tasmanian package—the big promise by the then Liberal opposition. John Howard announced this package on 7 February 1996. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania has a unique place in the Commonwealth. The federal government has a special responsibility to achieve equality for Tasmanians in developing opportunities for their state. The coalition accepts this responsibility and in government will implement the initiatives detailed in the Tasmania package. The Tasmania package financial commitments, which amount to $67.15 million over three years, will be funded over and above the financial assistance grants made by the Commonwealth to the states.
It goes on to outline a few things with regard to the Tasmania package and what will be provided.

In so far as legal services are concerned, in this case as they relate to the Family Court in Launceston, due to the budget cutbacks of this government, the Family Court in Launceston has closed as such. But Mr Smith made a number of public statements, both prior to the election, during the election and after the election—since he has become a minister, in fact. I would like to refer to some of those statements. In May 1995, Mr Smith attacked us in government and made comments in a press release that he issued on 28 May 1995. He said:
During last week's visit, John Howard met with Mr. Steven Smith, the State Secretary of the association—
that is, the lawyers association—
to discuss the implications for people living in Northern Tasmania and is very concerned at the downgraded and much more expensive service that Labor now wants to foist upon us.
Mr Smith said he would be urgently contacting the Shadow Attorney General, Senator Amanda Vanstone, to ensure that the Family Law Court in Launceston would not be downgraded.
He went on to say:

It shows yet again how out of touch the Labor Party is when it comes to the basic needs of people living in our area and how arrogant they can be when they expect people to pay an extra $500 to $600 for a service they need when in a state of emotional upheaval.
In another press statement of 7 August 1995 in part he said:
What is Silvia Smith—
the then member for Bass—
doing besides nodding in agreement with everything that Paul Keating wants to do?
A Justice Statement should be justice for all and, unfortunately, northern Tasmania is being treated with injustice by Labor.
He went on further in a press statement of 12 November 1995 to say:
As the Federal Member for Bass, I would ensure that a future Coalition Government sees that Tasmania receives the necessary share of social resources to help alleviate this problem.
The situation in Launceston is very serious with the current Family Law Court very overcrowded. A visiting Family Court Judge is here in November for just eight days.
Warwick Smith believes this is unacceptable.
He went on to say:
I will continue to fight for a full time resident Family Court Judge to be in Launceston. The need is clearly evident, and must be met.
He was reported in the Examiner in August 1995 as saying:
He said that the coalition would maintain the status quo—
that is, a Family Court judge based in Launceston—
that saw one judge based in Launceston and two in Hobart before Mr Justice Butler's move.
Mr Smith said he had discussed the issue with Shadow Attorney General Amanda Vanstone, whom he believes will visit Tasmania soon.
In July this year—since he became a minister—Mr Smith wrote a letter to the editor of the Examiner . In part, it says:

It is of deep concern that an understanding between the Chief Justice and the Family Law practitioners at their meeting in mid‐June that no decision would be made until a further meeting took place is of concern. The Court administration has gazumped a full consideration of all matters put to the Chief Justice.

The current practice of the Court arrangements being left solely to the Court is questionable in my view. Clearly this issue and the proposed arrangement by the Court administration will need to be reviewed in the light of experience and some most fundamental questions of court administration and access continue to require attention.
It is signed Warwick Smith, federal member for Bass and minister.

Of course, we know that we have been going through the estimates process. In questions that I put to the Family Court people in estimates they indicated that the Family Court has closed and there will not be a Family Court judge in Launceston. But the decision relating to the appointment of a Family Court judge is a matter for the government. Warwick Smith made fundamental commitments to the people of Bass and to the people of Tasmania, public commitments that he is clearly not prepared to keep. He has had the opportunity to have this question addressed by the now Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). I am not aware that he has taken any steps to do so. Indeed, on another issue he has called Tasmanians `whingers'. It is totally unacceptable that a minister who would be aware—because he was previously a shadow minister and was even once touted as a potential leader of the Liberal Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is more than they will ever say about you.

—That is right, Senator Abetz—he lost his seat. Above all other people, he should have a clear understanding of what is required in terms of honesty and integrity with regard to ministers and members of the government. As I said, questions to estimates indicated that they were still going to seek to have the Family Court judge not replaced in Tasmania, but based in Melbourne. The supposed savings that have been touted about as the reason for not having a Family Court judge based in Launceston would seem to me to be somewhat diminished. There may be some savings because, as I understand it, the Family Court judge used to travel from Tasmania to the mainland, Victoria in particular, to do work there. But Mr Warwick Smith gave the people of Bass a fundamental commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: If the judge is to be replaced—and it is my understanding that he may well be—with a judge based in Melbourne, then it makes my criticism of Warwick Smith all the more legitimate and it makes all the more true the claim that I make that Mr Smith has clearly, in his own public statements, been dishonest with the people of Bass and with the people of Tasmania. Either he should apologise for that or he should go to the Prime Minister and say, `I haven't adhered to the ministerial code of conduct, I haven't been open and honest in my public dealings. I have, in fact, made statements in an attempt to get myself elected to parliament and I have conned the people of Tasmania.' He should do one of two things: either apologise or resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I was not able to catch the comments earlier by the minister, Senator Vanstone, but I suspect that the topic that she was referring to, the issue of course costs for Australian university students versus the costs of Danish students, is an issue that I will have to take up in another adjournment debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to discuss a number of education issues, including some comments made in question time yesterday by Senator Amanda Vanstone, strangely enough attacking me again over issues that I have raised in this place. It is important to get on record an issue I raised today in relation to the dependent spouse allowance. An issue of great concern is the fact that this chamber had, in effect, disallowed certain Austudy regulations and, in doing so, reinstated the dependent spouse allowance. That took place on 10 September this year. Unfortunately, more than seven weeks later we are yet to see any of those eligible recipients getting those dependent spouse allowance benefits.

The DSA is paid to students who have a dependent spouse or at least one dependent child. I would like the minister to turn up in this place some time next week and explain that those students who are eligible to apply have been informed that they are eligible and that all those students who have previously been in receipt of those DSA benefits are actually now receiving them, and also to refute the claims and the evidence that we have—and it is advice that comes to the Australian Democrats from the Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances—that DEETYA are stating the reason that these benefits are not being paid, or that students are not being informed, is that the computer does not allow for the DSA any more. That means the computer software, presumably, has been lost or taken out of the computer and has not been reinstalled.

As a consequence of that, up to 15,000 people could be affected by this change and the Democrats are very concerned that these students have not been paid, despite the fact that it is the will of the Senate. I argue that this government is defying the will of the Senate by failing to provide those needy and eligible students with the payments to which they are entitled. However, in her answer to me today the minister raised the issue of drought affected students and their families and used that to attack the Australian Democrats yet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do to fix that up?

—We are quite happy to fix that up. You will note—through you, Madam President—that Senator Panizza mentions the issue of drought affected students. Not one drought affected family is affected by the change. We could put those regulations back tomorrow and they will not have missed out on any payments, as opposed to those students who are eligible for the DSA who are missing out on dollars every week. We are talking about struggling families here with dependent spouses or children. Unfortunately, the minister has seen fit to attack us on a number of occasions using that example—she certainly found the time to write a number of press releases on it, I believe—but she has not yet found the time to inquire what is happening with DSA recipients or those people who would be eligible to apply for the DSA.

SPEECH.PARA: In another issue that was raised yesterday, Minister Vanstone took issue with some figures that I used that demonstrate that students in Australian higher education institutions would, after the coalition's changes to higher education policy, be paying some of the highest tuition fees in the Western world. In fact, the evidence that we have seen demonstrates that we would be second highest in the entire world, second only to South Korea. I would like to cite the minister's comments because she has come up with some very different figures from those that I used in the chamber yesterday. The minister claims:
We have estimated that on average with the benefits, taking into account the benefits of the implicit interest subsidy under the deferral option used by some—that is, the deferral of their payment—
it sounds like something from Yes, Minister —
and the up‐front discount used by others, students will contribute, on average, about 27 per cent of the cost of their tuition.

We did not find it particularly difficult to place Australia in comparison with other countries using the World Bank table to which the minister also referred. In Australia, operating grant expenditure per equivalent full‐time student unit is $10,670. That is what it is in 1996. This figure is actually taken from the government reports, the 1997‐99 triennial report, using tables 4.3 and 4.4, for the record.

PARA.BREAK: Using this figure, Australian students currently pay fees—that is HECS—equivalent to 21 per cent of recurrent expenditure. This currently places Australia in eighth highest position on the World Bank chart of 33 countries, even at current levels of the contri bution of the HECS. That is not taking into account the proposed changes or the HECS hikes by this government. That means we are two places behind the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the proposed new changes and the differential HECS scheme, students will be paying $4,500 on average, or perhaps even a little less, because of relative numbers in each HECS band. This would actually place Australia at the top of the table with over 42 per cent. I look forward to the minister coming back to explain how she managed to come up with a figure of around 27 per cent when the calculations that have been done by my office, by me, by the National Tertiary Education Union and, I imagine, by a number of other bodies using the same system outlined by the World Bank and the World Bank charts, show that we have reached a figure of 42 per cent.

Regardless of the—I think the words that Senator Vanstone showed me just then were `fanciful' or `difficult'—statistics that we were using, under the proposed changes Australian students will be paying fees that are prohibitively high. They are exorbitant fees. As we heard on Monday during a public hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, they will shift the composition towards the wealthier students in this country. We will ensure that those people who have the money to pay will be those who are entitled to access higher education in this country.

I am not surprised that the minister is playing with figures or that she has misled the parliament on this issue as well as on a number of issues. I am willing to stand corrected on this one, but it adds to a long list. In the last couple of weeks we have seen so many slips by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The Democrats could not help but take offence at some of the accusations made at us and pointed to us regarding our home page on the Internet. To accuse us of breaching privacy provisions was absolutely outrageous. To accuse us of compiling lists for mailing and other services was just outrageous.

BREAK.PARA: I am only glad that the minister had to come in here and apologise, not for that accusation—she is yet to take that one back—but to admit her error that she had not received faxes from students and from members of the community who were protesting against higher education contribution changes, or Austudy changes for that matter, through our Internet and e-mail service. The minister had received faxes and we had transmission records as evidence. I am glad that the minister chose to apologise on that issue.

We only need to mention the words `Wright family' to bring a shiver to the spine of the minister. That is another example of an error that was made by the minister and by her department. Again, thankfully, she has apologised for that mistake. But it has done nothing except perpetuate the stereotype that Austudy and student financial assistance in this country is easy to access and it is particularly generous when we know that eligibility criteria for such an scheme are incredibly tight, very stringent and imposed very strongly by the department.

In this parliament over the last fortnight the most recent argument we have had involving the minister has related to her comments about employment projections and the achievability of the five per cent unemployment target by the turn of the century. The minister has been forced to acknowledge, and hopefully will concede further, that she made a mistake on that issue as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I was going to devote my speech on the adjournment debate to some very ill-considered comments of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who referred to parliamentarians on both sides of this parliament—both in the lower house and here in the Senate—as `bastards, bitches and ignoramuses' and somehow thought that by using that description he would increase the tone and level of the euthanasia debate within this country and inject some maturity into the debate. I simply say to Mr Stone: if you want to increase and raise the level of the euthana sia debate within this country, you ought desist from using those sorts of words; you do not increase your own stature by trying to cut off at the knees those who seem to oppose you.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply make the plea to the Chief Minister that he restrain from that sort of extravagant language, come back down to earth and realise that people on all sides of this parliament are giving the euthanasia debate serious and genuine consideration and that that sort of terminology employed by him does no benefit for the debate and, above all, does him no credit whatsoever.

The matter that I want to debate this evening is the exciting announcement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) and the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) this evening of the new woodchip licences. That is a great boost and boon to our economy, particularly that of Tasmania. It will provide security for jobs and potential for extra jobs.

It is interesting that the previous Labor contributor in this debate just continued with his normal attacks. Yesterday it was on Senator Newman about her office. Tonight it was on the member for Bass, Warwick Smith. He gets into these personal attacks rather than getting on with the real job. That is what the government has been doing.

It is interesting that the Labor senator who devoted 10 minutes of his time to a personal attack on the member for Bass also rejoices in the title of being president of the CFMEU in Tasmania, which allegedly represents the forest workers. We know that that honourable senator voted against the very export woodchip regulations which have now allowed Tasmania to benefit in such a very real way and provide extra jobs for Tasmanians. The announcement will provide certainty for timber workers and investors alike. There is the prospect of even further jobs in the timber sector.

The allocation of licences is the culmination of the Liberal government's commitment to Tasmania's timber workers and communities. The small sawmillers in Tasmania will be big winners, as will be the private tree growers. This is a victory for all sectors in the timber industry, especially for workers.

After a decade of bungling this issue by the Labor Party and the Labor government, the Liberal Party has now successfully delivered certainty within the first 12 months of government, in fact, within the first eight months of government. So the people out there can contrast 10 years of bungling and uncertainty with the delivery of certainty, job security and, indeed, more job opportunities within only eight months.

This shift and definite action shows the high priority that the government has given to providing security for timber workers. That is in stark contrast to Labor which is still wallowing in the aftermath of its shameful failed attempt to defeat the regulations which allowed for these new job and investment opportunities. Timber workers can now be absolutely satisfied right around Australia in regional seats, and especially in my home state of Tasmania, that it is the Liberal Party that genuinely delivers job security and opportunities for them.

I have been actively involved, ever since being appointed to the Senate, in pursuing the interests of the timber workers and the timber industry and in providing security and certainty for them. Within the two and a half years that I have been here, this really is the culmination of very important decisions that have been taken and it has allowed people to realise that we, in the Liberal Party, are genuinely concerned about the timber industry, about workers and about providing job opportunities.

Our first task was to win government. The second task was to bring in appropriate regulations. The third and final task has been delivered this evening in the provision of those licences. I can understand that senators opposite feel somewhat concerned whenever the issue of woodchips is mentioned. The federal campaign consultative panel of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales said that there were certain real problems in their strategy. They said:
There was, however, a number of issues involving ministers during the final term of the government which had damaged the image of the party.

Do you know what they were? They were: Carmen Lawrence, the whiteboard affair and woodchipping. What do they do? They appoint Carmen Lawrence as Shadow Minister for the Environment. She has opposed the creation of every single one of the new jobs that are going to be provided as a result of these decisions. We do not even have to rely on the New South Wales division of the Labor Party because a state colleague of mine, Senator Sue Mackay, Labor senator for Tasmania, assisted the Labor Party federally in analysing the problems that Labor had at the last election. She wrote, along with Barry Jones, the national president and the national secretary Gary Gray, these words under the heading, `Priorities and balance and what went wrong'. The first item was woodchips, jobs and environment. It reads:
The logging dispute and the blockade of parliament house exposed seemingly intractable conflicts between two of Labor's important constituencies—workers and environmentalists.

They tried to sit on the barbwire fence and it did untold damage to both sectors during the last election. But they were pushed off the fence when they voted on the export woodchip regulations. When they voted on those, they jumped off on the side of the environmentalists, thus deserting the workers. Undoubtedly, that is why people such as the honourable senators opposite, such as Senator Murphy, come into this House day after day trying to engage in personal attacks on Senator Newman, the member for Bass, rather than dealing with the real issues—because they know. Senator Murphy, himself, is allegedly the president of the forest workers union in Tasmania. He voted against the regulations which provided them with certainty. He voted against the regulations which would provide new job opportunities.

As a party, within the first eight months of government, we have delivered certainty and security to this industry, something that Labor could not do for over a decade. Why? Because they were trying to play off both sides. We unashamedly say that we want environmental responsibility but we also want to provide security.

BREAK.PARA: The people of Australia need to realise that a lot of these extra export woodchip opportunities basically are from sawmill residues which would otherwise have been burnt or from waste which lies on the forest floor and, under Labor's environmental policy, it lies there either to rot or burn. We say, `Let us export it. Let us provide jobs. Let us provide environmental responsibility and let us provide jobs for the unemployed around this country.' Today's announcement has been very welcome, especially by the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to talk on an issue very close to my heart, that of child care. Child care was certainly a major issue for me in considering entering this place and in putting my name forward in the election. Quality care for my children was an absolute priority and, in fact, a prerequisite to my making that decision. I knew that many of my nights would be spent in this place like this evening or at other commitments that come along with job and I needed to be very confident that the care my children were receiving was not only adequate but also the very best that I could afford.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the bulk of my salary is paid for that care makes me no different from most other parents in the work force. This is not often experienced even by senators and I think that most senators are rarely in a position these days to use formal care on a day‐to‐day basis. If they had to, I suspect that the government would not be so keen on making their changes to child‐care arrangements.

To more easily understand the commitment that many families are making towards child care, consider this: the cost of sending a primary school child to, for example, Canberra Boys Grammar is comparable to the cost of sending a one‐year‐old to full-time care. For most of us, a private school education is out of reach and this interesting fact was brought to my attention by a constituent. I thought it would be most helpful to those opposite to understand the commitment parents make to ensuring that their children receive the best quality care available.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to offer those in this place who have never personally confronted the issue of finding full-time care a little history lesson, if I may. Child‐care centres developed from a need. The majority were centres established and organised by parents or community groups like the local parish church or the YWCA. They often used any large building they could access cheaply.

One of Canberra's first centres, Black Mountain, was set up in a scout hall 17 years ago by parents who could not find care for their children. The scout hall, with its wooden floors and high windows, was the only place available. There was not any heating, other than an open fireplace, and that could not be used because it was too dangerous for the young children. Children from toddlers to preschoolers shared the same space and there were a few swings outside.

The hall had to be cleared of furniture each evening and every time it rained heavily the stormwater drain outside would overflow and flow into the hall, and the workers would have to form a bailing line to bail out the water. It was pretty tough going. The conditions, by today's standards, were atrocious, but one parent using the care at the time has described the workers as always being terrific and never complaining. Often parents themselves would come down to relieve sick workers.

The toll on both parents and workers was great, but the return was even greater. Within months of opening, the centre was full and had a massive waiting list. Regardless of the accommodation, the love of the carers and the quality of the program offered brought parents to the centre's door. But I am sure that Black Mountain was not unique. There was a need and parents in the community responded. That need is no less today. But in 1996, this government has set out to destroy these community centres by abolishing the subsidy they had been receiving to assist with administration of the centres.

These are non-profit centres. They fundraise tirelessly to buy new toys, subsidise excursions and upgrade their facilities, and they are often the only places that will take in very young babies and special needs children. The operational subsidy is recognition of the professionalism of the parents who manage the centres.

In the dogged philosophical pursuit of competition, this government is demanding that these centres compete with private centres, centres run to make a profit. I simply do not understand this approach. Community centres are non-profit organisations. They do not make money. Indeed, one should probably consider them as a charity. Yet this government wants to cut all the assistance it provides.

To add salt to this wound, the government has made a pretty back‐handed offer for financial counselling from consultants to the value of about $8 million. This government has little understanding, obviously, of the insult this proposal is. Not only does it say that they don't think community centres run by parents and community groups should exist, but this government does not think they can manage their own financial affairs.

These centres have been managing their own affairs for the past 20 years—centres on a shoestring, maintaining high standards and flexibility for families in difficult times. This government's actions are an insult to them. Abolishing subsidies in centres will either close them or they will have to charge parents an extra $30 a week. For the senators opposite $30 a week probably is not so much, but for most parents out there $30 a week may well be the difference between working and not. It may well be the difference between formal, qualified care and over‐the‐fence, backyard care. Parents may be forced to remove their children from supervised care and place their trust in someone who may be caring for numerous children, in unsafe homes, with no knowledge or regulation or guidance as to what occurs once the door closes.

This is what child care in Australia has been dragged from. This is where the past 20 years of lobbying and hard work has taken child care. To consider a return to such conditions raises great concerns amongst the long‐time workers in the industry. This government has no regard for the consequences of their actions.

I was honoured to speak at a family picnic day last weekend that concluded Children's Week in the ACT. Ignoring the storm clouds, hundreds of people gathered at Commonwealth Park to celebrate quality child care and the people who deliver it. Speakers included child‐care workers, parents, students and directors of centres. Family day care, community centres and private centres were represented. The various sectors of the industry in the ACT have shown an unusual solidarity in opposing these all‐encompassing threats to child care.

Many of the speakers spoke of the consequences of the other changes this government intends for child care. The 50‐hour a week cap on child‐care assistance does not recognise the needs of shift workers, workers who work overtime or students. Centres, whether private or community, will either charge more or restrict hours. Parents who already use extended hours will either lose their jobs or have to find more money. The tampering with the eligibility for child‐care assistance will mean fewer families will get assistance.

I wish senators opposite could meet the people who work in child care. The fact that we get so much for so little—we pay workers who care for children less than we pay a person to tend plants—is pure dedication. They are so dedicated and care so much about the standard of care they provide. The thought of taking child care back 20 years concerns them and most have been around child care over those years and have worked hard at giving Australian children one of the very best child‐care systems in the world. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government respond positively to a request by the five nuclear weapon states to carry the text of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) for ratification; if so, why.

(2)(a) Does the current CTBT text contain an entry into force provision that requires all 44 named countries, including India, Pakistan and Israel, to sign the treaty before it enters into force; and (b) has India refused to sign the treaty due to the lack of a timetable for disarmament or timetable for negotiations for disarmament.
(3)(a) Given the problems with the entry into force provision, does the Government believe the CTBT will ever enter into force; and (b) if it fails to do so, what value is it.

(4) Does the Government believe a timetable for disarmament within a CTBT would fall within the International Court of Justice decision ruling on the illegality of nuclear weapons and within the recommendations of the Canberra Commission; if not, why not.

(5) Given that India and the G21 nations are showing concern over the lack of disarmament provisions in the CTBT: (a) will the Australian Government use its position as co‐sponsor to take the opportunity to strengthen the CTBT either by pushing for a timetable for disarmament or a timetable for negotiations for disarmament; and (b) will the Australian Government take this to the UNGA; if not, why not.

(6)(a) What would Australia's position be if the G21 nations insisted on alterations to the CTBT text to remove the entry into force provision and/or disarmament provisions; and (b) in the same circumstances, what would Australia's position be if the P5 nations threatened to walk away from the treaty.

(7)(a) Will the Australian Government support measures outside the text of the CTBT, such as an ad hoc committee on nuclear disarmament at Geneva suggested by the Associate Director of International Physicians for the prevention of Nuclear War; and (b) will the Government support motions outside the text within the upcoming session of the UNGA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The recent adoption and opening for signature of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), in which Australia played a major role, is an historic step forward in global efforts to advance nuclear non‐proliferation and disarmament goals. Australia was very concerned that time was running out for the international community to have a CTBT open for signature by September 1996, as had been called for unanimously by the UN General Assembly last year. That is why, when all avenues were exhausted in the Conference on Disarmament, Australia acted promptly and initiated action which allowed the draft CTBT to be adopted and opened for signature by the international community at the UN General Assembly. Before making the final decision to go ahead, we consulted several key countries, including the nuclear weapon states, but the decision to take the CTBT to the United Nations for adoption was purely an Australian initiative. Australia's action was the natural conclusion to more than twenty years work to achieve a permanent end to nuclear testing.

(2)(a) The CTBT adopted by the United Nations General Assembly and opened for signature on 24 September 1996 will enter into force 180 days after the date of deposit of the instruments of ratification by all 44 states listed in the treaty, including the five nuclear weapon states and India, Pakistan and Israel, but in no case earlier than two years after the treaty's opening for signature.
(b) Yes.

(3) Australia is urging all states that have not yet done so to sign and then ratify the CTBT as soon as possible, so that it can be fully implemented. If the CTBT has not entered into force within three years of its opening for signature, there will be a Conference of States Parties to consider and decide by consensus what measures consistent with international law may be undertaken to accelerate the ratification process in order to facilitate the early entry into force of the treaty. This process will be repeated at subsequent anniversaries of the opening for signature of the treaty, until its entry into force.

Even if the CTBT does not enter into force for some time, signature of the treaty will constitute a political and moral commitment to renounce nuclear testing. There is also a principle of international law that a state which has signed a treaty is obliged to refrain from acts which would defeat the object and purpose of the treaty even before its entry into force. Each of the five nuclear weapon states—the United States, the United Kingdom, Russia, France and China—signed the CTBT upon its opening for signature at the United Nations in New York on 24 September. The fact that over 100 countries have signed the treaty since 24 September demonstrates the strength of international feeling against nuclear testing. By bringing nuclear testing to an end, the CTBT is a vital step in the nuclear disarmament process.

(4) No. In its recent advisory opinion, the International Court of Justice (ICJ) unanimously agreed that there exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all its aspects under strict and effective international control. The Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons carefully considered the merits of setting out a precise timeframe for the elimination of nuclear weapons, but elected not to do so. The Commission recommended that nuclear weapon elimination should be conducted as a series of phased, verified reductions, and emphasised that "the process followed must ensure that no state feels, at any stage, that further nuclear disarmament is a threat to security." The Government does not see any advantage in being prescriptive as to the detail, timing or sequence of nuclear disarmament. That is also the approach taken by the Commission. See also the answer to question 5.

(5) As noted in the answer to question (1), the CTBT has been adopted by the UN General Assembly and opened for signature. For the first time, the international community can reasonably hope and expect that nuclear testing will not be part of the future to be faced by succeeding generations. The Australian Government recognises that the CTBT is not a perfect treaty. However, as the overwhelming vote in favour of the CTBT resolution at the United Nations demonstrates, the vast majority of countries believe that the CTBT adopted by the UN General Assembly and opened for signature is as fair a reflection of the middle ground as it was possible to achieve.

The Government is committed to the twin goals of preventing proliferation of nuclear weapons and working through progressive balanced steps towards complete nuclear disarmament. However, neither this nor preceding governments in Australia have supported the concept of a so‐called timebound framework for nuclear disarmament. The Government's priority in this area is to focus on practical, realistic steps to achieve the ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons. It considers that calls for a restrictive timebound approach to the disarmament process are not realistic, and therefore do not advance the cause of disarmament in any concrete or practical way. What is required to advance the cause of nuclear disarmament is a patient and dogged pursuit of the various interlocking steps on the path to the complete elimination of nuclear weapons. In the Government's view, it simply does not make sense to advocate the sort of tight, sterile linkage that holds one negotiation or process hostage to the conclusion of another. The most likely outcome of such an approach would be impasse. The Government believes that it is more productive for the international community to concentrate on actually achieving further progress towards nuclear disarmament rather than seeking to debate an artificial timetable.

(6) There were no proposals to alter the text of the CTBT at the resumed UNGA 50 session. The UN resolution adopting the CTBT and opening it for signature was adopted by an overwhelming majority of states.

(7) As noted in the answer to question (5), the Government is committed to the twin goals of preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and working through progressive balanced steps towards complete nuclear disarmament. Among the most immediate tasks will be to work for the early commencement of substantive negotiations in the Conference on Disarmament on a convention prohibiting the production of fissile material for use in nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices (known as a "cut‐off" convention). This is widely acknowledged as the next logical multilateral step after a CTBT and would be a major new addition to the process of nuclear disarmament and to strengthening barriers to nuclear proliferation. Australia is also interested in working for agreement in the Conference on Disarmament on an appropriate framework for the discussion of nuclear disarmament questions, as part of a future comprehensive agenda.

The nuclear weapon states will continue to bear the major responsibility for steps to reduce further their nuclear stockpiles, with a view to their ultimate elimination. Australia will continue to encourage the nuclear weapon states to maintain the good progress achieved over the past several years in bringing about significant reductions to their nuclear stockpiles/arsenals. The recently released report of the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons, which the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, presented to the UN General Assembly on 30 September 1996 and which the Government will present to the Conference on Disarmament in January 1997, makes a significant contribution to new international thinking on nuclear disarmament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are you aware of charges against Jess Watson and Sally‐Anne Watson, alleging trespass at the Indonesian Consulate in Darwin on 17 August 1996.

(2) Are you aware that Jess Watson and Sally‐Anne Watson allege that they were assaulted by two employees of the Indonesian Consulate on 17 August 1996, and that they laid official complaints with the Northern Territory police.
(3) What is the procedure for investigating and charging employees of a foreign consulate for any alleged offence carried out in the grounds of the consulate.
(4) Who is responsible for laying charges.
(5) What action has been taken in relation to the complaints made by Jess Watson and Sally‐Anne Watson in this case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two women, Jess Watson and Sally‐Anne Watson, were arrested allegedly for trespassing upon the premises of the Indonesian Consulate in Darwin on 17 August 1996. They have been charged under the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971, which gives effect to the special obligations imposed on Australia under international law in relation to the protection of diplomatic and consular premises and staff. The matter is listed for hearing on 30 January 1997.

(2) Allegations that they were assaulted by two employees of the Indonesian Consulate during the incident have been made by the two women. That matter is currently under investigation by the Northern Territory police. I am not able to comment further.

(3) Where it is alleged an offence has taken place on the premises of a foreign consulate, it would be up to the local police to investigate. There may be issues of consular immunity involved, the waiver of which, under international law, is a matter for the sending state.
(4) Where there is no consular immunity involved, or immunity has been waived, it would be a matter for the local police to lay charges.
(5) The matter is still under investigation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Australian Government's position on France's decision to rule out full independence for New Caledonia (Kanaky) as an option to follow the referendum on self‐determination in 1998.

(2) In line with the United Nations' principles and practices for decolonisation, what action will the Government take to ensure that the 1998 referendum is fair and independent of the French Government's determination to stop New Caledonia achieving full independence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government believes that the question of the future of the territory is a matter to be resolved by the people of the territory in consultation with France, and that continued negotiations in the territory, in the context of the Matignon Accords, offer the best hope for a peaceful and lasting solution.

In New Caledonia, most of the Melanesian community supports independence, but the Melanesians comprise only a minority overall, though a large one at 45 per cent of the total population. In contrast, however, most of the rest of the population, comprising a clear electoral majority overall, is opposed to independence and wishes to maintain close links with France.

Negotiations on the political future of New Caledonia are under way between the French Government and the principal political forces in the territory. These negotiations are being held in the context of the Matignon Accords, a set of agreements reached in 1988 which followed a period of serious unrest, during which some fifty people were killed. In April of this year the French Government indicated that it did not see a transition to independence at this time as consistent with efforts to attain a broadly‐supported consensus resolution of uncertainties about the territory's constitutional future. At that time the French Government expressed a preference for increased autonomy in the territory, without however ruling out further constitutional evolution in due course.

In recent months all parties to the negotiations have expressed a preference for the negotiation of a compromise solution in advance of the referendum planned for 1998. There is widespread concern that a referendum which offered a stark choice would lead to renewed divisions and conflict. A broad range of options is being considered, and the possibility of a form of independence in the longer‐term is not necessarily excluded.

The Government has supported the monitoring of developments in New Caledonia by a ministerial committee of the South Pacific Forum. This committee visited New Caledonia in August, and reported to the South Pacific Forum, at its meeting in Majuro, Marshall Islands in September, that reasonable progress had occurred. The Forum Leaders called on all parties in New Caledonia to continue dialogue in search for a durable political solution to the question of the territory's long term future.
(2) Until further details are available about arrangements for the proposed referendum, it is not possible to comment further on the referendum, though we will continue to monitor developments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 9 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Commonwealth Government play any role in facilitating the decision by Hokushin to build a medium density fibreboard plant (Starwood) at Bell Bay, Tasmania; if so, in what ways did the Commonwealth assist the project.

(2) Is it a fact that 70 per cent of the feedstock for the plant in its first year of operation be from native forests; if not, what volumes of the feedstock will come from native forests in its first year of operation and at different stages of its operating life, and what proportion of the total do these volumes represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Through the Major Projects Feasibility Study fund, the Commonwealth Government contributed $65,000 to a pre-feasibility study of a medium density fibreboard (MDF) plant in Tasmania. The study was completed in September 1993.

Based on the positive outcome from the study, an investment brief was prepared which the Commonwealth Investment Promotion and Facilitation Program (IP&F) circulated through its investment counsellor network in Asia, North America and Europe. The Japanese firm, Hokushin Co Ltd, responded to the brief and subsequently committed to establish an MDF plant at Bell Bay in August 1994. The IP&F Program, in conjunction with the Tasmanian Government agencies arranged meetings for Hokushin in Tasmania, assisted with the efficient government approvals for the project and has provided information on relevant government programs.

Hokushin's $115 million timber processing project was granted Major Project Facilitation (MPF) status by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology in August 1994. MPF status provides the proponent with Commonwealth Government support to facilitate the projects approvals process, ensuring that progress is not subject to, delays and duplication of approvals. MPF status provides in-kind support only, and there has been no financial support from the Commonwealth made to Hokushin in relation to the project. The MDF plant provides substantial value adding to low grade timber resource and is expected to generate $70 million in exports annually.
This project is consistent with Government policy to add value to low value woodchips.

(2) No. The proposed feedstock to be used in this value adding plant is expected to be a mixture of 50% radiata pine and 50% eucalypt. The eucalypt is to be sourced from privately owned forests, sawmill residues and other designated production forests.

It is expected that the eucalypt source may vary over time in relation to forest planning changes and as more eucalypt plantations become available. I understand the company is already a joint venture partner with Forestry Tasmania in a radiata pine plantation and there is an expectation that this joint venture may be widened to take in eucalypt plantations.
